For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201ctensor network state\u201d and \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d in a Pytheus-compatible network (no dynamic feedback, only static LIN-OP + pair sources or single emitters, focus on network transformations like swapping/teleportation, not raw state generation).\n    1) Hierarchical (tree) entanglement swapping as a renormalization step: use a binary-tree of Bell-pair sources and Bell measurements to coarse-grain a line of Bell pairs into a single long-range pair. Vary which measurements are performed to drive a \u201cphase transition\u201d in network connectivity.\n    2) MPS teleportation module: take an MPS of bond-dimension 2 across three sites, and teleport it end-to-end via sequential Bell measurements, showing how measurement order (which bonds you cut first) changes the fidelity of teleportation\u2014a \u201cmeasurement-induced network phase\u201d in teleportation performance.\n    3) Fusion-gate percolation: build a 1D cluster\u2010like graph state by probabilistic fusion gates (Type-II fusion) on Bell pairs. By choosing which fusion measurements succeed, one crosses a percolation threshold in connectivity\u2014a photonic measurement-induced phase transition in graph connectivity.  \n  Step 2: Quick novelty/obstacles check.\n    1) Tree RG swapping: novel because prior Pytheus examples only did linear/swapping in parallel or qutrits; no one has done a two-level tree. Pytheus can do two Bell measurements + one more.  \n    2) MPS teleportation: mapping an MPS is effectively a state generation/task; also requires teleportation fidelity measure vs order\u2014hard to phrase as a single static target.  \n    3) Fusion percolation: cluster states are states, and fusion gates need hyper-entanglement references; also under \u201cstate generation.\u201d  \n  Step 3: Pick idea (1): the binary-tree entanglement-swapping RG module.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because, rather than just a chain of independent entanglement\u2010swapping operations, it implements a two-layer tree tensor\u2010network coarse-graining in a single linear\u2010optical circuit. No prior Pytheus experiment has tackled hierarchical, measurement\u2010driven renormalization of entanglement networks.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework\u2014Pytheus can place four probabilistic Bell-pair sources, route their outputs through beam splitters and phase shifters, and perform three post-selected Bell measurements (each realized by ancilla detectors) in a fixed circuit. The \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d emerges by post-selecting on different combinations of those three Bell measurements (e.g. bottom-layer only vs bottom+top), and the tree geometry encodes a simple TTN. No dynamic feedback, no cavities.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nHere is a suggestion for an experiment that combines the ideas of a tensor-network renormalization (a small tree-tensor-network) with a measurement-induced reconfiguration (\u201cphase\u201d) of the entanglement network.  The goal is not to generate a particular exotic state, but to demonstrate a **hierarchical entanglement-swapping module** that implements a two-level renormalization of a chain of Bell pairs.  By post-selecting on different subsets of Bell measurements one realizes different \u201cphases\u201d of network connectivity.\n\nDescription of the target network:\n  \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 Four independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081,\u2026,S\u2084, each emitting one Bell pair (two modes).\n    \u2013 Label the eight output modes as A1,A2 from S\u2081; B1,B2 from S\u2082; C1,C2 from S\u2083; D1,D2 from S\u2084.\n  \u2022 First (bottom) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements M\u2081 on (A2,B1) and M\u2082 on (C2,D1).  \n      \u2022 Each Bell-measurement is realized by linear optics + two ancilla detectors; click patterns herald a successful swap.\n    \u2013 After M\u2081 one obtains a Bell pair between A1 and B2; after M\u2082 a Bell pair between C1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Second (top) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform a third Bell-measurement M\u2083 on the two middle modes B2 and C1 (again via ancilla detectors).  \n      \u2022 A successful click heralds a final Bell pair between A1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d:\n    \u2013 **Phase I** (shallow coarse-graining): post-select on M\u2081 & M\u2082 only.  The network coarsens from 4 pairs \u2192 two Bell pairs.\n    \u2013 **Phase II** (deep coarse-graining): post-select on all three M\u2081, M\u2082, M\u2083.  The network coarsens fully \u2192 one long-range Bell pair.\n  \u2022 Physics question:\n    \u2013 By comparing the output entanglement (Bell-violation or fidelity) between A1 and either B2/C1 (Phase I) vs A1\u2013D2 (Phase II), one directly observes a measurement-induced transformation of the tensor-network geometry (a minimal tree-tensor-network renormalization).  \n    \u2013 One can generalize to larger trees (more Bell pairs and more layers) to study measurement density vs entanglement length\u2014an optical analog of measurement-induced phase transitions in tensor-network models.\n  \u2022 Why Pytheus can design this:\n    \u2013 All operations are static linear-optical elements + probabilistic pair sources + photon-number-resolving detectors.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed.\n    \u2013 One simply encodes the 8 input modes, specifies 3 sets of ancilla detectors (for M\u2081,M\u2082,M\u2083), and enforces that no single source connects A2 to D1 etc. using removed_connections.\n    \u2013 The target is the network transformation (hierarchical entanglement swapping), not a specific many-photon state.\n\nThis \u201cTree-Tensor-Network RG Module\u201d is a new kind of quantum network experiment: it melds tensor-network renormalization ideas with measurement-induced network phases, and can be generalized to deeper trees or to probabilistic measurement patterns."
}

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static 4-Mode Super-Bell-State Analyzer with Single-Photon Ancilla\n\nAbstract: We present a purely network-primitive linear-optical scheme that employs a single ancillary photon and a static 4-mode interferometer\u2014decomposed into three optimized beam splitters\u2014to unambiguously identify all four Bell states (\u03a6\u207a, \u03a6\u207b, \u03a8\u207a, \u03a8\u207b) of two abstract dual-rail qubits with a post-selected success rate of 62.5% and perfect conditional fidelity. Upon successful heralding, the shared Choistate across modes (0,1,2,3) becomes the unnormalized target \u03a8_GHZ=|0000\u27e9+|1111\u27e9, whose discrete Wigner function exhibits negativity and thereby certifies genuine GHZ-basis teleportation within the PyTheus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a suggestion for an experiment that combines the ideas of a tensor-network renormalization (a small tree-tensor-network) with a measurement-induced reconfiguration (\u201cphase\u201d) of the entanglement network.  The goal is not to generate a particular exotic state, but to demonstrate a **hierarchical entanglement-swapping module** that implements a two-level renormalization of a chain of Bell pairs.  By post-selecting on different subsets of Bell measurements one realizes different \u201cphases\u201d of network connectivity.\n\nDescription of the target network:\n  \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 Four independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081,\u2026,S\u2084, each emitting one Bell pair (two modes).\n    \u2013 Label the eight output modes as A1,A2 from S\u2081; B1,B2 from S\u2082; C1,C2 from S\u2083; D1,D2 from S\u2084.\n  \u2022 First (bottom) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements M\u2081 on (A2,B1) and M\u2082 on (C2,D1).  \n      \u2022 Each Bell-measurement is realized by linear optics + two ancilla detectors; click patterns herald a successful swap.\n    \u2013 After M\u2081 one obtains a Bell pair between A1 and B2; after M\u2082 a Bell pair between C1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Second (top) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform a third Bell-measurement M\u2083 on the two middle modes B2 and C1 (again via ancilla detectors).  \n      \u2022 A successful click heralds a final Bell pair between A1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d:\n    \u2013 **Phase I** (shallow coarse-graining): post-select on M\u2081 & M\u2082 only.  The network coarsens from 4 pairs \u2192 two Bell pairs.\n    \u2013 **Phase II** (deep coarse-graining): post-select on all three M\u2081, M\u2082, M\u2083.  The network coarsens fully \u2192 one long-range Bell pair.\n  \u2022 Physics question:\n    \u2013 By comparing the output entanglement (Bell-violation or fidelity) between A1 and either B2/C1 (Phase I) vs A1\u2013D2 (Phase II), one directly observes a measurement-induced transformation of the tensor-network geometry (a minimal tree-tensor-network renormalization).  \n    \u2013 One can generalize to larger trees (more Bell pairs and more layers) to study measurement density vs entanglement length\u2014an optical analog of measurement-induced phase transitions in tensor-network models.\n  \u2022 Why Pytheus can design this:\n    \u2013 All operations are static linear-optical elements + probabilistic pair sources + photon-number-resolving detectors.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed.\n    \u2013 One simply encodes the 8 input modes, specifies 3 sets of ancilla detectors (for M\u2081,M\u2082,M\u2083), and enforces that no single source connects A2 to D1 etc. using removed_connections.\n    \u2013 The target is the network transformation (hierarchical entanglement swapping), not a specific many-photon state.\n\nThis \u201cTree-Tensor-Network RG Module\u201d is a new kind of quantum network experiment: it melds tensor-network renormalization ideas with measurement-induced network phases, and can be generalized to deeper trees or to probabilistic measurement patterns.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposed \u201ctwo\u2010level\u201d hierarchical swap module is essentially just a standard two\u2010hop entanglement\u2010swapping repeater (first swap on A\u2013B and C\u2013D, then swap on B\u2013C) with trivial post\u2010selection on whether you include the top\u2010layer measurement or not.  That construction and the idea of coarse\u2010graining a Bell\u2010pair chain via successive swaps is already textbook and appears in both basic repeater proposals and in our ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network.\u201d  Simply toggling between bottom\u2010layer only or full two\u2010layer swapping phases does not introduce any genuinely new measurement primitive, state or network\u2010phase physics.  To be PRL\u2010worthy, one needs a nontrivial twist\u2014e.g. superposing measurement orders, joint multi\u2010photon projections, or a novel measurement\u2010induced phase transition beyond trivial coarse\u2010graining.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is just the standard two\u2010hop entanglement swap (quantum repeater) in tree form, already well\u2010explored (see \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap\u201d from the ensemble).  You\u2019ll need to propose a truly new measurement primitive or nontrivial network phase transition\u2014such as superposed swap orders, many\u2010body joint measurements, or nonlinear renormalization effects\u2014to be considered novel."
}
{
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. Vary which measurements are performed to drive a \u201cphase transition\u201d in network connectivity.\n    2) MPS teleportation module: take an MPS of bond-dimension 2 across three sites, and teleport it end-to-end via sequential Bell measurements, showing how measurement order (which bonds you cut first) changes the fidelity of teleportation\u2014a \u201cmeasurement-induced network phase\u201d in teleportation performance.\n    3) Fusion-gate percolation: build a 1D cluster\u2010like graph state by probabilistic fusion gates (Type-II fusion) on Bell pairs. By choosing which fusion measurements succeed, one crosses a percolation threshold in connectivity\u2014a photonic measurement-induced phase transition in graph connectivity.  \n  Step 2: Quick novelty/obstacles check.\n    1) Tree RG swapping: novel because prior Pytheus examples only did linear/swapping in parallel or qutrits; no one has done a two-level tree. Pytheus can do two Bell measurements + one more.  \n    2) MPS teleportation: mapping an MPS is effectively a state generation/task; also requires teleportation fidelity measure vs order\u2014hard to phrase as a single static target.  \n    3) Fusion percolation: cluster states are states, and fusion gates need hyper-entanglement references; also under \u201cstate generation.\u201d  \n  Step 3: Pick idea (1): the binary-tree entanglement-swapping RG module.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because, rather than just a chain of independent entanglement\u2010swapping operations, it implements a two-layer tree tensor\u2010network coarse-graining in a single linear\u2010optical circuit. No prior Pytheus experiment has tackled hierarchical, measurement\u2010driven renormalization of entanglement networks.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework\u2014Pytheus can place four probabilistic Bell-pair sources, route their outputs through beam splitters and phase shifters, and perform three post-selected Bell measurements (each realized by ancilla detectors) in a fixed circuit. The \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d emerges by post-selecting on different combinations of those three Bell measurements (e.g. bottom-layer only vs bottom+top), and the tree geometry encodes a simple TTN. No dynamic feedback, no cavities.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nHere is a suggestion for an experiment that combines the ideas of a tensor-network renormalization (a small tree-tensor-network) with a measurement-induced reconfiguration (\u201cphase\u201d) of the entanglement network.  The goal is not to generate a particular exotic state, but to demonstrate a **hierarchical entanglement-swapping module** that implements a two-level renormalization of a chain of Bell pairs.  By post-selecting on different subsets of Bell measurements one realizes different \u201cphases\u201d of network connectivity.\n\nDescription of the target network:\n  \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 Four independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081,\u2026,S\u2084, each emitting one Bell pair (two modes).\n    \u2013 Label the eight output modes as A1,A2 from S\u2081; B1,B2 from S\u2082; C1,C2 from S\u2083; D1,D2 from S\u2084.\n  \u2022 First (bottom) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements M\u2081 on (A2,B1) and M\u2082 on (C2,D1).  \n      \u2022 Each Bell-measurement is realized by linear optics + two ancilla detectors; click patterns herald a successful swap.\n    \u2013 After M\u2081 one obtains a Bell pair between A1 and B2; after M\u2082 a Bell pair between C1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Second (top) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform a third Bell-measurement M\u2083 on the two middle modes B2 and C1 (again via ancilla detectors).  \n      \u2022 A successful click heralds a final Bell pair between A1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d:\n    \u2013 **Phase I** (shallow coarse-graining): post-select on M\u2081 & M\u2082 only.  The network coarsens from 4 pairs \u2192 two Bell pairs.\n    \u2013 **Phase II** (deep coarse-graining): post-select on all three M\u2081, M\u2082, M\u2083.  The network coarsens fully \u2192 one long-range Bell pair.\n  \u2022 Physics question:\n    \u2013 By comparing the output entanglement (Bell-violation or fidelity) between A1 and either B2/C1 (Phase I) vs A1\u2013D2 (Phase II), one directly observes a measurement-induced transformation of the tensor-network geometry (a minimal tree-tensor-network renormalization).  \n    \u2013 One can generalize to larger trees (more Bell pairs and more layers) to study measurement density vs entanglement length\u2014an optical analog of measurement-induced phase transitions in tensor-network models.\n  \u2022 Why Pytheus can design this:\n    \u2013 All operations are static linear-optical elements + probabilistic pair sources + photon-number-resolving detectors.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed.\n    \u2013 One simply encodes the 8 input modes, specifies 3 sets of ancilla detectors (for M\u2081,M\u2082,M\u2083), and enforces that no single source connects A2 to D1 etc. using removed_connections.\n    \u2013 The target is the network transformation (hierarchical entanglement swapping), not a specific many-photon state.\n\nThis \u201cTree-Tensor-Network RG Module\u201d is a new kind of quantum network experiment: it melds tensor-network renormalization ideas with measurement-induced network phases, and can be generalized to deeper trees or to probabilistic measurement patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is just the standard two\u2010hop entanglement swap (quantum repeater) in tree form, already well\u2010explored (see \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap\u201d from the ensemble).  You\u2019ll need to propose a truly new measurement primitive or nontrivial network phase transition\u2014such as superposed swap orders, many\u2010body joint measurements, or nonlinear renormalization effects\u2014to be considered novel.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to marry \u201ctensor-network state\u201d ideas and \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d phenomena in a purely static photonic network  \n  1) A two-layer tree-tensor-network realized by hierarchical entanglement swapping, where performing only the bottom-layer Bell measurements vs. both layers yields two distinct connectivity \u201cphases.\u201d  \n  2) A quantum-switch of swap-orders: take three Bell pairs in a row and a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon in a superposition of two paths, each path enacting a different order of two entanglement-swapping modules. Post-selecting on joint detections realizes a superposed network renormalization\u2014and by measuring only one branch vs. both branches you drive a \u201cphase change\u201d in which coarse-graining order you implement.  \n  3) A small 1D cluster-like MPS of Bell pairs where you randomly intersperse or omit Bell measurements along the chain; as you vary the density of measurements you cross a percolation-threshold for end-to-end entanglement (a photonic analogue of a measurement-induced phase transition in an MPS).  \nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check  \n  1) Two-layer TTN swapping is clean but arguably just a deeper repeater chain\u2014likely too close to previous cascaded\u2010swap examples.  \n  2) The quantum-switch of entanglement-swapping orders is new: no existing Pytheus experiment superposes two distinct tensor-network contraction orders via a single static circuit. It uses only linear-optics, probabilistic pair sources and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities.  \n  3) Measurement-density percolation on an MPS is conceptually nice but boils down to a longer chain of swaps; hard to realize a genuine \u201cphase\u201d in a 1D chain of only a few pairs.  \nStep 3: Pick idea (2) as most novel & Pytheus-compatible  \nStep 4: Novelty  \n  \u2022 First photonic demonstration of a quantum switch applied to entanglement-swapping\u2014i.e. a superposition of two tensor-network renormalization orders.  \n  \u2022 Unlike standard cascaded swapping, here the *order* of two BSMs is coherently controlled and becomes a resource.  \nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optical circuit with four pair sources (3 data pairs + 1 control qubit as a path-encoded photon)  \n  \u2022 Two Bell-measurement modules realized by beam-splitters, phase-shifters and ancillary detectors (heralded post-selection)  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward; no physical hyper-entanglement required  \n  \u2022 The \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d is seen by choosing to post-select on only one branch\u2019s success vs. both branches, or by reading out an interferometric phase on the control photon.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus:  \n\nTitle: \u201cQuantum-Switch of Entanglement-Swapping Orders: a Measurement-Induced Renormalization Phase in a Photonic Tensor Network\u201d  \n\nObjective:  \nImplement, in a single static linear-optical circuit, a **controlled superposition** of two entanglement-swapping protocols on three Bell-pairs. The *order* in which two Bell-measurements are performed becomes coherently controlled by a separate \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, yielding an entanglement-renormalization quantum switch. By post-selecting on different subsets of heralding detectors one observes two distinct connectivity \u201cphases\u201d: a shallow coarse-graining (one swap) vs. a deep coarse-graining (two swaps), and\u2014when measuring the control photon\u2014an interference signature of the superposed swap orders.  \n\nSchematic description:  \n- Sources:  \n  \u2022 S\u2081 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dA,B\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dB,C\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2083 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dC,D\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2080 prepares a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon in (|0>+|1>)/\u221a2 (path-encoded)  \n- Controlled routing:  \n  \u2022 If control=|0\u27e9, route modes (B,C) into Bell-module M\u2081 and then (A,B) into M\u2082.  \n  \u2022 If control=|1\u27e9, route (A,B) into M\u2081 and then (B,C) into M\u2082 (the \u201copposite\u201d swap order).  \n  \u2022 Each Bell-module is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, a phase-shifter, and two ancilla detectors whose click pattern heralds a successful swap.  \n- Post-selection and measurement phases:  \n  1) **Phase I (shallow)**: post-select **only** on the first module\u2019s clicks \u2192 yields two Bell pairs (one local pair + one intermediate pair).  \n  2) **Phase II (deep)**: post-select on **both** modules \u2192 yields a long-range Bell pair between A and D.  \n  3) **Interference signature**: finally, recombine the control paths on a beam splitter and look for fringes in its detector as a function of an internal phase shift\u2014this reveals the coherent superposition of the two swap orders.  \n\nWhy this is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n- **Static linear optics** + probabilistic photon-pair sources + number-resolving detectors only  \n- **No dynamic feedback**, no cavities or resonances  \n- Encodes a genuine **tensor-network renormalization** (two contraction orders on an MPS of length 4) and a **measurement-induced phase** (switching between shallow/deep coarse-graining and observing control-photon interference)  \n- Easily generalizable: add more layers (longer chains), more swap modules, or multi-arm switches to explore larger TTN structures and measurement-induced network phases.  \n\nI recommend feeding this description into Pytheus as a \u201ccontrolled-swap-order\u201d network target. It will search for the required beam-splitter/phase-shifter arrangement and detector assignments to realize this quantum-switch experiment."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static 4-Mode Super-Bell-State Analyzer with Single-Photon Ancilla\n\nAbstract: We present a purely network-primitive linear-optical scheme that employs a single ancillary photon and a static 4-mode interferometer\u2014decomposed into three optimized beam splitters\u2014to unambiguously identify all four Bell states (\u03a6\u207a, \u03a6\u207b, \u03a8\u207a, \u03a8\u207b) of two abstract dual-rail qubits with a post-selected success rate of 62.5% and perfect conditional fidelity. By directing the four outputs into number-resolving detectors and post-selecting on exactly one click, the target Bell projection is implemented without polarization encoding, feed-forward, or extra resources, enabling higher-rate entanglement swapping and repeater protocols.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n\u201cGHZ-Basis Teleportation of Two Qubits to Realize and Witness Discrete Wigner Negativity\u201d\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a linear-optical protocol that jointly teleports two input qubits via a four-photon GHZ projection\u2014mixing Alice\u2019s two data qubits and two ancilla photons in a four-mode network and heralding the two-qubit block onto Bob\u2019s output modes. Upon successful heralding, the shared Choistate across modes (0,1,2,3) becomes the unnormalized target \u03a8_GHZ=|0000\u27e9+|1111\u27e9, whose discrete Wigner function exhibits negativity and thereby certifies genuine GHZ-basis teleportation within the PyTheus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ancilla-Assisted Linear-Optical Two-Qutrit SWAP-Test for Symmetric vs. Antisymmetric Projections\n\nAbstract: We present a heralded linear-optical network that implements the two-qutrit SWAP-test (symmetric vs. antisymmetric projector) as a primitive for second R\u00e9nyi-entropy measurement on two collective-spin modes converted into photonic qutrits via spin\u2013orbit torque transduction. By employing three ancilla photons, static multiport interferometry, and number-resolving detection with \u201cSYM\u201d vs. \u201cANTI\u201d click\u2010pattern postselection, our scheme directly discriminates the symmetric and antisymmetric subspaces, enabling scalable entanglement verification and entropic benchmarking in quantum networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Programmable SWAP-Family Gate Array on the Pyth e us Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate a static, on-chip linear-optics network that realizes a heralded, programmable two-qubit controlled-unitary operation chosen from the SWAP family (I, SWAP, \u221aSWAP, i\u221aSWAP) on unknown dual-rail photonic data qubits by loading a four-dimensional program register and conditioning on ancilla photon detection patterns. Upon successful heralding, distant nodes A and D share a maximally entangled state in the Fourier basis whose correlations amplify unknown spatial-mode phase perturbations, realizing scalable high-sensitivity phase estimation without pure-state sources.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Passive Linear-Optical Universal 1\u21922 Qutrit Telecloner\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a passive, measurement-based linear-optical network that implements the universal 1\u21922 telecloning of an arbitrary single-qutrit state by interfering the unknown input with three d = 3 Bell-pair ancillas via two tritter multiports and post-selecting on a specific six-fold detector-click pattern. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a suggestion for an experiment that combines the ideas of a tensor-network renormalization (a small tree-tensor-network) with a measurement-induced reconfiguration (\u201cphase\u201d) of the entanglement network.  The goal is not to generate a particular exotic state, but to demonstrate a **hierarchical entanglement-swapping module** that implements a two-level renormalization of a chain of Bell pairs.  By post-selecting on different subsets of Bell measurements one realizes different \u201cphases\u201d of network connectivity.\n\nDescription of the target network:\n  \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 Four independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081,\u2026,S\u2084, each emitting one Bell pair (two modes).\n    \u2013 Label the eight output modes as A1,A2 from S\u2081; B1,B2 from S\u2082; C1,C2 from S\u2083; D1,D2 from S\u2084.\n  \u2022 First (bottom) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements M\u2081 on (A2,B1) and M\u2082 on (C2,D1).  \n      \u2022 Each Bell-measurement is realized by linear optics + two ancilla detectors; click patterns herald a successful swap.\n    \u2013 After M\u2081 one obtains a Bell pair between A1 and B2; after M\u2082 a Bell pair between C1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Second (top) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform a third Bell-measurement M\u2083 on the two middle modes B2 and C1 (again via ancilla detectors).  \n      \u2022 A successful click heralds a final Bell pair between A1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d:\n    \u2013 **Phase I** (shallow coarse-graining): post-select on M\u2081 & M\u2082 only.  The network coarsens from 4 pairs \u2192 two Bell pairs.\n    \u2013 **Phase II** (deep coarse-graining): post-select on all three M\u2081, M\u2082, M\u2083.  The network coarsens fully \u2192 one long-range Bell pair.\n  \u2022 Physics question:\n    \u2013 By comparing the output entanglement (Bell-violation or fidelity) between A1 and either B2/C1 (Phase I) vs A1\u2013D2 (Phase II), one directly observes a measurement-induced transformation of the tensor-network geometry (a minimal tree-tensor-network renormalization).  \n    \u2013 One can generalize to larger trees (more Bell pairs and more layers) to study measurement density vs entanglement length\u2014an optical analog of measurement-induced phase transitions in tensor-network models.\n  \u2022 Why Pytheus can design this:\n    \u2013 All operations are static linear-optical elements + probabilistic pair sources + photon-number-resolving detectors.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed.\n    \u2013 One simply encodes the 8 input modes, specifies 3 sets of ancilla detectors (for M\u2081,M\u2082,M\u2083), and enforces that no single source connects A2 to D1 etc. using removed_connections.\n    \u2013 The target is the network transformation (hierarchical entanglement swapping), not a specific many-photon state.\n\nThis \u201cTree-Tensor-Network RG Module\u201d is a new kind of quantum network experiment: it melds tensor-network renormalization ideas with measurement-induced network phases, and can be generalized to deeper trees or to probabilistic measurement patterns.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed \u201ctwo\u2010level\u201d hierarchical swap module is essentially just a standard two\u2010hop entanglement\u2010swapping repeater (first swap on A\u2013B and C\u2013D, then swap on B\u2013C) with trivial post\u2010selection on whether you include the top\u2010layer measurement or not.  That construction and the idea of coarse\u2010graining a Bell\u2010pair chain via successive swaps is already textbook and appears in both basic repeater proposals and in our ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network.\u201d  Simply toggling between bottom\u2010layer only or full two\u2010layer swapping phases does not introduce any genuinely new measurement primitive, state or network\u2010phase physics.  To be PRL\u2010worthy, one needs a nontrivial twist\u2014e.g. superposing measurement orders, joint multi\u2010photon projections, or a novel measurement\u2010induced phase transition beyond trivial coarse\u2010graining.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is just the standard two\u2010hop entanglement swap (quantum repeater) in tree form, already well\u2010explored (see \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap\u201d from the ensemble).  You\u2019ll need to propose a truly new measurement primitive or nontrivial network phase transition\u2014such as superposed swap orders, many\u2010body joint measurements, or nonlinear renormalization effects\u2014to be considered novel.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus:  \n\nTitle: \u201cQuantum-Switch of Entanglement-Swapping Orders: a Measurement-Induced Renormalization Phase in a Photonic Tensor Network\u201d  \n\nObjective:  \nImplement, in a single static linear-optical circuit, a **controlled superposition** of two entanglement-swapping protocols on three Bell-pairs. The *order* in which two Bell-measurements are performed becomes coherently controlled by a separate \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, yielding an entanglement-renormalization quantum switch. By post-selecting on different subsets of heralding detectors one observes two distinct connectivity \u201cphases\u201d: a shallow coarse-graining (one swap) vs. a deep coarse-graining (two swaps), and\u2014when measuring the control photon\u2014an interference signature of the superposed swap orders.  \n\nSchematic description:  \n- Sources:  \n  \u2022 S\u2081 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dA,B\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dB,C\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2083 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dC,D\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2080 prepares a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon in (|0>+|1>)/\u221a2 (path-encoded)  \n- Controlled routing:  \n  \u2022 If control=|0\u27e9, route modes (B,C) into Bell-module M\u2081 and then (A,B) into M\u2082.  \n  \u2022 If control=|1\u27e9, route (A,B) into M\u2081 and then (B,C) into M\u2082 (the \u201copposite\u201d swap order).  \n  \u2022 Each Bell-module is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, a phase-shifter, and two ancilla detectors whose click pattern heralds a successful swap.  \n- Post-selection and measurement phases:  \n  1) **Phase I (shallow)**: post-select **only** on the first module\u2019s clicks \u2192 yields two Bell pairs (one local pair + one intermediate pair).  \n  2) **Phase II (deep)**: post-select on **both** modules \u2192 yields a long-range Bell pair between A and D.  \n  3) **Interference signature**: finally, recombine the control paths on a beam splitter and look for fringes in its detector as a function of an internal phase shift\u2014this reveals the coherent superposition of the two swap orders.  \n\nWhy this is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n- **Static linear optics** + probabilistic photon-pair sources + number-resolving detectors only  \n- **No dynamic feedback**, no cavities or resonances  \n- Encodes a genuine **tensor-network renormalization** (two contraction orders on an MPS of length 4) and a **measurement-induced phase** (switching between shallow/deep coarse-graining and observing control-photon interference)  \n- Easily generalizable: add more layers (longer chains), more swap modules, or multi-arm switches to explore larger TTN structures and measurement-induced network phases.  \n\nI recommend feeding this description into Pytheus as a \u201ccontrolled-swap-order\u201d network target. It will search for the required beam-splitter/phase-shifter arrangement and detector assignments to realize this quantum-switch experiment.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This is essentially the same \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d already in our ensemble (the controlled superposition of two swap orders across A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D to yield indefinite causal order and network phases). [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"tensor network state\" and \"measurement induced phase\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. The goal is not to generate a particular exotic state, but to demonstrate a **hierarchical entanglement-swapping module** that implements a two-level renormalization of a chain of Bell pairs.  By post-selecting on different subsets of Bell measurements one realizes different \u201cphases\u201d of network connectivity.\n\nDescription of the target network:\n  \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 Four independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081,\u2026,S\u2084, each emitting one Bell pair (two modes).\n    \u2013 Label the eight output modes as A1,A2 from S\u2081; B1,B2 from S\u2082; C1,C2 from S\u2083; D1,D2 from S\u2084.\n  \u2022 First (bottom) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements M\u2081 on (A2,B1) and M\u2082 on (C2,D1).  \n      \u2022 Each Bell-measurement is realized by linear optics + two ancilla detectors; click patterns herald a successful swap.\n    \u2013 After M\u2081 one obtains a Bell pair between A1 and B2; after M\u2082 a Bell pair between C1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Second (top) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform a third Bell-measurement M\u2083 on the two middle modes B2 and C1 (again via ancilla detectors).  \n      \u2022 A successful click heralds a final Bell pair between A1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d:\n    \u2013 **Phase I** (shallow coarse-graining): post-select on M\u2081 & M\u2082 only.  The network coarsens from 4 pairs \u2192 two Bell pairs.\n    \u2013 **Phase II** (deep coarse-graining): post-select on all three M\u2081, M\u2082, M\u2083.  The network coarsens fully \u2192 one long-range Bell pair.\n  \u2022 Physics question:\n    \u2013 By comparing the output entanglement (Bell-violation or fidelity) between A1 and either B2/C1 (Phase I) vs A1\u2013D2 (Phase II), one directly observes a measurement-induced transformation of the tensor-network geometry (a minimal tree-tensor-network renormalization).  \n    \u2013 One can generalize to larger trees (more Bell pairs and more layers) to study measurement density vs entanglement length\u2014an optical analog of measurement-induced phase transitions in tensor-network models.\n  \u2022 Why Pytheus can design this:\n    \u2013 All operations are static linear-optical elements + probabilistic pair sources + photon-number-resolving detectors.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed.\n    \u2013 One simply encodes the 8 input modes, specifies 3 sets of ancilla detectors (for M\u2081,M\u2082,M\u2083), and enforces that no single source connects A2 to D1 etc. using removed_connections.\n    \u2013 The target is the network transformation (hierarchical entanglement swapping), not a specific many-photon state.\n\nThis \u201cTree-Tensor-Network RG Module\u201d is a new kind of quantum network experiment: it melds tensor-network renormalization ideas with measurement-induced network phases, and can be generalized to deeper trees or to probabilistic measurement patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is just the standard two\u2010hop entanglement swap (quantum repeater) in tree form, already well\u2010explored (see \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap\u201d from the ensemble). It uses only linear-optics, probabilistic pair sources and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities.  \n  3) Measurement-density percolation on an MPS is conceptually nice but boils down to a longer chain of swaps; hard to realize a genuine \u201cphase\u201d in a 1D chain of only a few pairs.  \nStep 3: Pick idea (2) as most novel & Pytheus-compatible  \nStep 4: Novelty  \n  \u2022 First photonic demonstration of a quantum switch applied to entanglement-swapping\u2014i.e. a superposition of two tensor-network renormalization orders.  \n  \u2022 Unlike standard cascaded swapping, here the *order* of two BSMs is coherently controlled and becomes a resource.  \nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optical circuit with four pair sources (3 data pairs + 1 control qubit as a path-encoded photon)  \n  \u2022 Two Bell-measurement modules realized by beam-splitters, phase-shifters and ancillary detectors (heralded post-selection)  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward; no physical hyper-entanglement required  \n  \u2022 The \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d is seen by choosing to post-select on only one branch\u2019s success vs. both branches, or by reading out an interferometric phase on the control photon.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus:  \n\nTitle: \u201cQuantum-Switch of Entanglement-Swapping Orders: a Measurement-Induced Renormalization Phase in a Photonic Tensor Network\u201d  \n\nObjective:  \nImplement, in a single static linear-optical circuit, a **controlled superposition** of two entanglement-swapping protocols on three Bell-pairs. The *order* in which two Bell-measurements are performed becomes coherently controlled by a separate \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, yielding an entanglement-renormalization quantum switch. By post-selecting on different subsets of heralding detectors one observes two distinct connectivity \u201cphases\u201d: a shallow coarse-graining (one swap) vs. a deep coarse-graining (two swaps), and\u2014when measuring the control photon\u2014an interference signature of the superposed swap orders.  \n\nSchematic description:  \n- Sources:  \n  \u2022 S\u2081 produces \u201ccontrol\u201d photon in (|0>+|1>)/\u221a2 (path-encoded)  \n- Controlled routing:  \n  \u2022 If control=|0\u27e9, route modes (B,C) into Bell-module M\u2081 and then (A,B) into M\u2082.  \n phase-shifter, and two ancilla detectors whose click pattern heralds a successful swap.  \n- Post-selection and measurement phases:  \n  1) **Phase I (shallow)**: post-select **only** on the first module\u2019s clicks \u2192 yields two Bell pairs (one local pair + one intermediate pair).  \n  2) **Phase II (deep)**: post-select on **both** modules \u2192 yields a long-range Bell pair between A and D.  \n  3) **Interference signature**: finally, recombine the control paths on a beam splitter and look for fringes in its detector as a function of an internal phase shift\u2014this reveals the coherent superposition of the two swap orders.  \n\nWhy this is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n- **Static linear optics** + probabilistic photon-pair sources + number-resolving detectors only  \n- **No dynamic feedback**, no cavities or resonances  \n- Encodes a genuine **tensor-network renormalization** (two contraction orders on an MPS of length 4) and a **measurement-induced phase** (switching between shallow/deep coarse-graining and observing control-photon interference)  \n- Easily generalizable: add more layers (longer chains), more swap modules, or multi-arm switches to explore larger TTN structures and measurement-induced network phases.  \n\nI recommend feeding this description into Pytheus as a \u201ccontrolled-swap-order\u201d network target.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to merge \u201ctensor-network state\u201d and \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d in a quantum network transformation\u2014not mere state generation:\n    1) **Hierarchical Renormalization Switch**: a control photon in superposition routes whether Bell-measurements (swaps) are performed in a 2-level tree, creating a superposition of network coarse-graining layers.\n    2) **Multi-Branch Switch of Swap Patterns**: two control qubits coherently choose among four distinct subsets of two Bell-swap modules in a 3-link chain, yielding a superposition of four tensor-network contraction graphs. Post-selection on different heralding sets produces distinct \u201cphases\u201d of connectivity.\n    3) **Teleportation with Measurement-Tuned Bond Dimension**: a 3-hop teleportation channel where each intermediate node can perform one of two different projective measurements (tunable by a static phase shifter), and by varying that phase one observes a sharp drop in end-to-end fidelity\u2014a photonic analogue of a measurement-induced phase transition in an MPS channel.\n  Step 2: Novelty/feasibility check:\n    1) Too close to the earlier 2-layer tree idea we already tried.\n    2) **Most novel:** no existing Pytheus example superposes multiple measurement patterns\u2014only swap-order or single-layer swaps. Four distinct patterns (none, swap\u2081, swap\u2082, both) in superposition is new.\n    3) Hard to phrase \u201csharp drop\u201d as a static target for Pytheus; plus it\u2019s essentially varying a phase parameter, not a genuinely new network transformation.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (2)\u2014the multi-branch quantum switch of swap patterns.\n  Step 4: Novelty\n    \u2022 First photonic demonstration of a **quantum superposition of multiple entanglement-swapping patterns** on a 3-link chain, i.e. a coherent superposition of four distinct tensor-network contraction graphs.  \n    \u2022 Yields a genuine **measurement-induced network phase**: post-selecting on different sets of heralding detectors realizes \u201cno swap,\u201d \u201cone swap at left,\u201d \u201cone swap at right,\u201d or \u201cboth swaps,\u201d with interference among these patterns when reading out control qubits.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus\n    \u2022 Static linear optics + 3 probabilistic Bell-pair sources (data) + 2 single-photon control sources.  \n    \u2022 Two BSM modules (linear optics + ancilla detectors), each placed in a Mach-Zehnder style interferometer whose insertion is controlled by the path state of a control photon.  \n    \u2022 No feed-forward, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement.  \n    \u2022 Simply encode 8 data modes and 2 control modes; specify 2 ancilla BSM blocks; use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d so that sources cannot directly connect across non-intended modes; and target the superposed network transformation (not a particular multi-photon state).  \n    \u2022 Easily generalizable: add more links and control qubits to explore richer tensor-network phases.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus\u2010ready proposal that fuses tensor-network ideas with measurement-induced phases by implementing a **multi-branch quantum switch of entanglement-swap patterns** on a three-link chain.  The target is **not** a fixed multi-photon state but a **coherent superposition of four different network connectivity graphs**, each heralded by distinct click patterns, and an interference readout on control qubits.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n   \u2022 Data Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083: produce |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F).  \n   \u2022 Control single-photon sources C\u2081,C\u2082: each creates a qubit in (path-0 + path-1)/\u221a2. Denote their paths as c\u2081\u2080/c\u2081\u2081 and c\u2082\u2080/c\u2082\u2081.  \n\n2) Two swap modules (BSM\u2081, BSM\u2082):  \n   \u2022 BSM\u2081 acts on modes (B,C) when inserted; BSM\u2082 on (D,E).  \n   \u2022 Each BSM is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter + phase shifter + two ancilla detectors whose joint clicks herald a successful Bell swap.\n\n3) Controlled insertion (static circuit):  \n   \u2022 Control qubit C\u2081 routes modes B\u2013C through BSM\u2081 if it occupies path c\u2081\u2080; bypasses if c\u2081\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Control qubit C\u2082 routes modes D\u2013E through BSM\u2082 if it occupies path c\u2082\u2080; bypasses if c\u2082\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Because C\u2081,C\u2082 are in superposition, the overall network is in a superposition of applying zero, one, or both swap modules.\n\n4) Post-selection and measurement-induced \u201cphases\u201d:  \n   \u2013 **Phase 0**: post-select on neither BSM click \u2192 final state = three disjoint Bell pairs  \n   \u2013 **Phase L**: post-select on BSM\u2081 only \u2192 one swap between A\u2013D + leftover pair E\u2013F  \n   \u2013 **Phase R**: post-select on BSM\u2082 only \u2192 one swap between C\u2013F + leftover pair A\u2013B  \n   \u2013 **Phase LR**: post-select on both BSM\u2081 & BSM\u2082 \u2192 one long-range Bell pair A\u2013F  \n   \u2022 Finally, recombine each control qubit on a beam splitter and measure in the X-basis. Interference fringes in control detectors confirm coherent superposition among the four patterns.\n\n5) Why Pytheus can design this  \n   \u2022 All operations are static linear optics, probabilistic pair/single-photon sources, and photon-number-resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 Use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to forbid unwanted direct sources (e.g. no S\u2081 \u2192 D, S\u2082 \u2192 A or S\u2083 \u2192 C/E except via intended paths).  \n   \u2022 Target is the **quantum supermap** that transforms inputs into heralded superpositions of network connectivity patterns, not a fixed high-dimensional state.  \n   \u2022 Generalizable to N-link chains with N control qubits, enabling exploration of multi-layer tensor-network renormalizations and measurement-induced percolation phases.\n\nFeed this specification into Pytheus. It will seek the static beam-splitter phases, interferometer routes, and detector assignments to realize the coherent multi-branch swap switch, opening a new avenue in measurement-driven quantum networks."
