phase-shifter, and two ancilla detectors whose click pattern heralds a successful swap.  \n- Post-selection and measurement phases:  \n  1) **Phase I (shallow)**: post-select **only** on the first module\u2019s clicks \u2192 yields two Bell pairs (one local pair + one intermediate pair).  \n  2) **Phase II (deep)**: post-select on **both** modules \u2192 yields a long-range Bell pair between A and D.  \n  3) **Interference signature**: finally, recombine the control paths on a beam splitter and look for fringes in its detector as a function of an internal phase shift\u2014this reveals the coherent superposition of the two swap orders.  \n\nWhy this is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n- **Static linear optics** + probabilistic photon-pair sources + number-resolving detectors only  \n- **No dynamic feedback**, no cavities or resonances  \n- Encodes a genuine **tensor-network renormalization** (two contraction orders on an MPS of length 4) and a **measurement-induced phase** (switching between shallow/deep coarse-graining and observing control-photon interference)  \n- Easily generalizable: add more layers (longer chains), more swap modules, or multi-arm switches to explore larger TTN structures and measurement-induced network phases.  \n\nI recommend feeding this description into Pytheus as a \u201ccontrolled-swap-order\u201d network target. The target is **not** a fixed multi-photon state but a **coherent superposition of four different network connectivity graphs**, each heralded by distinct click patterns, and an interference readout on control qubits.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n   \u2022 Data Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083: produce |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F).  \n   \u2022 Control single-photon sources C\u2081,C\u2082: each creates a qubit in (path-0 + path-1)/\u221a2. in a static LO network; risk Pytheus cannot solve loops/indefinite order.\n    3) Partial MERA toggling is interesting but again boils down to layered swaps on 4 modes, too close to the two-layer tree \u201cmeasurement-induced phase transition\u201d in a small tensor network.  \n    \u2022 By treating Bell-measurements along an MPS chain as probabilistic bonds, one realizes a clear percolation threshold in end-to-end entanglement.  \n    \u2022 Previous Pytheus work has done fixed entanglement-swapping chains but never studied threshold phenomena or connectivity percolation in an MPS.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus\n    \u2022 Only static linear optics, four or more probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a network of beam splitters/phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors for the four intermediate BSM modules and the two end analyzers.  \n    \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward, cavities, or exotic encodings.  \n    \u2022 Use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to forbid unwanted direct pair sources between non-neighboring modes.  \n    \u2022 The target is the mapping from patterns of clicked BSMs (k out of 4) to whether the end modes A and H become entangled (Bell-like correlations) or remain separable\u2014Pytheus can optimize the LO interferometer so that for each k\u22652 the end detectors correlate, and for k<2 they do not.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus\u2010ready target that combines a simple 1D tensor-network structure (an MPS of Bell pairs) with a genuine measurement-induced phase transition (percolation of entanglement connectivity):\n\n1) Network layout  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair sources S\u2081\u2026S\u2085 emit five independent qubit\u2013pairs onto modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F), (G,H), (I,J).  \n   \u2022 We label the five bonds between neighboring sites as bonds 1\u20134 connecting B\u2013C, D\u2013E, F\u2013G, H\u2013I.  \n\n2) Intermediate Bell-swap modules  \n   \u2022 On each bond \u2113=1\u20264 we place a static Bell-measurement module BSM_\u2113, realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, phase shifter, and two photon-number-resolving detectors whose coincidence heralds a successful swap on that bond.  \n   \u2022 There are therefore 8 ancilla detectors for the four BSMs.\n\n3) End analyzers  \n   \u2022 At modes A and J we place simple qubit analyzers (e.g. polarizing beam splitters + detectors) that record whether those two photons exit in the same logical state (0/0 or 1/1).\n\n4) Measurement\u2010induced percolation \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2022 Define k = the number of BSM modules (out of 4) that click.  \n   \u2022 **Phase I (no long-range entanglement):** for k < 2, the end detectors at A & J show no correlation beyond random.  \n   \u2022 **Phase II (percolated entanglement):** for k \u2265 2, the end detectors at A & J exhibit Bell-correlations (i.e. a heralded end-to-end entangled pair).  \n   \u2022 By post-selecting on runs with various k one observes a clear threshold (percolation) at k=2.\n\n5) Why this is novel and Pytheus\u2010compatible  \n   \u2022 Novel demonstration of a **measurement-induced phase transition** in a minimal photonic tensor network: you literally see entanglement \u201cpercolate\u201d only once enough intermediate measurements succeed.  \n   \u2022 Uses ONLY static linear optics + probabilistic pair sources + number-resolving detection\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hybrid encodings.  \n   \u2022 \u201cremoved_connections\u201d can forbid any source from linking non-neighboring modes, forcing the swaps to act only on intended bonds.  \n   \u2022 The target is a **network transformation**\u2014mapping subsets of BSM clicks (k) to end-mode correlations\u2014NOT raw state generation.  \n   \u2022 Easily generalizable to longer chains, 2D grids, or high-dimensional MPS/PEPS to explore richer measurement-induced critical phenomena.\n\nFeed this specification into Pytheus. It will search for the interferometric layout (beam-splitter angles, phase shifts, path connections) and detector assignments so that the end-to-end entanglement appears sharply when k\u22652, thereby creating the first small-scale photonic entanglement-percolation experiment in tensor-network language.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The threshold behavior here arises trivially from having two successful adjacent swaps in a repeater chain, not from any novel measurement-induced phase transition or new network connectivity supermap. Measuring that control in different bases then causes a discontinuous jump in end-to-end entanglement yield\u2014a genuine **measurement-induced phase transition** of network connectivity.  No dynamic feedback, no cavities\u2014just static beam splitters, phase shifters, ancilla detectors, and probabilistic sources. In each definite-order outcome, the probability p_def of heralding end-to-end entanglement between A and H is modest (swap success requires 3 cascaded Bell swaps).  \n   \u2013 Measure the control in the **Fourier basis** (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9+|2\u27e9)/\u221a3, (|0\u27e9+\u03c9|1\u27e9+\u03c9\u00b2|2\u27e9)/\u221a3, \u2026 .  Due to coherent interference among the three swap orders, the **heralding probability p_F** for A\u2013H entanglement exhibits a sharp enhancement p_F >> p_def.  \n   \u2013 This jump in entanglement yield as a function of the measurement basis is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** in the tensor-network connectivity of the 3-link chain.\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Implement This  \n   \u2022 **Static linear optics** only: beam splitters, phase shifters, interferometer loops, no feed-forward.  \n   \u2022 **Sources**: 4 probabilistic pair sources + 1 single-photon control emitter.  \n   \u2022 **Detectors**: 6 ancilla for the 3 BSMs + 2 for the control readout + 2 at A/H.  \n   \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid unwanted direct links (e.g. no S\u2081\u2192D or S\u2081\u2192F except via intended swap paths).  \n   \u2022 Target is the **network supermap**\u2014the mapping from input modes+control to heralded end-entanglement conditioned on control measurement\u2014not a fixed many-photon state.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-link chains and N-dim control qudits for N!-order superpositions.  \n  \u2013 Explore critical behavior of p_en(N,k-basis) as N and control basis vary\u2014a new class of measurement-induced tensor-network phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus. The simplest yet novel scheme is to place a single intermediate node B on a three-site line A\u2013B\u2013C sharing Bell pairs (A\u2013B and B\u2013C). Node B can either perform a Bell\u2013measurement (entanglement swap \u2192 A\u2013C entangled) or a computational-basis measurement (destroy both links \u2192 no entanglement). If that choice itself is put into superposition by a control photon, then measuring the control in different bases induces a sharp \u201cphase change\u201d between end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement vs. no entanglement. This transformation is a network metamorphosis\u2014an entanglement-swapping vs. entanglement-severing switch\u2014rather than state generation, and it can be implemented with static linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, one single-photon emitter, and number-resolving detectors. It naturally generalizes to longer chains or higher-dimensional tensor networks. \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n\n1) Data sources  \n   \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources S\u2081, S\u2082 creating |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B) and (C,D).  \n   \u2022 Node B holds modes B and C.  \n\n2) Control qubit  \n   \u2022 One single-photon emitter C\u2080 prepares a path-encoded qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 = (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 in two optical modes c\u2080 and c\u2081.\n\n3) Two measurement primitives at B  \n   \u2022 Bell-swap module M_swap: performs apost-selected Bell measurement on modes B,C (50/50 BS + phase shift + two ancilla detectors). A click heralds entanglement swapped to A\u2013D.  \n   \u2022 Severing module M_sever: measures B,C each in the computational basis (two PBS + detectors), destroying any entanglement.\n\n4) Controlled insertion (static routing)  \n   \u2022 Path c\u2080 routes B,C through M_swap.  \n   \u2022 Path c\u2081 routes B,C through M_sever.  \n   \u2022 Use static beam splitters and phase shifters to implement this \u201cquantum\u2010switch\u201d of measurement primitives.  \n\n5) Post-selection & measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2013 Measure the control photon in basis {|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}:  \n     \u2022 Outcome |0\u27e9 \u2192 network applied swap \u2192 A\u2013D entangled.  \n     \u2022 Outcome |1\u27e9 \u2192 sever \u2192 A\u2013D separable.  \n   \u2013 Measure the control in the Hadamard basis H{|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}:  \n     \u2022 Interference between swap/sever branches yields a jump in the A\u2013D correlation strength, a clear **measurement\u2010induced network phase transition** between entangled vs. separable regimes.  \n\n6) Why Pytheus can do it  \n   \u2022 All operations are static linear optics + 2 pair sources + 1 single emitter + number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n   \u2022 Enforce with `removed_connections` that no source directly connects A\u2194C or B\u2194D except via the intended modules.  \n   \u2022 The **target** is the mapping from control basis & herald clicks to end-mode entanglement vs. separability\u2014a network transformation, not state generation.  \n\nGeneralization  \n   \u2022 Extend to N-link MPS chains with an (N\u20131)-qubit control superposition choosing subsets of swap vs sever on each bond \u2192 explore rich measurement-induced percolation or critical phenomena in tensor networks.  \n\nFeed this description into Pytheus.     "output": "Here\u2019s a fully static, purely linear\u2010optical quantum\u2010network switch that (a) implements a new tensor\u2010network operation\u20143-party entanglement swapping via a GHZ\u2010basis measurement\u2014while (b) exhibiting a \u201cmeasurement-induced phase transition\u201d between pairwise and genuine tripartite entanglement on the same hardware.  Crucially, you do **not** ask Pytheus to *generate* any GHZ or Bell state; you give it sources and ask it to *route* and *measure* them in two different ways.\n\n1) Sources and modes  \n   \u2022 Three probabilistic Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083 emitting \u239c\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 on modes (A,a), (B,b), (C,c).  Parties A,B,C hold A,B,C; modes a,b,c meet at the central station.  \n   \u2022 One single-photon control emitter C\u2080 preparing (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 in two path modes p\u2080,p\u2081.\n\n2) Two measurement \u201cphases\u201d at the central station (all static)  \n   \u2013 **Bell-phase** (control in path p\u2080): implement three independent Bell-measurements on (a,b), (b,c), (c,a) via 50/50 beam splitters + phase shifters + ancilla detectors.  Heralds three EPR pairs among A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013A.  \n   \u2013 **GHZ-phase** (control in p\u2081): implement a *single* 3-photon GHZ-basis analyzer on (a,b,c)\u2014a joint measurement projecting onto one of the eight GHZ basis states\u2014using linear optics + ancilla photons + number-resolving detectors.  Heralds a *single* tripartite GHZ\u2010entangled state shared by A,B,C.\n\n3) Routing (static quantum\u2010switch)  \n   \u2022 Path p\u2080 of C\u2080 feeds the three Bell-modules; path p\u2081 feeds the GHZ-module.  p\u2080,p\u2081 recombined on a 50/50 beam splitter before detection so you can read out the control in either the Z\u2010basis (|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9) or the X\u2010basis (|\u00b1\u27e9).  \n   \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward\u2014everything is a fixed interferometer.\n\n4) Measurement-induced network \u201cphase transition\u201d  \n   a) If you measure the control in Z: you deterministically pick **either** the Bell-phase or the GHZ-phase and observe pairwise vs tripartite entanglement among A,B,C.  \n   b) If you measure the control in X (|\u00b1\u27e9 basis), the two modules *interfere* coherently.  The *heralding probabilities* and *type* of entanglement on A,B,C jump sharply when you rotate the control-phase\u2014this is a bona fide measurement-induced phase transition in the network\u2019s entanglement structure.\n\n5) Why Pytheus can build it  \n   \u2022 Only static linear optics, 3 probabilistic pair sources, 1 single-photon source, and number-resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid any source from sending two photons into the wrong module.  \n   \u2022 Ask Pytheus two sub-targets:  \n     (i) A 3-photon GHZ\u2010basis analyzer (target: the eight GHZ click patterns),  \n     (ii) Three independent Bell analyzers (target: the four Bell click patterns on each pair).  \n   \u2022 Then embed them in a static switch controlled by the control paths p\u2080,p\u2081.  The overall target is the *supermap* from {sources + control input} \u2192 {herald clicks + control outcome} \u2192 network entanglement phase (pairwise vs GHZ).\n\n6) Generalization  \n   \u2013 Go from three parties to N parties: toggle between N-fold Bell-pair webs vs N-party GHZ via an N-port GHZ analyzer.  \n   \u2013 Study critical behavior of heralding probability and entanglement type when reading out the control in different MUBs\u2014a family of measurement-induced tensor-network phase transitions.\n\nThis proposal neither *generates* a static GHZ/Bell state nor uses feedback or cavities.  It focuses on a new **network transformation**\u2014a 3-party entanglement\u2010swap vs entanglement\u2010sever switch\u2014whose **phase** (pairwise vs tripartite) is driven purely by the choice of measurement basis on one control photon.  Feed this specification into Pytheus.  It will output the beam-splitter angles, phase shifts, mode connections, and detector assignments needed to realize both the GHZ analyzer and the Bell-analyzer blocks, plus the static quantum-switch routing, thereby opening a new class of measurement-driven tensor-network experiments."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': Vary which measurements are performed to drive a \u201cphase transition\u201d in network connectivity.\n    2) MPS teleportation module: take an MPS of bond-dimension 2 across three sites, and teleport it end-to-end via sequential Bell measurements, showing how measurement order (which bonds you cut first) changes the fidelity of teleportation\u2014a \u201cmeasurement-induced network phase\u201d in teleportation performance.\n    3) Fusion-gate percolation: build a 1D cluster\u2010like graph state by probabilistic fusion gates (Type-II fusion) on Bell pairs. By choosing which fusion measurements succeed, one crosses a percolation threshold in connectivity\u2014a photonic measurement-induced phase transition in graph connectivity.  \n  Step 2: Quick novelty/obstacles check.\n    1) Tree RG swapping: novel because prior Pytheus examples only did linear/swapping in parallel or qutrits; no one has done a two-level tree. The goal is not to generate a particular exotic state, but to demonstrate a **hierarchical entanglement-swapping module** that implements a two-level renormalization of a chain of Bell pairs.  By post-selecting on different subsets of Bell measurements one realizes different \u201cphases\u201d of network connectivity.\n\nDescription of the target network:\n  \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 Four independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081,\u2026,S\u2084, each emitting one Bell pair (two modes).\n    \u2013 Label the eight output modes as A1,A2 from S\u2081; B1,B2 from S\u2082; C1,C2 from S\u2083; D1,D2 from S\u2084.\n  \u2022 First (bottom) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements M\u2081 on (A2,B1) and M\u2082 on (C2,D1).  \n      \u2022 Each Bell-measurement is realized by linear optics + two ancilla detectors; click patterns herald a successful swap.\n    \u2013 After M\u2081 one obtains a Bell pair between A1 and B2; after M\u2082 a Bell pair between C1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Second (top) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform a third Bell-measurement M\u2083 on the two middle modes B2 and C1 (again via ancilla detectors).  \n      \u2022 A successful click heralds a final Bell pair between A1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d:\n    \u2013 **Phase I** (shallow coarse-graining): post-select on M\u2081 & M\u2082 only.  The network coarsens from 4 pairs \u2192 two Bell pairs.\n    \u2013 **Phase II** (deep coarse-graining): post-select on all three M\u2081, M\u2082, M\u2083.  The network coarsens fully \u2192 one long-range Bell pair.\n  \u2022 Physics question:\n    \u2013 By comparing the output entanglement (Bell-violation or fidelity) between A1 and either B2/C1 (Phase I) vs A1\u2013D2 (Phase II), one directly observes a measurement-induced transformation of the tensor-network geometry (a minimal tree-tensor-network renormalization).  \n    \u2013 One can generalize to larger trees (more Bell pairs and more layers) to study measurement density vs entanglement length\u2014an optical analog of measurement-induced phase transitions in tensor-network models.\n  \u2022 Why Pytheus can design this:\n    \u2013 All operations are static linear-optical elements + probabilistic pair sources + photon-number-resolving detectors.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed.\n    \u2013 One simply encodes the 8 input modes, specifies 3 sets of ancilla detectors (for M\u2081,M\u2082,M\u2083), and enforces that no single source connects A2 to D1 etc. using removed_connections.\n    \u2013 The target is the network transformation (hierarchical entanglement swapping), not a specific many-photon state.\n\nThis \u201cTree-Tensor-Network RG Module\u201d is a new kind of quantum network experiment: it melds tensor-network renormalization ideas with measurement-induced network phases, and can be generalized to deeper trees or to probabilistic measurement patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is just the standard two\u2010hop entanglement swap (quantum repeater) in tree form, already well\u2010explored (see \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap\u201d from the ensemble). The *order* in which two Bell-measurements are performed becomes coherently controlled by a separate \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, yielding an entanglement-renormalization quantum switch. By post-selecting on different subsets of heralding detectors one observes two distinct connectivity \u201cphases\u201d: a shallow coarse-graining (one swap) vs. a deep coarse-graining (two swaps), and\u2014when measuring the control photon\u2014an interference signature of the superposed swap orders.  \n\nSchematic description:  \n- Sources:  \n  \u2022 S\u2081 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dA,B\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dB,C\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2083 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dC,D\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2080 prepares a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon in (|0>+|1>)/\u221a2 (path-encoded)  \n- Controlled routing:  \n  \u2022 If control=|0\u27e9, route modes (B,C) into Bell-module M\u2081 and then (A,B) into M\u2082.  \n  \u2022 If control=|1\u27e9, route (A,B) into M\u2081 and then (B,C) into M\u2082 (the \u201copposite\u201d swap order).  \n  \u2022 Each Bell-module is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, a phase-shifter, and two ancilla detectors whose click pattern heralds a successful swap.  \n- Post-selection and measurement phases:  \n  1) **Phase I (shallow)**: post-select **only** on the first module\u2019s clicks \u2192 yields two Bell pairs (one local pair + one intermediate pair).  \n  2) **Phase II (deep)**: post-select on **both** modules \u2192 yields a long-range Bell pair between A and D.  \n  3) **Interference signature**: finally, recombine the control paths on a beam splitter and look for fringes in its detector as a function of an internal phase shift\u2014this reveals the coherent superposition of the two swap orders.  \n\nWhy this is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n- **Static linear optics** + probabilistic photon-pair sources + number-resolving detectors only  \n- **No dynamic feedback**, no cavities or resonances  \n- Encodes a genuine **tensor-network renormalization** (two contraction orders on an MPS of length 4) and a **measurement-induced phase** (switching between shallow/deep coarse-graining and observing control-photon interference)  \n- Easily generalizable: add more layers (longer chains), more swap modules, or multi-arm switches to explore larger TTN structures and measurement-induced network phases.  \n\nI recommend feeding this description into Pytheus as a \u201ccontrolled-swap-order\u201d network target. It will search for the required beam-splitter/phase-shifter arrangement and detector assignments to realize this quantum-switch experiment.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The controlled superposition of two entanglement-swap sequences you describe duplicates the \u201cEntanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\u201d in our ensemble. Post-selection on different heralding sets produces distinct \u201cphases\u201d of connectivity.\n    3) **Teleportation with Measurement-Tuned Bond Dimension**: a 3-hop teleportation channel where each intermediate node can perform one of two different projective measurements (tunable by a static phase shifter), and by varying that phase one observes a sharp drop in end-to-end fidelity\u2014a photonic analogue of a measurement-induced phase transition in an MPS channel.\n  Step 2: Novelty/feasibility check:\n    1) Too close to the earlier 2-layer tree idea we already tried.\n    2) **Most novel:** no existing Pytheus example superposes multiple measurement patterns\u2014only swap-order or single-layer swaps. Four distinct patterns (none, swap\u2081, swap\u2082, both) in superposition is new.\n    3) Hard to phrase \u201csharp drop\u201d as a static target for Pytheus; plus it\u2019s essentially varying a phase parameter, not a genuinely new network transformation.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (2)\u2014the multi-branch quantum switch of swap patterns.\n  Step 4: Novelty\n    \u2022 First photonic demonstration of a **quantum superposition of multiple entanglement-swapping patterns** on a 3-link chain, i.e. a coherent superposition of four distinct tensor-network contraction graphs.  \n    \u2022 Yields a genuine **measurement-induced network phase**: post-selecting on different sets of heralding detectors realizes \u201cno swap,\u201d \u201cone swap at left,\u201d \u201cone swap at right,\u201d or \u201cboth swaps,\u201d with interference among these patterns when reading out control qubits.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus\n    \u2022 Static linear optics + 3 probabilistic Bell-pair sources (data) + 2 single-photon control sources.  \n    \u2022 Two BSM modules (linear optics + ancilla detectors), each placed in a Mach-Zehnder style interferometer whose insertion is controlled by the path state of a control photon.  \n    \u2022 No feed-forward, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement.  \n    \u2022 Simply encode 8 data modes and 2 control modes; specify 2 ancilla BSM blocks; use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d so that sources cannot directly connect across non-intended modes; and target the superposed network transformation (not a particular multi-photon state).  \n    \u2022 Easily generalizable: add more links and control qubits to explore richer tensor-network phases.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus\u2010ready proposal that fuses tensor-network ideas with measurement-induced phases by implementing a **multi-branch quantum switch of entanglement-swap patterns** on a three-link chain.  The target is **not** a fixed multi-photon state but a **coherent superposition of four different network connectivity graphs**, each heralded by distinct click patterns, and an interference readout on control qubits.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n   \u2022 Data Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083: produce |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F).  \n   \u2022 Control single-photon sources C\u2081,C\u2082: each creates a qubit in (path-0 + path-1)/\u221a2. Denote their paths as c\u2081\u2080/c\u2081\u2081 and c\u2082\u2080/c\u2082\u2081.  \n\n2) Two swap modules (BSM\u2081, BSM\u2082):  \n   \u2022 BSM\u2081 acts on modes (B,C) when inserted; BSM\u2082 on (D,E).  \n   \u2022 Each BSM is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter + phase shifter + two ancilla detectors whose joint clicks herald a successful Bell swap.\n\n3) Controlled insertion (static circuit):  \n   \u2022 Control qubit C\u2081 routes modes B\u2013C through BSM\u2081 if it occupies path c\u2081\u2080; bypasses if c\u2081\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Control qubit C\u2082 routes modes D\u2013E through BSM\u2082 if it occupies path c\u2082\u2080; bypasses if c\u2082\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Because C\u2081,C\u2082 are in superposition, the overall network is in a superposition of applying zero, one, or both swap modules.\n\n4) Post-selection and measurement-induced \u201cphases\u201d:  \n   \u2013 **Phase 0**: post-select on neither BSM click \u2192 final state = three disjoint Bell pairs  \n   \u2013 **Phase L**: post-select on BSM\u2081 only \u2192 one swap between A\u2013D + leftover pair E\u2013F  \n   \u2013 **Phase R**: post-select on BSM\u2082 only \u2192 one swap between C\u2013F + leftover pair A\u2013B  \n   \u2013 **Phase LR**: post-select on both BSM\u2081 & BSM\u2082 \u2192 one long-range Bell pair A\u2013F  \n   \u2022 Finally, recombine each control qubit on a beam splitter and measure in the X-basis. Interference fringes in control detectors confirm coherent superposition among the four patterns.\n\n5) Why Pytheus can design this  \n   \u2022 All operations are static linear optics, probabilistic pair/single-photon sources, and photon-number-resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 Use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to forbid unwanted direct sources (e.g. no S\u2081 \u2192 D, S\u2082 \u2192 A or S\u2083 \u2192 C/E except via intended paths).  \n   \u2022 Target is the **quantum supermap** that transforms inputs into heralded superpositions of network connectivity patterns, not a fixed high-dimensional state.  \n   \u2022 Generalizable to N-link chains with N control qubits, enabling exploration of multi-layer tensor-network renormalizations and measurement-induced percolation phases.\n\nFeed this specification into Pytheus. None of the existing Pytheus examples address percolation or threshold effects in entanglement connectivity.\n    2) Three-module indefinite switch is exotic but extremely challenging even to specify in a static LO network; risk Pytheus cannot solve loops/indefinite order.\n    3) Partial MERA toggling is interesting but again boils down to layered swaps on 4 modes, too close to the two-layer tree answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus\u2010ready target that combines a simple 1D tensor-network structure (an MPS of Bell pairs) with a genuine measurement-induced phase transition (percolation of entanglement connectivity):\n\n1) Network layout  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair sources S\u2081\u2026S\u2085 emit five independent qubit\u2013pairs onto modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F), (G,H), (I,J).  \n   \u2022 We label the five bonds between neighboring sites as bonds 1\u20134 connecting B\u2013C, D\u2013E, F\u2013G, H\u2013I.  \n\n2) Intermediate Bell-swap modules  \n   \u2022 On each bond \u2113=1\u20264 we place a static Bell-measurement module BSM_\u2113, realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, phase shifter, and two photon-number-resolving detectors whose coincidence heralds a successful swap on that bond.  \n   \u2022 There are therefore 8 ancilla detectors for the four BSMs.\n\n3) End analyzers  \n   \u2022 At modes A and J we place simple qubit analyzers (e.g. polarizing beam splitters + detectors) that record whether those two photons exit in the same logical state (0/0 or 1/1).\n\n4) Measurement\u2010induced percolation \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2022 Define k = the number of BSM modules (out of 4) that click.  \n   \u2022 **Phase I (no long-range entanglement):** for k < 2, the end detectors at A & J show no correlation beyond random.  \n   \u2022 **Phase II (percolated entanglement):** for k \u2265 2, the end detectors at A & J exhibit Bell-correlations (i.e. a heralded end-to-end entangled pair).  \n   \u2022 By post-selecting on runs with various k one observes a clear threshold (percolation) at k=2.\n\n5) Why this is novel and Pytheus\u2010compatible  \n   \u2022 Novel demonstration of a **measurement-induced phase transition** in a minimal photonic tensor network: you literally see entanglement \u201cpercolate\u201d only once enough intermediate measurements succeed.  \n   \u2022 Uses ONLY static linear optics + probabilistic pair sources + number-resolving detection\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hybrid encodings.  \n   \u2022 \u201cremoved_connections\u201d can forbid any source from linking non-neighboring modes, forcing the swaps to act only on intended bonds.  \n   \u2022 The target is a **network transformation**\u2014mapping subsets of BSM clicks (k) to end-mode correlations\u2014NOT raw state generation.  \n   \u2022 Easily generalizable to longer chains, 2D grids, or high-dimensional MPS/PEPS to explore richer measurement-induced critical phenomena.\n\nFeed this specification into Pytheus. It will search for the interferometric layout (beam-splitter angles, phase shifts, path connections) and detector assignments so that the end-to-end entanglement appears sharply when k\u22652, thereby creating the first small-scale photonic entanglement-percolation experiment in tensor-network language.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The threshold behavior here arises trivially from having two successful adjacent swaps in a repeater chain, not from any novel measurement-induced phase transition or new network connectivity supermap. The idea is to take entanglement swapping and elevate it to an **indefinite causal order** of three swaps\u2014a photonic **3-switch**\u2014so that the *order* in which the swaps are applied is coherently superposed by a control qudit.  Measuring that control in different bases then causes a discontinuous jump in end-to-end entanglement yield\u2014a genuine **measurement-induced phase transition** of network connectivity.  No dynamic feedback, no cavities\u2014just static beam splitters, phase shifters, ancilla detectors, and probabilistic sources.  This has never been done in Pytheus.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus-compatible proposal that fuses tensor-network renormalization with an indefinite-order quantum switch to create a **measurement-induced network phase transition**:\n\n1) Data and Control Sources  \n   \u2022 Four Bell-pair sources S\u2081\u2026S\u2084 producing |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F), (G,H).  \n   \u2022 One single-photon control source C preparing a path-encoded qutrit in state (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9+|2\u27e9)/\u221a3.\n\n2) Swap Modules (BSM\u2081, BSM\u2082, BSM\u2083)  \n   \u2022 BSM\u2081 acts on modes (B,C), BSM\u2082 on (D,E), BSM\u2083 on (F,G).  \n   \u2022 Each BSM is a 50/50 beam splitter + static phase shift + two ancilla detectors; a particular click pattern heralds a successful Bell swap.\n\n3) Controlled Indefinite Order  \n   \u2022 Control path |0\u27e9 routes the data photon sequentially through BSM\u2081\u2192BSM\u2082\u2192BSM\u2083.  \n   \u2022 Path |1\u27e9 routes through BSM\u2082\u2192BSM\u2083\u2192BSM\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Path |2\u27e9 routes through BSM\u2083\u2192BSM\u2081\u2192BSM\u2082.  \n   \u2022 All paths recombine at the end on a 3-port interferometer whose beam-splitter angles and phases are to be optimized.\n\n4) Measurement-Induced \u201cPhase\u201d  \n   \u2013 Measure the control qutrit in the **computational basis** { |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 }.  In each definite-order outcome, the probability p_def of heralding end-to-end entanglement between A and H is modest (swap success requires 3 cascaded Bell swaps).  \n   \u2013 Measure the control in the **Fourier basis** (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9+|2\u27e9)/\u221a3, (|0\u27e9+\u03c9|1\u27e9+\u03c9\u00b2|2\u27e9)/\u221a3, \u2026 .  Due to coherent interference among the three swap orders, the **heralding probability p_F** for A\u2013H entanglement exhibits a sharp enhancement p_F >> p_def.  \n   \u2013 This jump in entanglement yield as a function of the measurement basis is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** in the tensor-network connectivity of the 3-link chain.\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Implement This  \n   \u2022 **Static linear optics** only: beam splitters, phase shifters, interferometer loops, no feed-forward.  \n   \u2022 **Sources**: 4 probabilistic pair sources + 1 single-photon control emitter.  \n   \u2022 **Detectors**: 6 ancilla for the 3 BSMs + 2 for the control readout + 2 at A/H.  \n   \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid unwanted direct links (e.g. no S\u2081\u2192D or S\u2081\u2192F except via intended swap paths).  \n   \u2022 Target is the **network supermap**\u2014the mapping from input modes+control to heralded end-entanglement conditioned on control measurement\u2014not a fixed many-photon state.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-link chains and N-dim control qudits for N!-order superpositions.  \n  \u2013 Explore critical behavior of p_en(N,k-basis) as N and control basis vary\u2014a new class of measurement-induced tensor-network phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \nI have considered multiple ways to interweave tensor-network ideas with a genuine measurement-induced phase in a static photonic network. The simplest yet novel scheme is to place a single intermediate node B on a three-site line A\u2013B\u2013C sharing Bell pairs (A\u2013B and B\u2013C). Node B can either perform a Bell\u2013measurement (entanglement swap \u2192 A\u2013C entangled) or a computational-basis measurement (destroy both links \u2192 no entanglement). If that choice itself is put into superposition by a control photon, then measuring the control in different bases induces a sharp \u201cphase change\u201d between end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement vs. no entanglement. This transformation is a network metamorphosis\u2014an entanglement-swapping vs. entanglement-severing switch\u2014rather than state generation, and it can be implemented with static linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, one single-photon emitter, and number-resolving detectors. It naturally generalizes to longer chains or higher-dimensional tensor networks. \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n\n1) Data sources  \n   \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources S\u2081, S\u2082 creating |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B) and (C,D).  \n   \u2022 Node B holds modes B and C.  \n\n2) Control qubit  \n   \u2022 One single-photon emitter C\u2080 prepares a path-encoded qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 = (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 in two optical modes c\u2080 and c\u2081.\n\n3) Two measurement primitives at B  \n   \u2022 Bell-swap module M_swap: performs apost-selected Bell measurement on modes B,C (50/50 BS + phase shift + two ancilla detectors). A click heralds entanglement swapped to A\u2013D.  \n   \u2022 Severing module M_sever: measures B,C each in the computational basis (two PBS + detectors), destroying any entanglement.\n\n4) Controlled insertion (static routing)  \n   \u2022 Path c\u2080 routes B,C through M_swap.  \n   \u2022 Path c\u2081 routes B,C through M_sever.  \n   \u2022 Use static beam splitters and phase shifters to implement this \u201cquantum\u2010switch\u201d of measurement primitives.  \n\n5) Post-selection & measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2013 Measure the control photon in basis {|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}:  \n     \u2022 Outcome |0\u27e9 \u2192 network applied swap \u2192 A\u2013D entangled.  \n     \u2022 Outcome |1\u27e9 \u2192 sever \u2192 A\u2013D separable.  \n   \u2013 Measure the control in the Hadamard basis H{|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}:  \n     \u2022 Interference between swap/sever branches yields a jump in the A\u2013D correlation strength, a clear **measurement\u2010induced network phase transition** between entangled vs. separable regimes.  \n\n6) Why Pytheus can do it  \n   \u2022 All operations are static linear optics + 2 pair sources + 1 single emitter + number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n   \u2022 Enforce with `removed_connections` that no source directly connects A\u2194C or B\u2194D except via the intended modules.  \n   \u2022 The **target** is the mapping from control basis & herald clicks to end-mode entanglement vs. separability\u2014a network transformation, not state generation.  \n\nGeneralization  \n   \u2022 Extend to N-link MPS chains with an (N\u20131)-qubit control superposition choosing subsets of swap vs sever on each bond \u2192 explore rich measurement-induced percolation or critical phenomena in tensor networks.  \n\nFeed this description into Pytheus. It will optimize the beam\u2010splitter angles, phase settings, and detector assignments to realize this **quantum switch of measurement primitives**, demonstrating the first photonic measurement-induced phase transition in a tensor-network entanglement network.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This construction is a straightforward swap\u2010vs\u2010sever quantum switch, closely mirroring previous \u201csuperposition of network primitives\u201d experiments. To be novel at the PRL level, you need a genuinely new measurement primitive or a nontrivial many\u2010body renormalization/critical effect that cannot be reduced to a two\u2010branch quantum switch.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\nWe need a genuinely new multi-party measurement primitive\u2014a photonic network transformation rather than fixed state generation\u2014that exhibits a sharp, tunable \u201cphase transition\u201d in how entanglement is routed among nodes.  Pytheus can handle static linear optics, probabilistic Bell-pair sources, single-photon emitters, and number-resolving detectors, but cannot do feedback or cavities.  A three-port entanglement router (a joint 3-photon interferometric measurement) meets these requirements, creating a measurement-induced switch in network topology.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus-ready proposal:  \n\nTitle: \u201cMeasurement-Induced Entanglement Routing in a Three-Port Photonic Network\u201d\n\nObjective:\nImplement a **static** linear-optical circuit that takes three Bell pairs and\u2014via a single joint three-photon measurement\u2014heralds entanglement between **any two** of the three \u201cend\u201d modes.  By tuning a single internal phase, the network exhibits a **sharp routing transition**: the preferred entangled link jumps abruptly from one pair of output nodes to another as the phase crosses a critical value.  This is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** of network connectivity.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n  \u2022 Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083 each probabilistically emit one pair in |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 onto modes (A\u2081,B\u2081), (A\u2082,B\u2082), (A\u2083,B\u2083).  \n  \u2022 Modes A\u2081,A\u2082,A\u2083 are the \u201cend\u201d nodes to be entangled; modes B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083 go into the router.\n\n2) Three-Port Router (Multiport Interferometer + Detectors)  \n  \u2022 A static 3\u00d73 multiport unitary U(\u03c6) acts on B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083.  U is built from beam splitters and phase shifters, with one tunable internal phase \u03c6.  \n  \u2022 At U\u2019s outputs we place three photon-number-resolving detectors D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083.  Exactly one click (one photon) among them heralds success.\n\n3) Heralding Rule (Entanglement Routing)  \n  \u2022 If D\u2081 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2082 & A\u2083 become projected into a Bell state.  \n  \u2022 If D\u2082 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2081 & A\u2083 become entangled.  \n  \u2022 If D\u2083 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2081 & A\u2082 become entangled.  \n  \u2022 No other detectors click (post-select on exactly one click).\n\n4) Measurement-Induced Routing Phase Transition  \n  \u2022 Define p_i(\u03c6) = probability that D_i clicks and heralds that routing.  \n  \u2022 As \u03c6 is varied from 0 to 2\u03c0, one finds **sharp crossover points** \u03c6_c where the dominant p_i(\u03c6) jumps from i to j.  \n  \u2022 At \u03c6_c the network topology effectively \u201cswitches phase\u201d\u2014which two end nodes share entanglement changes abruptly\u2014mirroring a percolation or network phase transition induced purely by the measurement basis (\u03c6).\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Design This  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optics only: beam splitters, phase shifters including one tunable \u03c6, and a 3\u00d73 interferometer.  \n  \u2022 Sources: 3 probabilistic Bell-pair emitters.  \n  \u2022 Detectors: 3 router detectors + 4 end analyzers (to verify Bell correlations on the heralded pair).  \n  \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid any direct source\u2192end link other than the intended B\u2081\u2192U, etc.  \n  \u2022 **Target** is the network supermap: for each \u03c6, the mapping from detected outcomes {D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083} to a Bell correlation between the correct pair of A-modes\u2014**no fixed multi-photon state**.\n\nGeneralizations:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-port routers on N Bell pairs: study measurement-induced critical phenomena in larger tensor-networks.  \n  \u2013 Use single-photon control qudits to coherently superpose two different router unitaries, creating indefinite-order routing phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus.  It will optimize the internal beam-splitter reflectivities and phase settings so that exactly one click at D_i \u2192 maximal Bell fidelity between the corresponding A-nodes, and so that p_i(\u03c6) exhibits the desired sharp transitions in routing probability. This is the first minimal photonic demonstration of a **measurement-induced entanglement-routing phase transition** in a tensor-network setting."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static 4-Mode Super-Bell-State Analyzer with Single-Photon Ancilla\n\nAbstract: We present a purely network-primitive linear-optical scheme that employs a single ancillary photon and a static 4-mode interferometer\u2014decomposed into three optimized beam splitters\u2014to unambiguously identify all four Bell states (\u03a6\u207a, \u03a6\u207b, \u03a8\u207a, \u03a8\u207b) of two abstract dual-rail qubits with a post-selected success rate of 62.5% and perfect conditional fidelity. By directing the four outputs into number-resolving detectors and post-selecting on exactly one click, the target Bell projection is implemented without polarization encoding, feed-forward, or extra resources, enabling higher-rate entanglement swapping and repeater protocols.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n\u201cGHZ-Basis Teleportation of Two Qubits to Realize and Witness Discrete Wigner Negativity\u201d\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a linear-optical protocol that jointly teleports two input qubits via a four-photon GHZ projection\u2014mixing Alice\u2019s two data qubits and two ancilla photons in a four-mode network and heralding the two-qubit block onto Bob\u2019s output modes. Upon successful heralding, the shared Choistate across modes (0,1,2,3) becomes the unnormalized target \u03a8_GHZ=|0000\u27e9+|1111\u27e9, whose discrete Wigner function exhibits negativity and thereby certifies genuine GHZ-basis teleportation within the PyTheus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By employing three ancilla photons, static multiport interferometry, and number-resolving detection with \u201cSYM\u201d vs. \u201cANTI\u201d click\u2010pattern postselection, our scheme directly discriminates the symmetric and antisymmetric subspaces, enabling scalable entanglement verification and entropic benchmarking in quantum networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. Only the joint triple-coincidence detection at the network\u2019s three output modes reveals the global third-order phase e^{i(\u03c6A+\u03c6B+\u03c6C)}, while any single- or two-loop marginal yields no measurable phase, thereby realizing the targeted higher-order (Massey) topological invariant.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Remote CNOT via Gate Teleportation with Maximized Entangling Power\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target \u201cheralded remote CNOT via gate teleportation with maximal entangling power,\u201d realizing a genuine nonlocal two-qubit CNOT purely by linear optics, SPDC Bell pairs, single-photon emitters, and post-selection on trivial Pauli corrections. The goal is not to generate a particular exotic state, but to demonstrate a **hierarchical entanglement-swapping module** that implements a two-level renormalization of a chain of Bell pairs.  By post-selecting on different subsets of Bell measurements one realizes different \u201cphases\u201d of network connectivity.\n\nDescription of the target network:\n  \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 Four independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081,\u2026,S\u2084, each emitting one Bell pair (two modes).\n    \u2013 Label the eight output modes as A1,A2 from S\u2081; B1,B2 from S\u2082; C1,C2 from S\u2083; D1,D2 from S\u2084.\n  \u2022 First (bottom) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements M\u2081 on (A2,B1) and M\u2082 on (C2,D1).  \n      \u2022 Each Bell-measurement is realized by linear optics + two ancilla detectors; click patterns herald a successful swap.\n    \u2013 After M\u2081 one obtains a Bell pair between A1 and B2; after M\u2082 a Bell pair between C1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Second (top) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform a third Bell-measurement M\u2083 on the two middle modes B2 and C1 (again via ancilla detectors).  \n      \u2022 A successful click heralds a final Bell pair between A1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d:\n    \u2013 **Phase I** (shallow coarse-graining): post-select on M\u2081 & M\u2082 only.  The network coarsens from 4 pairs \u2192 two Bell pairs.\n    \u2013 **Phase II** (deep coarse-graining): post-select on all three M\u2081, M\u2082, M\u2083.  The network coarsens fully \u2192 one long-range Bell pair.\n  \u2022 Physics question:\n    \u2013 By comparing the output entanglement (Bell-violation or fidelity) between A1 and either B2/C1 (Phase I) vs A1\u2013D2 (Phase II), one directly observes a measurement-induced transformation of the tensor-network geometry (a minimal tree-tensor-network renormalization).  \n    \u2013 One can generalize to larger trees (more Bell pairs and more layers) to study measurement density vs entanglement length\u2014an optical analog of measurement-induced phase transitions in tensor-network models.\n  \u2022 Why Pytheus can design this:\n    \u2013 All operations are static linear-optical elements + probabilistic pair sources + photon-number-resolving detectors.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed.\n    \u2013 One simply encodes the 8 input modes, specifies 3 sets of ancilla detectors (for M\u2081,M\u2082,M\u2083), and enforces that no single source connects A2 to D1 etc. using removed_connections.\n    \u2013 The target is the network transformation (hierarchical entanglement swapping), not a specific many-photon state.\n\nThis \u201cTree-Tensor-Network RG Module\u201d is a new kind of quantum network experiment: it melds tensor-network renormalization ideas with measurement-induced network phases, and can be generalized to deeper trees or to probabilistic measurement patterns.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed \u201ctwo\u2010level\u201d hierarchical swap module is essentially just a standard two\u2010hop entanglement\u2010swapping repeater (first swap on A\u2013B and C\u2013D, then swap on B\u2013C) with trivial post\u2010selection on whether you include the top\u2010layer measurement or not.  That construction and the idea of coarse\u2010graining a Bell\u2010pair chain via successive swaps is already textbook and appears in both basic repeater proposals and in our ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network.\u201d  Simply toggling between bottom\u2010layer only or full two\u2010layer swapping phases does not introduce any genuinely new measurement primitive, state or network\u2010phase physics. The *order* in which two Bell-measurements are performed becomes coherently controlled by a separate \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, yielding an entanglement-renormalization quantum switch. By post-selecting on different subsets of heralding detectors one observes two distinct connectivity \u201cphases\u201d: a shallow coarse-graining (one swap) vs. a deep coarse-graining (two swaps), and\u2014when measuring the control photon\u2014an interference signature of the superposed swap orders.  \n\nSchematic description:  \n- Sources:  \n  \u2022 S\u2081 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dA,B\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dB,C\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2083 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dC,D\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2080 prepares a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon in (|0>+|1>)/\u221a2 (path-encoded)  \n- Controlled routing:  \n  \u2022 If control=|0\u27e9, route modes (B,C) into Bell-module M\u2081 and then (A,B) into M\u2082.  \n  \u2022 If control=|1\u27e9, route (A,B) into M\u2081 and then (B,C) into M\u2082 (the \u201copposite\u201d swap order).  \n  \u2022 Each Bell-module is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, a phase-shifter, and two ancilla detectors whose click pattern heralds a successful swap.  \n- Post-selection and measurement phases:  \n  1) **Phase I (shallow)**: post-select **only** on the first module\u2019s clicks \u2192 yields two Bell pairs (one local pair + one intermediate pair).  \n  2) **Phase II (deep)**: post-select on **both** modules \u2192 yields a long-range Bell pair between A and D.  \n  3) **Interference signature**: finally, recombine the control paths on a beam splitter and look for fringes in its detector as a function of an internal phase shift\u2014this reveals the coherent superposition of the two swap orders.  \n\nWhy this is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n- **Static linear optics** + probabilistic photon-pair sources + number-resolving detectors only  \n- **No dynamic feedback**, no cavities or resonances  \n- Encodes a genuine **tensor-network renormalization** (two contraction orders on an MPS of length 4) and a **measurement-induced phase** (switching between shallow/deep coarse-graining and observing control-photon interference)  \n- Easily generalizable: add more layers (longer chains), more swap modules, or multi-arm switches to explore larger TTN structures and measurement-induced network phases.  \n\nI recommend feeding this description into Pytheus as a \u201ccontrolled-swap-order\u201d network target. It will search for the required beam-splitter/phase-shifter arrangement and detector assignments to realize this quantum-switch experiment.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This is essentially the same \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d already in our ensemble (the controlled superposition of two swap orders across A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D to yield indefinite causal order and network phases). The target is **not** a fixed multi-photon state but a **coherent superposition of four different network connectivity graphs**, each heralded by distinct click patterns, and an interference readout on control qubits.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n   \u2022 Data Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083: produce |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F).  \n   \u2022 Control single-photon sources C\u2081,C\u2082: each creates a qubit in (path-0 + path-1)/\u221a2. Denote their paths as c\u2081\u2080/c\u2081\u2081 and c\u2082\u2080/c\u2082\u2081.  \n\n2) Two swap modules (BSM\u2081, BSM\u2082):  \n   \u2022 BSM\u2081 acts on modes (B,C) when inserted; BSM\u2082 on (D,E).  \n   \u2022 Each BSM is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter + phase shifter + two ancilla detectors whose joint clicks herald a successful Bell swap.\n\n3) Controlled insertion (static circuit):  \n   \u2022 Control qubit C\u2081 routes modes B\u2013C through BSM\u2081 if it occupies path c\u2081\u2080; bypasses if c\u2081\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Control qubit C\u2082 routes modes D\u2013E through BSM\u2082 if it occupies path c\u2082\u2080; bypasses if c\u2082\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Because C\u2081,C\u2082 are in superposition, the overall network is in a superposition of applying zero, one, or both swap modules.\n\n4) Post-selection and measurement-induced \u201cphases\u201d:  \n   \u2013 **Phase 0**: post-select on neither BSM click \u2192 final state = three disjoint Bell pairs  \n   \u2013 **Phase L**: post-select on BSM\u2081 only \u2192 one swap between A\u2013D + leftover pair E\u2013F  \n   \u2013 **Phase R**: post-select on BSM\u2082 only \u2192 one swap between C\u2013F + leftover pair A\u2013B  \n   \u2013 **Phase LR**: post-select on both BSM\u2081 & BSM\u2082 \u2192 one long-range Bell pair A\u2013F  \n   \u2022 Finally, recombine each control qubit on a beam splitter and measure in the X-basis. Interference fringes in control detectors confirm coherent superposition among the four patterns.\n\n5) Why Pytheus can design this  \n   \u2022 All operations are static linear optics, probabilistic pair/single-photon sources, and photon-number-resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 Use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to forbid unwanted direct sources (e.g. no S\u2081 \u2192 D, S\u2082 \u2192 A or S\u2083 \u2192 C/E except via intended paths).  \n   \u2022 Target is the **quantum supermap** that transforms inputs into heralded superpositions of network connectivity patterns, not a fixed high-dimensional state.  \n   \u2022 Generalizable to N-link chains with N control qubits, enabling exploration of multi-layer tensor-network renormalizations and measurement-induced percolation phases.\n\nFeed this specification into Pytheus. a Pytheus\u2010ready target that combines a simple 1D tensor-network structure (an MPS of Bell pairs) with a genuine measurement-induced phase transition (percolation of entanglement connectivity):\n\n1) Network layout  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair sources S\u2081\u2026S\u2085 emit five independent qubit\u2013pairs onto modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F), (G,H), (I,J).  \n   \u2022 We label the record whether those two photons exit in the same logical state (0/0 or 1/1).\n\n4) Measurement\u2010induced percolation \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2022 Define k = the number of BSM modules (out of 4) that click.  \n   \u2022 **Phase I (no long-range entanglement):** for k < 2, the end detectors at A & J show no correlation beyond random.  \n   \u2022 **Phase II (percolated entanglement):** for k \u2265 2, the end detectors at A & J exhibit Bell-correlations (i.e. a heralded end-to-end entangled pair).  \n   \u2022 By post-selecting on runs with various k one observes a clear threshold (percolation) at k=2.\n\n5) Why this is novel and Pytheus\u2010compatible  \n   \u2022 Novel demonstration of a **measurement-induced phase transition** in a minimal photonic tensor network: you literally see entanglement \u201cpercolate\u201d only once enough intermediate measurements succeed.  \n   \u2022 Uses ONLY static linear optics + probabilistic pair sources + number-resolving detection\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hybrid encodings.  \n   \u2022 \u201cremoved_connections\u201d can forbid any source from linking non-neighboring modes, forcing the swaps to act only on intended bonds.  \n   \u2022 The target is a **network transformation**\u2014mapping subsets of BSM clicks (k) to end-mode correlations\u2014NOT raw state generation.  \n   \u2022 Easily generalizable to longer chains, 2D grids, or high-dimensional MPS/PEPS to explore richer measurement-induced critical phenomena.\n\nFeed this specification into Pytheus. In each definite-order outcome, the probability p_def of heralding end-to-end entanglement between A and H is modest (swap success requires 3 cascaded Bell swaps).  \n   \u2013 Measure the control in the **Fourier basis** (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9+|2\u27e9)/\u221a3, (|0\u27e9+\u03c9|1\u27e9+\u03c9\u00b2|2\u27e9)/\u221a3, \u2026 .  Due to coherent interference among the three swap orders, the **heralding probability p_F** for A\u2013H entanglement exhibits a sharp enhancement p_F >> p_def.  \n   \u2013 This jump in entanglement yield as a function of the measurement basis is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** in the tensor-network connectivity of the 3-link chain.\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Implement This  \n   \u2022 **Static linear optics** only: beam splitters, phase shifters, interferometer loops, no feed-forward.  \n   \u2022 **Sources**: 4 probabilistic pair sources + 1 single-photon control emitter.  \n   \u2022 **Detectors**: 6 ancilla for the 3 BSMs + 2 for the control readout + 2 at A/H.  \n   \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid unwanted direct links (e.g. no S\u2081\u2192D or S\u2081\u2192F except via intended swap paths).  \n   \u2022 Target is the **network supermap**\u2014the mapping from input modes+control to heralded end-entanglement conditioned on control measurement\u2014not a fixed many-photon state.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-link chains and N-dim control qudits for N!-order superpositions.  \n  \u2013 Explore critical behavior of p_en(N,k-basis) as N and control basis vary\u2014a new class of measurement-induced tensor-network phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus. Similar superpositions of swap patterns already appear in our ensemble (\u201cEntanglement-Switch Quantum Switch\u2026\u201d and \u201cSuperposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps\u2026\u201d). This remains too incremental for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach PRL novelty you must propose a genuinely new measurement primitive or tensor-network effect\u2014e.g. irreversible multi-copy joint projections, non-commuting measurement sequences beyond simple swap orders, or a nontrivial network critical point that cannot be reduced to interference of independent Bell swaps.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n\n1) Data sources  \n   \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources S\u2081, S\u2082 creating |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B) and (C,D).  \n   \u2022 Node B holds modes B and C.  \n\n2) Control qubit  \n   \u2022 One single-photon emitter C\u2080 prepares a path-encoded qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 = (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 in two optical modes c\u2080 and c\u2081.\n\n3) Two measurement primitives at B  \n   \u2022 Bell-swap module M_swap: performs apost-selected Bell measurement on modes B,C (50/50 BS + phase shift + two ancilla detectors). A click heralds entanglement swapped to A\u2013D.  \n   \u2022 Severing module M_sever: measures B,C each in the computational basis (two PBS + detectors), destroying any entanglement.\n\n4) Controlled insertion (static routing)  \n   \u2022 Path c\u2080 routes B,C through M_swap.  \n   \u2022 Path c\u2081 routes B,C through M_sever.  \n   \u2022 Use static beam splitters and phase shifters to implement this \u201cquantum\u2010switch\u201d of measurement primitives.  \n\n5) Post-selection & measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2013 Measure the control photon in basis {|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}:  \n     \u2022 Outcome |0\u27e9 \u2192 network applied swap \u2192 A\u2013D entangled.  \n     \u2022 Outcome |1\u27e9 \u2192 sever \u2192 A\u2013D separable.  \n   \u2013 Measure the control in the Hadamard basis H{|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}:  \n     \u2022 Interference between swap/sever branches yields a jump in the A\u2013D correlation strength, a clear **measurement\u2010induced network phase transition** between entangled vs. separable regimes.  \n\n6) Why Pytheus can do it  \n   \u2022 All operations are static linear optics + 2 pair sources + 1 single emitter + number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n   \u2022 Enforce with `removed_connections` that no source directly connects A\u2194C or B\u2194D except via the intended modules.  \n   \u2022 The **target** is the mapping from control basis & herald clicks to end-mode entanglement vs. separability\u2014a network transformation, not state generation.  \n\nGeneralization  \n   \u2022 Extend to N-link MPS chains with an (N\u20131)-qubit control superposition choosing subsets of swap vs sever on each bond \u2192 explore rich measurement-induced percolation or critical phenomena in tensor networks.  \n\nFeed this description into Pytheus. It will optimize the beam\u2010splitter angles, phase settings, and detector assignments to realize this **quantum switch of measurement primitives**, demonstrating the first photonic measurement-induced phase transition in a tensor-network entanglement network.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal essentially implements a quantum switch between two measurement primitives\u2014entanglement swap versus severing (computational measurement)\u2014controlled and recombined to yield an entangled\u2013vs\u2013separable \u201cphase\u201d via interference. However, this is just another instance of the quantum\u2010switch superposition of two network primitives (swap vs measure) already explored in the ensemble (e.g., the \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct\u2010Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\u201d and the entanglement\u2010switch swap\u2010order schemes). It introduces no new multi\u2010photon projector or nontrivial network\u2010phase effect beyond what existing quantum\u2010switch protocols achieve.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This construction is a straightforward swap\u2010vs\u2010sever quantum switch, closely mirroring previous \u201csuperposition of network primitives\u201d experiments. To be novel at the PRL level, you need a genuinely new measurement primitive or a nontrivial many\u2010body renormalization/critical effect that cannot be reduced to a two\u2010branch quantum switch.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a Pytheus-ready proposal:  \n\nTitle: \u201cMeasurement-Induced Entanglement Routing in a Three-Port Photonic Network\u201d\n\nObjective:\nImplement a **static** linear-optical circuit that takes three Bell pairs and\u2014via a single joint three-photon measurement\u2014heralds entanglement between **any two** of the three \u201cend\u201d modes.  By tuning a single internal phase, the network exhibits a **sharp routing transition**: the preferred entangled link jumps abruptly from one pair of output nodes to another as the phase crosses a critical value.  This is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** of network connectivity.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n  \u2022 Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083 each probabilistically emit one pair in |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 onto modes (A\u2081,B\u2081), (A\u2082,B\u2082), (A\u2083,B\u2083).  \n  \u2022 Modes A\u2081,A\u2082,A\u2083 are the \u201cend\u201d nodes to be entangled; modes B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083 go into the router.\n\n2) Three-Port Router (Multiport Interferometer + Detectors)  \n  \u2022 A static 3\u00d73 multiport unitary U(\u03c6) acts on B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083.  U is built from beam splitters and phase shifters, with one tunable internal phase \u03c6.  \n  \u2022 At U\u2019s outputs we place three photon-number-resolving detectors D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083.  Exactly one click (one photon) among them heralds success.\n\n3) Heralding Rule (Entanglement Routing)  \n  \u2022 If D\u2081 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2082 & A\u2083 become projected into a Bell state.  \n  \u2022 If D\u2082 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2081 & A\u2083 become entangled.  \n  \u2022 If D\u2083 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2081 & A\u2082 become entangled.  \n  \u2022 No other detectors click (post-select on exactly one click).\n\n4) Measurement-Induced Routing Phase Transition  \n  \u2022 Define p_i(\u03c6) = probability that D_i clicks and heralds that routing.  \n  \u2022 As \u03c6 is varied from 0 to 2\u03c0, one finds **sharp crossover points** \u03c6_c where the dominant p_i(\u03c6) jumps from i to j.  \n  \u2022 At \u03c6_c the network topology effectively \u201cswitches phase\u201d\u2014which two end nodes share entanglement changes abruptly\u2014mirroring a percolation or network phase transition induced purely by the measurement basis (\u03c6).\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Design This  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optics only: beam splitters, phase shifters including one tunable \u03c6, and a 3\u00d73 interferometer.  \n  \u2022 Sources: 3 probabilistic Bell-pair emitters.  \n  \u2022 Detectors: 3 router detectors + 4 end analyzers (to verify Bell correlations on the heralded pair).  \n  \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid any direct source\u2192end link other than the intended B\u2081\u2192U, etc.  \n  \u2022 **Target** is the network supermap: for each \u03c6, the mapping from detected outcomes {D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083} to a Bell correlation between the correct pair of A-modes\u2014**no fixed multi-photon state**.\n\nGeneralizations:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-port routers on N Bell pairs: study measurement-induced critical phenomena in larger tensor-networks.  \n  \u2013 Use single-photon control qudits to coherently superpose two different router unitaries, creating indefinite-order routing phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus.  It will optimize the internal beam-splitter reflectivities and phase settings so that exactly one click at D_i \u2192 maximal Bell fidelity between the corresponding A-nodes, and so that p_i(\u03c6) exhibits the desired sharp transitions in routing probability. This is the first minimal photonic demonstration of a **measurement-induced entanglement-routing phase transition** in a tensor-network setting.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This three\u2010port \u201centanglement router\u201d is essentially just another static multiport\u2010based switch that, upon a single\u2010click herald, selects which of three Bell-swap branches succeeds\u2014closely echoing existing entanglement-router protocols (e.g. the dual- and four-way routers in the ensemble) and offering nothing beyond trivial interference\u2010tuned click probabilities. The claimed \u201cphase transition\u201d is just the crossing of sin\u00b2/cos\u00b2 curves in a 3\u00d73 interferometer, not a genuine many-body critical phenomenon or new measurement primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too close to prior entanglement-router schemes in our ensemble (e.g. the Pythreus-compatible multiplexed router and the double-controlled four-way entanglement router) and offers no fundamentally new joint measurement or network-phase effect. To be novel, propose a truly new multi-photon projector or an irreducible measurement-induced critical behavior that cannot be reduced to independent Bell swaps and simple interferometric thresholds."
