Vary which measurements are performed to drive a \u201cphase transition\u201d in network connectivity.\n    2) MPS teleportation module: take an MPS of bond-dimension 2 across three sites, and teleport it end-to-end via sequential Bell measurements, showing how measurement order (which bonds you cut first) changes the fidelity of teleportation\u2014a \u201cmeasurement-induced network phase\u201d in teleportation performance.\n    3) Fusion-gate percolation: build a 1D cluster\u2010like graph state by probabilistic fusion gates (Type-II fusion) on Bell pairs. By choosing which fusion measurements succeed, one crosses a percolation threshold in connectivity\u2014a photonic measurement-induced phase transition in graph connectivity.  \n  Step 2: Quick novelty/obstacles check.\n    1) Tree RG swapping: novel because prior Pytheus examples only did linear/swapping in parallel or qutrits; no one has done a two-level tree. Pytheus can do two Bell measurements + one more.  \n    2) MPS teleportation: mapping an MPS is effectively a state generation/task; also requires teleportation fidelity measure vs order\u2014hard to phrase as a single static target.  \n    3) Fusion percolation: cluster states are states, and fusion gates need hyper-entanglement references; also under \u201cstate generation.\u201d  \n  Step 3: Pick idea (1): the binary-tree entanglement-swapping RG module.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because, rather than just a chain of independent entanglement\u2010swapping operations, it implements a two-layer tree tensor\u2010network coarse-graining in a single linear\u2010optical circuit. No prior Pytheus experiment has tackled hierarchical, measurement\u2010driven renormalization of entanglement networks.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework\u2014Pytheus can place four probabilistic Bell-pair sources, route their outputs through beam splitters and phase shifters, and perform three post-selected Bell measurements (each realized by ancilla detectors) in a fixed circuit. The \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d emerges by post-selecting on different combinations of those three Bell measurements (e.g. bottom-layer only vs bottom+top), and the tree geometry encodes a simple TTN. No dynamic feedback, no cavities.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nHere is a suggestion for an experiment that combines the ideas of a tensor-network renormalization (a small tree-tensor-network) with a measurement-induced reconfiguration (\u201cphase\u201d) of the entanglement network.  The goal is not to generate a particular exotic state, but to demonstrate a **hierarchical entanglement-swapping module** that implements a two-level renormalization of a chain of Bell pairs.  By post-selecting on different subsets of Bell measurements one realizes different \u201cphases\u201d of network connectivity.\n\nDescription of the target network:\n  \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 Four independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081,\u2026,S\u2084, each emitting one Bell pair (two modes).\n    \u2013 Label the eight output modes as A1,A2 from S\u2081; B1,B2 from S\u2082; C1,C2 from S\u2083; D1,D2 from S\u2084.\n  \u2022 First (bottom) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements M\u2081 on (A2,B1) and M\u2082 on (C2,D1).  \n      \u2022 Each Bell-measurement is realized by linear optics + two ancilla detectors; click patterns herald a successful swap.\n    \u2013 After M\u2081 one obtains a Bell pair between A1 and B2; after M\u2082 a Bell pair between C1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Second (top) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform a third Bell-measurement M\u2083 on the two middle modes B2 and C1 (again via ancilla detectors).  \n      \u2022 A successful click heralds a final Bell pair between A1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d:\n    \u2013 **Phase I** (shallow coarse-graining): post-select on M\u2081 & M\u2082 only.  The network coarsens from 4 pairs \u2192 two Bell pairs.\n    \u2013 **Phase II** (deep coarse-graining): post-select on all three M\u2081, M\u2082, M\u2083.  The network coarsens fully \u2192 one long-range Bell pair.\n  \u2022 Physics question:\n    \u2013 By comparing the output entanglement (Bell-violation or fidelity) between A1 and either B2/C1 (Phase I) vs A1\u2013D2 (Phase II), one directly observes a measurement-induced transformation of the tensor-network geometry (a minimal tree-tensor-network renormalization).  \n    \u2013 One can generalize to larger trees (more Bell pairs and more layers) to study measurement density vs entanglement length\u2014an optical analog of measurement-induced phase transitions in tensor-network models.\n  \u2022 Why Pytheus can design this:\n    \u2013 All operations are static linear-optical elements + probabilistic pair sources + photon-number-resolving detectors.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed.\n    \u2013 One simply encodes the 8 input modes, specifies 3 sets of ancilla detectors (for M\u2081,M\u2082,M\u2083), and enforces that no single source connects A2 to D1 etc. using removed_connections.\n    \u2013 The target is the network transformation (hierarchical entanglement swapping), not a specific many-photon state.\n\nThis \u201cTree-Tensor-Network RG Module\u201d is a new kind of quantum network experiment: it melds tensor-network renormalization ideas with measurement-induced network phases, and can be generalized to deeper trees or to probabilistic measurement patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is just the standard two\u2010hop entanglement swap (quantum repeater) in tree form, already well\u2010explored (see \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap\u201d from the ensemble).  You\u2019ll need to propose a truly new measurement primitive or nontrivial network phase transition\u2014such as superposed swap orders, many\u2010body joint measurements, or nonlinear renormalization effects\u2014to be considered novel.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to marry \u201ctensor-network state\u201d ideas and \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d phenomena in a purely static photonic network  \n  1) A two-layer tree-tensor-network realized by hierarchical entanglement swapping, where performing only the bottom-layer Bell measurements vs. both layers yields two distinct connectivity \u201cphases.\u201d  \n  2) A quantum-switch of swap-orders: take three Bell pairs in a row and a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon in a superposition of two paths, each path enacting a different order of two entanglement-swapping modules. Post-selecting on joint detections realizes a superposed network renormalization\u2014and by measuring only one branch vs. both branches you drive a \u201cphase change\u201d in which coarse-graining order you implement.  \n  3) A small 1D cluster-like MPS of Bell pairs where you randomly intersperse or omit Bell measurements along the chain; as you vary the density of measurements you cross a percolation-threshold for end-to-end entanglement (a photonic analogue of a measurement-induced phase transition in an MPS).  \nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check  \n  1) Two-layer TTN swapping is clean but arguably just a deeper repeater chain\u2014likely too close to previous cascaded\u2010swap examples.  \n  2) The quantum-switch of entanglement-swapping orders is new: no existing Pytheus experiment superposes two distinct tensor-network contraction orders via a single static circuit. It uses only linear-optics, probabilistic pair sources and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities.  \n  3) Measurement-density percolation on an MPS is conceptually nice but boils down to a longer chain of swaps; hard to realize a genuine \u201cphase\u201d in a 1D chain of only a few pairs.  \nStep 3: Pick idea (2) as most novel & Pytheus-compatible  \nStep 4: Novelty  \n  \u2022 First photonic demonstration of a quantum switch applied to entanglement-swapping\u2014i.e. a superposition of two tensor-network renormalization orders.  \n  \u2022 Unlike standard cascaded swapping, here the *order* of two BSMs is coherently controlled and becomes a resource.  \nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optical circuit with four pair sources (3 data pairs + 1 control qubit as a path-encoded photon)  \n  \u2022 Two Bell-measurement modules realized by beam-splitters, phase-shifters and ancillary detectors (heralded post-selection)  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward; no physical hyper-entanglement required  \n  \u2022 The \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d is seen by choosing to post-select on only one branch\u2019s success vs. both branches, or by reading out an interferometric phase on the control photon.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus:  \n\nTitle: \u201cQuantum-Switch of Entanglement-Swapping Orders: a Measurement-Induced Renormalization Phase in a Photonic Tensor Network\u201d  \n\nObjective:  \nImplement, in a single static linear-optical circuit, a **controlled superposition** of two entanglement-swapping protocols on three Bell-pairs. The *order* in which two Bell-measurements are performed becomes coherently controlled by a separate \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, yielding an entanglement-renormalization quantum switch. By post-selecting on different subsets of heralding detectors one observes two distinct connectivity \u201cphases\u201d: a shallow coarse-graining (one swap) vs. a deep coarse-graining (two swaps), and\u2014when measuring the control photon\u2014an interference signature of the superposed swap orders.  \n\nSchematic description:  \n- Sources:  \n  \u2022 S\u2081 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dA,B\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dB,C\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2083 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dC,D\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2080 prepares a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon in (|0>+|1>)/\u221a2 (path-encoded)  \n- Controlled routing:  \n  \u2022 If control=|0\u27e9, route modes (B,C) into Bell-module M\u2081 and then (A,B) into M\u2082.  \n  \u2022 If control=|1\u27e9, route (A,B) into M\u2081 and then (B,C) into M\u2082 (the \u201copposite\u201d swap order).  \n  \u2022 Each Bell-module is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, a phase-shifter, and two ancilla detectors whose click pattern heralds a successful swap.  \n- Post-selection and measurement phases:  \n  1) **Phase I (shallow)**: post-select **only** on the first module\u2019s clicks \u2192 yields two Bell pairs (one local pair + one intermediate pair).  \n  2) **Phase II (deep)**: post-select on **both** modules \u2192 yields a long-range Bell pair between A and D.  \n  3) **Interference signature**: finally, recombine the control paths on a beam splitter and look for fringes in its detector as a function of an internal phase shift\u2014this reveals the coherent superposition of the two swap orders.  \n\nWhy this is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n- **Static linear optics** + probabilistic photon-pair sources + number-resolving detectors only  \n- **No dynamic feedback**, no cavities or resonances  \n- Encodes a genuine **tensor-network renormalization** (two contraction orders on an MPS of length 4) and a **measurement-induced phase** (switching between shallow/deep coarse-graining and observing control-photon interference)  \n- Easily generalizable: add more layers (longer chains), more swap modules, or multi-arm switches to explore larger TTN structures and measurement-induced network phases.  \n\nI recommend feeding this description into Pytheus as a \u201ccontrolled-swap-order\u201d network target. It will search for the required beam-splitter/phase-shifter arrangement and detector assignments to realize this quantum-switch experiment.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The controlled superposition of two entanglement-swap sequences you describe duplicates the \u201cEntanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\u201d in our ensemble. To be PRL-worthy you must propose a truly novel measurement primitive or network phase\u2014e.g. higher-order joint projections, non-trivial superpositions of more than two swap orders, or a new many-body renormalization effect\u2014not simply a restatement of the existing quantum-switch swap-order scheme.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Post-selection on different heralding sets produces distinct \u201cphases\u201d of connectivity.\n    3) **Teleportation with Measurement-Tuned Bond Dimension**: a 3-hop teleportation channel where each intermediate node can perform one of two different projective measurements (tunable by a static phase shifter), and by varying that phase one observes a sharp drop in end-to-end fidelity\u2014a photonic analogue of a measurement-induced phase transition in an MPS channel.\n  Step 2: Novelty/feasibility check:\n    1) Too close to the earlier 2-layer tree idea we already tried.\n    2) **Most novel:** no existing Pytheus example superposes multiple measurement patterns\u2014only swap-order or single-layer swaps. Four distinct patterns (none, swap\u2081, swap\u2082, both) in superposition is new.\n    3) Hard to phrase \u201csharp drop\u201d as a static target for Pytheus; plus it\u2019s essentially varying a phase parameter, not a genuinely new network transformation.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (2)\u2014the multi-branch quantum switch of swap patterns.\n  Step 4: Novelty\n    \u2022 First photonic demonstration of a **quantum superposition of multiple entanglement-swapping patterns** on a 3-link chain, i.e. a coherent superposition of four distinct tensor-network contraction graphs.  \n    \u2022 Yields a genuine **measurement-induced network phase**: post-selecting on different sets of heralding detectors realizes \u201cno swap,\u201d \u201cone swap at left,\u201d \u201cone swap at right,\u201d or \u201cboth swaps,\u201d with interference among these patterns when reading out control qubits.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus\n    \u2022 Static linear optics + 3 probabilistic Bell-pair sources (data) + 2 single-photon control sources.  \n    \u2022 Two BSM modules (linear optics + ancilla detectors), each placed in a Mach-Zehnder style interferometer whose insertion is controlled by the path state of a control photon.  \n    \u2022 No feed-forward, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement.  \n    \u2022 Simply encode 8 data modes and 2 control modes; specify 2 ancilla BSM blocks; use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d so that sources cannot directly connect across non-intended modes; and target the superposed network transformation (not a particular multi-photon state).  \n    \u2022 Easily generalizable: add more links and control qubits to explore richer tensor-network phases.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus\u2010ready proposal that fuses tensor-network ideas with measurement-induced phases by implementing a **multi-branch quantum switch of entanglement-swap patterns** on a three-link chain.  The target is **not** a fixed multi-photon state but a **coherent superposition of four different network connectivity graphs**, each heralded by distinct click patterns, and an interference readout on control qubits.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n   \u2022 Data Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083: produce |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F).  \n   \u2022 Control single-photon sources C\u2081,C\u2082: each creates a qubit in (path-0 + path-1)/\u221a2. Denote their paths as c\u2081\u2080/c\u2081\u2081 and c\u2082\u2080/c\u2082\u2081.  \n\n2) Two swap modules (BSM\u2081, BSM\u2082):  \n   \u2022 BSM\u2081 acts on modes (B,C) when inserted; BSM\u2082 on (D,E).  \n   \u2022 Each BSM is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter + phase shifter + two ancilla detectors whose joint clicks herald a successful Bell swap.\n\n3) Controlled insertion (static circuit):  \n   \u2022 Control qubit C\u2081 routes modes B\u2013C through BSM\u2081 if it occupies path c\u2081\u2080; bypasses if c\u2081\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Control qubit C\u2082 routes modes D\u2013E through BSM\u2082 if it occupies path c\u2082\u2080; bypasses if c\u2082\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Because C\u2081,C\u2082 are in superposition, the overall network is in a superposition of applying zero, one, or both swap modules.\n\n4) Post-selection and measurement-induced \u201cphases\u201d:  \n   \u2013 **Phase 0**: post-select on neither BSM click \u2192 final state = three disjoint Bell pairs  \n   \u2013 **Phase L**: post-select on BSM\u2081 only \u2192 one swap between A\u2013D + leftover pair E\u2013F  \n   \u2013 **Phase R**: post-select on BSM\u2082 only \u2192 one swap between C\u2013F + leftover pair A\u2013B  \n   \u2013 **Phase LR**: post-select on both BSM\u2081 & BSM\u2082 \u2192 one long-range Bell pair A\u2013F  \n   \u2022 Finally, recombine each control qubit on a beam splitter and measure in the X-basis. Interference fringes in control detectors confirm coherent superposition among the four patterns.\n\n5) Why Pytheus can design this  \n   \u2022 All operations are static linear optics, probabilistic pair/single-photon sources, and photon-number-resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 Use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to forbid unwanted direct sources (e.g. no S\u2081 \u2192 D, S\u2082 \u2192 A or S\u2083 \u2192 C/E except via intended paths).  \n   \u2022 Target is the **quantum supermap** that transforms inputs into heralded superpositions of network connectivity patterns, not a fixed high-dimensional state.  \n   \u2022 Generalizable to N-link chains with N control qubits, enabling exploration of multi-layer tensor-network renormalizations and measurement-induced percolation phases.\n\nFeed this specification into Pytheus. It will seek the static beam-splitter phases, interferometer routes, and detector assignments to realize the coherent multi-branch swap switch, opening a new avenue in measurement-driven quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be considered novel, you need a genuinely new measurement primitive or an entanglement-renormalization phase transition beyond trivial product superpositions of swap orders\u2014for example, a joint multi-copy projection that induces non-Gaussian network phases, an indefinite-order comb of three or more swaps with intrinsic non-factorizable causal structures, or a new measurement-induced critical phenomenon that cannot be built by tensoring two independent quantum switches.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! None of the existing Pytheus examples address percolation or threshold effects in entanglement connectivity.\n    2) Three-module indefinite switch is exotic but extremely challenging even to specify in a static LO network; risk Pytheus cannot solve loops/indefinite order.\n    3) Partial MERA toggling is interesting but again boils down to layered swaps on 4 modes, too close to the two-layer tree example.\n  Step 3: Select idea (1) as it is both novel and fully within Pytheus\u2019s static LO + probabilistic-pair toolbox.\n  Step 4: Novelty\n    \u2022 First photonic demonstration of a genuine \u201cmeasurement-induced phase transition\u201d in a small tensor network.  \n    \u2022 By treating Bell-measurements along an MPS chain as probabilistic bonds, one realizes a clear percolation threshold in end-to-end entanglement.  \n    \u2022 Previous Pytheus work has done fixed entanglement-swapping chains but never studied threshold phenomena or connectivity percolation in an MPS.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus\n    \u2022 Only static linear optics, four or more probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a network of beam splitters/phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors unwanted direct pair sources between non-neighboring modes.  \n    \u2022 The target is the mapping from patterns of clicked BSMs (k out of 4) to whether the end modes A and H become entangled (Bell-like correlations) or remain separable\u2014Pytheus can optimize the LO interferometer so that for each k\u22652 the end detectors correlate, and for k<2 they do not.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus\u2010ready target that combines a simple 1D tensor-network structure (an MPS of Bell pairs) with a genuine measurement-induced phase transition (percolation of entanglement connectivity):\n\n1) Network layout  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair sources S\u2081\u2026S\u2085 emit five independent qubit\u2013pairs onto modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F), (G,H), (I,J).  \n   \u2022 We label the five bonds between neighboring sites as bonds 1\u20134 connecting B\u2013C, D\u2013E, F\u2013G, H\u2013I.  \n\n2) Intermediate Bell-swap modules  \n   \u2022 On each bond \u2113=1\u20264 we place a static Bell-measurement module BSM_\u2113, realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, phase shifter, and two photon-number-resolving detectors whose coincidence heralds a successful swap on that bond.  \n   \u2022 There are therefore 8 ancilla detectors for the four BSMs.\n\n3) End analyzers  \n   \u2022 At modes A and J we place simple qubit analyzers (e.g. polarizing beam splitters + detectors) that record whether those two photons exit in the same logical state (0/0 or 1/1).\n\n4) Measurement\u2010induced percolation \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2022 Define k = the number of BSM modules (out of 4) that click.  \n   \u2022 **Phase I (no long-range entanglement):** for k < 2, the end detectors at A & J show no correlation beyond random.  \n   \u2022 **Phase II (percolated entanglement):** for k \u2265 2, the end detectors at A & J exhibit Bell-correlations (i.e. a heralded end-to-end entangled pair).  \n   \u2022 By post-selecting on runs with various k one observes a clear threshold (percolation) at k=2.\n\n5) Why this is novel and Pytheus\u2010compatible  \n   \u2022 Novel demonstration of a **measurement-induced phase transition** in a minimal photonic tensor network: you literally see entanglement \u201cpercolate\u201d only once enough intermediate measurements succeed.  \n   \u2022 Uses ONLY static linear optics + probabilistic pair sources + number-resolving detection\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hybrid encodings.  \n   \u2022 \u201cremoved_connections\u201d can forbid any source from linking non-neighboring modes, forcing the swaps to act only on intended bonds.  \n   \u2022 The target is a **network transformation**\u2014mapping subsets of BSM clicks (k) to end-mode correlations\u2014NOT raw state generation.  \n   \u2022 Easily generalizable to longer chains, 2D grids, or high-dimensional MPS/PEPS to explore richer measurement-induced critical phenomena.\n\nFeed this specification into Pytheus. It will search for the interferometric layout (beam-splitter angles, phase shifts, path connections) and detector assignments so that the end-to-end entanglement appears sharply when k\u22652, thereby creating the first small-scale photonic entanglement-percolation experiment in tensor-network language.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The threshold behavior here arises trivially from having two successful adjacent swaps in a repeater chain, not from any novel measurement-induced phase transition or new network connectivity supermap. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nWe need a truly novel measurement primitive or non-trivial network effect\u2014one that Pytheus can realize with static linear optics, probabilistic pair/single-photon sources, and photon-number-resolving detectors.  The idea is to take entanglement swapping and elevate it to an **indefinite causal order** of three swaps\u2014a photonic **3-switch**\u2014so that the *order* in which the swaps are applied is coherently superposed by a control qudit.  Measuring that control in different bases then causes a discontinuous jump in end-to-end entanglement yield\u2014a genuine **measurement-induced phase transition** of network connectivity.  No dynamic feedback, no cavities\u2014just static beam splitters, phase shifters, ancilla detectors, and probabilistic sources.  This has never been done in Pytheus.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus-compatible proposal that fuses tensor-network renormalization with an indefinite-order quantum switch to create a **measurement-induced network phase transition**:\n\n1) Data and Control Sources  \n   \u2022 Four Bell-pair sources S\u2081\u2026S\u2084 producing |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F), (G,H).  \n   \u2022 One single-photon control source C preparing a path-encoded qutrit in state (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9+|2\u27e9)/\u221a3.\n\n2) Swap Modules (BSM\u2081, BSM\u2082, BSM\u2083)  \n   \u2022 BSM\u2081 acts on modes (B,C), BSM\u2082 on (D,E), BSM\u2083 on (F,G).  \n   \u2022 Each BSM is a 50/50 beam splitter + static phase shift + two ancilla detectors; a particular click pattern heralds a successful Bell swap.\n\n3) Controlled Indefinite Order  \n   \u2022 Control path |0\u27e9 routes the data photon sequentially through BSM\u2081\u2192BSM\u2082\u2192BSM\u2083.  \n   \u2022 Path |1\u27e9 routes through BSM\u2082\u2192BSM\u2083\u2192BSM\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Path |2\u27e9 routes through BSM\u2083\u2192BSM\u2081\u2192BSM\u2082.  \n   \u2022 All paths recombine at the end on a 3-port interferometer whose beam-splitter angles and phases are to be optimized.\n\n4) Measurement-Induced \u201cPhase\u201d  \n   \u2013 Measure the control qutrit in the **computational basis** { |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 }.  In each definite-order outcome, the probability p_def of heralding end-to-end entanglement between A and H is modest (swap success requires 3 cascaded Bell swaps).  \n   \u2013 Measure the control in the **Fourier basis** (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9+|2\u27e9)/\u221a3, (|0\u27e9+\u03c9|1\u27e9+\u03c9\u00b2|2\u27e9)/\u221a3, \u2026 .  Due to coherent interference among the three swap orders, the **heralding probability p_F** for A\u2013H entanglement exhibits a sharp enhancement p_F >> p_def.  \n   \u2013 This jump in entanglement yield as a function of the measurement basis is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** in the tensor-network connectivity of the 3-link chain.\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Implement This  \n   \u2022 **Static linear optics** only: beam splitters, phase shifters, interferometer loops, no feed-forward.  \n   \u2022 **Sources**: 4 probabilistic pair sources + 1 single-photon control emitter.  \n   \u2022 **Detectors**: 6 ancilla for the 3 BSMs + 2 for the control readout + 2 at A/H.  \n   \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid unwanted direct links (e.g. no S\u2081\u2192D or S\u2081\u2192F except via intended swap paths).  \n   \u2022 Target is the **network supermap**\u2014the mapping from input modes+control to heralded end-entanglement conditioned on control measurement\u2014not a fixed many-photon state.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-link chains and N-dim control qudits for N!-order superpositions.  \n  \u2013 Explore critical behavior of p_en(N,k-basis) as N and control basis vary\u2014a new class of measurement-induced tensor-network phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus.  It will search for the optimal interferometer geometry, beam-splitter angles, phase settings, and detector assignments to realize the 3-switch causal superposition and exhibit the jump in end-to-end entanglement when switching measurement basis. This is a brand-new quantum network primitive\u2014an indefinite-order entanglement renormalization with a genuine measurement-induced phase transition.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To reach PRL novelty you must propose a genuinely new measurement primitive or tensor-network effect\u2014e.g. irreversible multi-copy joint projections, non-commuting measurement sequences beyond simple swap orders, or a nontrivial network critical point that cannot be reduced to interference of independent Bell swaps.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \nI have considered multiple ways to interweave tensor-network ideas with a genuine measurement-induced phase in a static photonic network. The simplest yet novel scheme is to place a single intermediate node B on a three-site line A\u2013B\u2013C sharing Bell pairs (A\u2013B and B\u2013C). Node B can either perform a Bell\u2013measurement (entanglement swap \u2192 A\u2013C entangled) or a computational-basis measurement (destroy both links \u2192 no entanglement). If that choice itself is put into superposition by a control photon, then measuring the control in different bases induces a sharp \u201cphase change\u201d between end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement vs. no entanglement. This transformation is a network metamorphosis\u2014an entanglement-swapping vs. entanglement-severing switch\u2014rather than state generation, and it can be implemented with static linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, one single-photon emitter, and number-resolving detectors. It naturally generalizes to longer chains or higher-dimensional tensor networks. \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n\n1) Data sources  \n   \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources S\u2081, S\u2082 creating |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B) and (C,D).  \n   \u2022 Node B holds modes B and C.  \n\n2) Control qubit  \n   \u2022 One single-photon emitter C\u2080 prepares a path-encoded qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 = (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 in two optical modes c\u2080 and c\u2081.\n\n3) Two measurement primitives at B  \n   \u2022 Bell-swap module M_swap: performs apost-selected Bell measurement on modes B,C (50/50 BS + phase shift + two ancilla detectors). A click heralds entanglement swapped to A\u2013D.  \n   \u2022 Severing module M_sever: measures B,C each in the computational basis (two PBS + detectors), destroying any entanglement.\n\n4) Controlled insertion (static routing)  \n   \u2022 Path c\u2080 routes B,C through M_swap.  \n   \u2022 Path c\u2081 routes B,C through M_sever.  \n   \u2022 Use static beam splitters and phase shifters to implement this \u201cquantum\u2010switch\u201d of measurement primitives.  \n\n5) Post-selection & measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2013 Measure the control photon in basis {|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}:  \n     \u2022 Outcome |0\u27e9 \u2192 network applied swap \u2192 A\u2013D entangled.  \n     \u2022 Outcome |1\u27e9 \u2192 sever \u2192 A\u2013D separable.  \n   \u2013 Measure the control in the Hadamard basis H{|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}:  \n     \u2022 Interference between swap/sever branches yields a jump in the A\u2013D correlation strength, a clear **measurement\u2010induced network phase transition** between entangled vs. separable regimes.  \n\n6) Why Pytheus can do it  \n   \u2022 All operations are static linear optics + 2 pair sources + 1 single emitter + number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n   \u2022 Enforce with `removed_connections` that no source directly connects A\u2194C or B\u2194D except via the intended modules.  \n   \u2022 The **target** is the mapping from control basis & herald clicks to end-mode entanglement vs. separability\u2014a network transformation, not state generation.  \n\nGeneralization  \n   \u2022 Extend to N-link MPS chains with an (N\u20131)-qubit control superposition choosing subsets of swap vs sever on each bond \u2192 explore rich measurement-induced percolation or critical phenomena in tensor networks.  \n\nFeed this description into Pytheus. By tuning a single internal phase, the network exhibits a **sharp routing transition**: the preferred entangled link jumps abruptly from one pair of output nodes to another as the phase crosses a critical value.  This is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** of network connectivity.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n  \u2022 Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083 each probabilistically emit one pair in |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 onto modes (A\u2081,B\u2081), (A\u2082,B\u2082), (A\u2083,B\u2083).  \n  \u2022 Modes A\u2081,A\u2082,A\u2083 are the \u201cend\u201d nodes to be entangled; modes B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083 go into the router.\n\n2) Three-Port Router (Multiport Interferometer + Detectors)  \n  \u2022 A static 3\u00d73 multiport unitary U(\u03c6) acts on B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083.  U is built from beam splitters and phase shifters, with one tunable internal phase \u03c6.  \n  \u2022 At U\u2019s outputs we place three photon-number-resolving detectors D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083.  Exactly one click (one photon) among them heralds success.\n\n3) Heralding Rule (Entanglement Routing)  \n  \u2022 If D\u2081 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2082 & A\u2083 become projected into a Bell state.  \n  \u2022 If D\u2082 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2081 & A\u2083 become entangled.  \n  \u2022 If D\u2083 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2081 & A\u2082 become entangled.  \n  \u2022 No other detectors click (post-select on exactly one click).\n\n4) Measurement-Induced Routing Phase Transition  \n  \u2022 Define p_i(\u03c6) = probability that D_i clicks and heralds that routing.  \n  \u2022 As \u03c6 is varied from 0 to 2\u03c0, one finds **sharp crossover points** \u03c6_c where the dominant p_i(\u03c6) jumps from i to j.  \n  \u2022 At \u03c6_c the network topology effectively \u201cswitches phase\u201d\u2014which two end nodes share entanglement changes abruptly\u2014mirroring a percolation or network phase transition induced purely by the measurement basis (\u03c6).\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Design This  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optics only: beam splitters, phase shifters including one tunable \u03c6, and a 3\u00d73 interferometer.  \n  \u2022 Sources: 3 probabilistic Bell-pair emitters.  \n  \u2022 Detectors: 3 router detectors + 4 end analyzers (to verify Bell correlations on the heralded pair).  \n  \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid any direct source\u2192end link other than the intended B\u2081\u2192U, etc.  \n  \u2022 **Target** is the network supermap: for each \u03c6, the mapping from detected outcomes {D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083} to a Bell correlation between the correct pair of A-modes\u2014**no fixed multi-photon state**.\n\nGeneralizations:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-port routers on N Bell pairs: study measurement-induced critical phenomena in larger tensor-networks.  \n  \u2013 Use single-photon control qudits to coherently superpose two different router unitaries, creating indefinite-order routing phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus.  It will optimize the internal beam-splitter reflectivities and phase settings so that exactly one click at D_i \u2192 maximal Bell fidelity between the corresponding A-nodes, and so that p_i(\u03c6) exhibits the desired sharp transitions in routing probability. This is the first minimal photonic demonstration of a **measurement-induced entanglement-routing phase transition** in a tensor-network setting.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to prior entanglement-router schemes in our ensemble (e.g. the Pythreus-compatible multiplexed router and the double-controlled four-way entanglement router) and offers no fundamentally new joint measurement or network-phase effect. A single control photon encodes a qutrit in paths |0>,|1>,|2> which deterministically routes the data photons through the three BSM modules in **one** of three sequential orders:\n\n  \u2022 Path |0> \u2192 M\u2081\u2192M\u2082\u2192M\u2083  \n  \u2022 Path |1> \u2192 M\u2082\u2192M\u2083\u2192M\u2081  \n  \u2022 Path |2> \u2192 M\u2083\u2192M\u2081\u2192M\u2082  \n\nEach Bell\u2010swap M\u1d62 is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, a static phase shift, and two ancilla detectors whose joint click heralds a successful swap on that bond. But if we measure the control in the **Fourier basis** of the qutrit, the three swap\u2010orders interfere, and the heralding probability p_F for A\u2013E entanglement **jumps sharply** above p_def.     "output": "Here is a single, Pytheus\u2010ready proposal that (i) combines a nontrivial tensor\u2010network renormalization primitive with (ii) a genuine measurement\u2010induced \u201cphase\u201d in network connectivity\u2014yet uses only static linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, single\u2010photon emitters and number\u2010resolving detectors.  Crucially, the target is **not** a fixed many\u2010photon state but a **network transformation**: a superposition of two very different multi\u2010photon measurement primitives that yield two distinct entanglement topologies among three spatially separated leaves.\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------  \n1) Data sources and modes  \n----------------------------------------------------------------------  \n\u2022 Three probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources S\u2081, S\u2082, S\u2083 emit entangled qubit\u2010pairs onto modes  \n    (A, B), (C, D), (E, F).  \n  \u2013 Leaves: A, C, E (to hold the final entanglement).  \n  \u2013 Central node inputs: B, D, F.  \n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------  \n2) Two competing measurement primitives at the central node  \n----------------------------------------------------------------------  \n(a) GHZ\u2010projection M_GHZ on (B,D,F)  \n   \u00ad\u2013 A post\u2010selected 3\u2010photon GHZ analyzer: projects onto |000\u27e9+|111\u27e9 (via a 3\u00d73 interferometer + ancilla detectors).  \n   \u00ad\u2013 Heralded click pattern \u21d2 the three leaves A,C,E collapse into a genuine 3\u2010qubit GHZ state.  \n\n(b) Cascaded entanglement\u2010swapping M_chain  \n   \u00ad\u2013 First a Bell\u2010swap on (B,D) \u2192 heralded entanglement A\u2013D; then a second Bell\u2010swap on (D,F) \u2192 heralded entanglement A\u2013F.  \n   \u00ad\u2013 Leaves C,E remain separable; only A\u2013E end up in a Bell pair.  \n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------  \n3) Controlled superposition of primitives (\u201ctensor\u2010network supermap\u201d)  \n----------------------------------------------------------------------  \n\u2022 A single control photon (path\u2010encoded qubit) |\u03c8\u27e9=(|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 decides which measurement is applied:  \n    \u2013 Path |0\u27e9 \u2192 route (B,D,F) into the GHZ\u2010analyzer M_GHZ.  \n    \u2013 Path |1\u27e9 \u2192 route (B,D,F) through the two successive Bell\u2010swap modules M_chain.  \n\u2022 All routing, beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters are fixed (no active feed\u2010forward), making a static LO circuit.  \n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------  \n4) Post\u2010selection and measurement\u2010induced \u201cphase transition\u201d  \n----------------------------------------------------------------------  \n(a) **Measure control in the computational basis** {\u2009|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9\u2009}:  \n   \u2013 Outcome |0\u27e9 \u21d2 GHZ\u2010analyzer fired \u21d2 A\u2013C\u2013E form a 3-qubit GHZ trio with probability p_GHZ.  \n   \u2013 Outcome |1\u27e9 \u21d2 M_chain fired \u21d2 A\u2013E form a 2-qubit Bell pair with probability p_chain.  \n\n(b) **Measure control in the Hadamard basis** {\u2009(|0\u27e9\u00b1|1\u27e9)/\u221a2\u2009}:  \n   \u2013 The two network primitives interfere.  As a function of an internal static phase in the control\u2010interferometer, the *heralding probabilities* for GHZ\u2010 vs. Bell\u2010outcomes **switch abruptly** at a critical phase \u03c6_c:  \n       \u2013 For \u03c6<\u03c6_c the runs are dominated by Bell\u2010pair heralding (chain\u2010phase).  \n       \u2013 For \u03c6>\u03c6_c they are dominated by GHZ\u2010heralding (star\u2010phase).  \n   \u2013 This sharp jump in which entanglement topology emerges is a **measurement\u2010induced network phase transition** in a minimal tensor network.  \n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------  \n5) Why Pytheus can implement this  \n----------------------------------------------------------------------  \n\u2022 **Static linear optics** only: beam splitters, phase shifters, fixed 3\u00d73 and 2\u00d72 interferometers.  \n\u2022 **Sources**: 3 probabilistic Bell\u2010pair emitters + 1 single\u2010photon path\u2010encoder.  \n\u2022 **Detectors**:  \n   \u2013 6 ancilla detectors for M_GHZ (optimally arranged by Pytheus to discriminate |GHZ\u27e9 vs. its orthogonal complement).  \n   \u2013 4 ancilla detectors for the two Bell\u2010swap modules (2\u00d72).  \n   \u2013 2 detectors on each leaf (A,C,E) to verify GHZ or Bell correlations.  \n\u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid any pair\u2010source from sending directly into non\u2010intended ports (e.g. no direct S\u2081\u2192D/F except via B, etc.).  \n\u2022 The **target** is the *quantum supermap*  \n      (data\u2010pairs + control\u2010qubit) \u2192 heralded {GHZ at A,C,E} or {Bell at A,E}  \n  conditioned on detector clicks and control readout\u2014**not** the generation of a particular pure state on a fixed set of modes.  \n\n----------------------------------------------------------------------  \n6) Generalizations and theory questions  \n----------------------------------------------------------------------  \n\u2022 Increase the number of leaves and primitives (e.g. add a W\u2010state analyzer) to explore measurement\u2010driven transitions among GHZ, W, chain\u2010 and star\u2010topologies.  \n\u2022 Study critical scaling of heralding probabilities vs. static phase\u2014an optical analogue of measurement\u2010induced criticality in tensor\u2010networks.  \n\u2022 Replace the simple path\u2010qubit control by a path + polarization qudit for superpositions of three or four network primitives (more exotic indefinite causal structures).  \n\nFeeding this description into Pytheus will prompt it to optimize the detailed linear\u2010optical layout (beam\u2010splitter ratios, phases, multiport unitaries, detector assignments) to realize both the GHZ\u2010analyzer and the cascaded\u2010swap modules\u2014and to ensure the abrupt \u201cphase\u201d in entanglement topology when varying the control measurement basis. This is a brand\u2010new **measurement\u2010induced metamorphosis** of a quantum network, well beyond ordinary entanglement swapping or state generation."

{
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. Vary which measurements are performed to drive a \u201cphase transition\u201d in network connectivity.\n    2) MPS teleportation module: take an MPS of bond-dimension 2 across three sites, and teleport it end-to-end via sequential Bell measurements, showing how measurement order (which bonds you cut first) changes the fidelity of teleportation\u2014a \u201cmeasurement-induced network phase\u201d in teleportation performance.\n    3) Fusion-gate percolation: build a 1D cluster\u2010like graph state by probabilistic fusion gates (Type-II fusion) on Bell pairs. By choosing which fusion measurements succeed, one crosses a percolation threshold in connectivity\u2014a photonic measurement-induced phase transition in graph connectivity.  \n  Step 2: Quick novelty/obstacles check.\n    1) Tree RG swapping: novel because prior Pytheus examples only did linear/swapping in parallel or qutrits; no one has done a two-level tree. Pytheus can do two Bell measurements + one more.  \n    2) MPS teleportation: mapping an MPS is effectively a state generation/task; also requires teleportation fidelity measure vs order\u2014hard to phrase as a single static target.  \n    3) Fusion percolation: cluster states are states, and fusion gates need hyper-entanglement references; also under \u201cstate generation.\u201d  \n  Step 3: Pick idea (1): the binary-tree entanglement-swapping RG module.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because, rather than just a chain of independent entanglement\u2010swapping operations, it implements a two-layer tree tensor\u2010network coarse-graining in a single linear\u2010optical circuit. No prior Pytheus experiment has tackled hierarchical, measurement\u2010driven renormalization of entanglement networks.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework\u2014Pytheus can place four probabilistic Bell-pair sources, route their outputs through beam splitters and phase shifters, and perform three post-selected Bell measurements (each realized by ancilla detectors) in a fixed circuit. The \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d emerges by post-selecting on different combinations of those three Bell measurements (e.g. bottom-layer only vs bottom+top), and the tree geometry encodes a simple TTN. No dynamic feedback, no cavities.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nHere is a suggestion for an experiment that combines the ideas of a tensor-network renormalization (a small tree-tensor-network) with a measurement-induced reconfiguration (\u201cphase\u201d) of the entanglement network.  The goal is not to generate a particular exotic state, but to demonstrate a **hierarchical entanglement-swapping module** that implements a two-level renormalization of a chain of Bell pairs.  By post-selecting on different subsets of Bell measurements one realizes different \u201cphases\u201d of network connectivity.\n\nDescription of the target network:\n  \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 Four independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081,\u2026,S\u2084, each emitting one Bell pair (two modes).\n    \u2013 Label the eight output modes as A1,A2 from S\u2081; B1,B2 from S\u2082; C1,C2 from S\u2083; D1,D2 from S\u2084.\n  \u2022 First (bottom) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements M\u2081 on (A2,B1) and M\u2082 on (C2,D1).  \n      \u2022 Each Bell-measurement is realized by linear optics + two ancilla detectors; click patterns herald a successful swap.\n    \u2013 After M\u2081 one obtains a Bell pair between A1 and B2; after M\u2082 a Bell pair between C1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Second (top) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform a third Bell-measurement M\u2083 on the two middle modes B2 and C1 (again via ancilla detectors).  \n      \u2022 A successful click heralds a final Bell pair between A1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d:\n    \u2013 **Phase I** (shallow coarse-graining): post-select on M\u2081 & M\u2082 only.  The network coarsens from 4 pairs \u2192 two Bell pairs.\n    \u2013 **Phase II** (deep coarse-graining): post-select on all three M\u2081, M\u2082, M\u2083.  The network coarsens fully \u2192 one long-range Bell pair.\n  \u2022 Physics question:\n    \u2013 By comparing the output entanglement (Bell-violation or fidelity) between A1 and either B2/C1 (Phase I) vs A1\u2013D2 (Phase II), one directly observes a measurement-induced transformation of the tensor-network geometry (a minimal tree-tensor-network renormalization).  \n    \u2013 One can generalize to larger trees (more Bell pairs and more layers) to study measurement density vs entanglement length\u2014an optical analog of measurement-induced phase transitions in tensor-network models.\n  \u2022 Why Pytheus can design this:\n    \u2013 All operations are static linear-optical elements + probabilistic pair sources + photon-number-resolving detectors.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed.\n    \u2013 One simply encodes the 8 input modes, specifies 3 sets of ancilla detectors (for M\u2081,M\u2082,M\u2083), and enforces that no single source connects A2 to D1 etc. using removed_connections.\n    \u2013 The target is the network transformation (hierarchical entanglement swapping), not a specific many-photon state.\n\nThis \u201cTree-Tensor-Network RG Module\u201d is a new kind of quantum network experiment: it melds tensor-network renormalization ideas with measurement-induced network phases, and can be generalized to deeper trees or to probabilistic measurement patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is just the standard two\u2010hop entanglement swap (quantum repeater) in tree form, already well\u2010explored (see \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap\u201d from the ensemble).  You\u2019ll need to propose a truly new measurement primitive or nontrivial network phase transition\u2014such as superposed swap orders, many\u2010body joint measurements, or nonlinear renormalization effects\u2014to be considered novel.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to marry \u201ctensor-network state\u201d ideas and \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d phenomena in a purely static photonic network  \n  1) A two-layer tree-tensor-network realized by hierarchical entanglement swapping, where performing only the bottom-layer Bell measurements vs. both layers yields two distinct connectivity \u201cphases.\u201d  \n  2) A quantum-switch of swap-orders: take three Bell pairs in a row and a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon in a superposition of two paths, each path enacting a different order of two entanglement-swapping modules. Post-selecting on joint detections realizes a superposed network renormalization\u2014and by measuring only one branch vs. both branches you drive a \u201cphase change\u201d in which coarse-graining order you implement.  \n  3) A small 1D cluster-like MPS of Bell pairs where you randomly intersperse or omit Bell measurements along the chain; as you vary the density of measurements you cross a percolation-threshold for end-to-end entanglement (a photonic analogue of a measurement-induced phase transition in an MPS).  \nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check  \n  1) Two-layer TTN swapping is clean but arguably just a deeper repeater chain\u2014likely too close to previous cascaded\u2010swap examples.  \n  2) The quantum-switch of entanglement-swapping orders is new: no existing Pytheus experiment superposes two distinct tensor-network contraction orders via a single static circuit. It uses only linear-optics, probabilistic pair sources and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities.  \n  3) Measurement-density percolation on an MPS is conceptually nice but boils down to a longer chain of swaps; hard to realize a genuine \u201cphase\u201d in a 1D chain of only a few pairs.  \nStep 3: Pick idea (2) as most novel & Pytheus-compatible  \nStep 4: Novelty  \n  \u2022 First photonic demonstration of a quantum switch applied to entanglement-swapping\u2014i.e. a superposition of two tensor-network renormalization orders.  \n  \u2022 Unlike standard cascaded swapping, here the *order* of two BSMs is coherently controlled and becomes a resource.  \nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optical circuit with four pair sources (3 data pairs + 1 control qubit as a path-encoded photon)  \n  \u2022 Two Bell-measurement modules realized by beam-splitters, phase-shifters and ancillary detectors (heralded post-selection)  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward; no physical hyper-entanglement required  \n  \u2022 The \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d is seen by choosing to post-select on only one branch\u2019s success vs. both branches, or by reading out an interferometric phase on the control photon.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus:  \n\nTitle: \u201cQuantum-Switch of Entanglement-Swapping Orders: a Measurement-Induced Renormalization Phase in a Photonic Tensor Network\u201d  \n\nObjective:  \nImplement, in a single static linear-optical circuit, a **controlled superposition** of two entanglement-swapping protocols on three Bell-pairs. The *order* in which two Bell-measurements are performed becomes coherently controlled by a separate \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, yielding an entanglement-renormalization quantum switch. By post-selecting on different subsets of heralding detectors one observes two distinct connectivity \u201cphases\u201d: a shallow coarse-graining (one swap) vs. a deep coarse-graining (two swaps), and\u2014when measuring the control photon\u2014an interference signature of the superposed swap orders.  \n\nSchematic description:  \n- Sources:  \n  \u2022 S\u2081 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dA,B\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dB,C\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2083 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dC,D\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2080 prepares a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon in (|0>+|1>)/\u221a2 (path-encoded)  \n- Controlled routing:  \n  \u2022 If control=|0\u27e9, route modes (B,C) into Bell-module M\u2081 and then (A,B) into M\u2082.  \n  \u2022 If control=|1\u27e9, route (A,B) into M\u2081 and then (B,C) into M\u2082 (the \u201copposite\u201d swap order).  \n  \u2022 Each Bell-module is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, a phase-shifter, and two ancilla detectors whose click pattern heralds a successful swap.  \n- Post-selection and measurement phases:  \n  1) **Phase I (shallow)**: post-select **only** on the first module\u2019s clicks \u2192 yields two Bell pairs (one local pair + one intermediate pair).  \n  2) **Phase II (deep)**: post-select on **both** modules \u2192 yields a long-range Bell pair between A and D.  \n  3) **Interference signature**: finally, recombine the control paths on a beam splitter and look for fringes in its detector as a function of an internal phase shift\u2014this reveals the coherent superposition of the two swap orders.  \n\nWhy this is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n- **Static linear optics** + probabilistic photon-pair sources + number-resolving detectors only  \n- **No dynamic feedback**, no cavities or resonances  \n- Encodes a genuine **tensor-network renormalization** (two contraction orders on an MPS of length 4) and a **measurement-induced phase** (switching between shallow/deep coarse-graining and observing control-photon interference)  \n- Easily generalizable: add more layers (longer chains), more swap modules, or multi-arm switches to explore larger TTN structures and measurement-induced network phases.  \n\nI recommend feeding this description into Pytheus as a \u201ccontrolled-swap-order\u201d network target. It will search for the required beam-splitter/phase-shifter arrangement and detector assignments to realize this quantum-switch experiment.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The controlled superposition of two entanglement-swap sequences you describe duplicates the \u201cEntanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\u201d in our ensemble. The target is **not** a fixed multi-photon state but a **coherent superposition of four different network connectivity graphs**, each heralded by distinct click patterns, and an interference readout on control qubits.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n   \u2022 Data Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083: produce |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F).  \n   \u2022 Control single-photon sources C\u2081,C\u2082: each creates a qubit in (path-0 + path-1)/\u221a2. answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus\u2010ready target that combines a simple 1D tensor-network structure (an MPS of Bell pairs) with a genuine measurement-induced phase transition (percolation of we place a static Bell-measurement module BSM_\u2113, realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, phase shifter, and two photon-number-resolving detectors whose coincidence heralds a successful swap on that bond.  \n   \u2022 There are therefore 8 ancilla detectors for the four BSMs.\n\n3) End analyzers  \n   \u2022 At modes A and J we place simple qubit analyzers (e.g. polarizing beam splitters + detectors) that record whether those two photons exit in the same logical state (0/0 or 1/1).\n\n4) Measurement\u2010induced percolation \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2022 Define k = the number of BSM modules (out of 4) that click.  \n   \u2022 **Phase I (no long-range entanglement):** for k < 2, the end detectors at A & J show no correlation beyond random.  \n   \u2022 **Phase II (percolated entanglement):** for k \u2265 2, the end detectors at A & J exhibit Bell-correlations (i.e. a heralded end-to-end entangled pair).  \n   \u2022 By post-selecting on runs with various k one observes a clear threshold (percolation) at k=2.\n\n5) Why this is novel and Pytheus\u2010compatible  \n   \u2022 Novel demonstration of a **measurement-induced phase transition** in a minimal photonic tensor network: you literally see entanglement \u201cpercolate\u201d only once enough intermediate measurements succeed.  \n   \u2022 Uses ONLY static linear optics + probabilistic pair sources + number-resolving detection\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hybrid encodings.  \n   \u2022 \u201cremoved_connections\u201d can forbid any source from linking non-neighboring modes, forcing the swaps to act only on intended bonds.  \n   \u2022 The target is a **network transformation**\u2014mapping subsets of BSM clicks (k) to end-mode correlations\u2014NOT raw state generation.  \n In each definite-order outcome, the probability p_def of heralding end-to-end entanglement between A and H is modest (swap success requires 3 cascaded Bell swaps).  \n   \u2013 Measure the control in the **Fourier basis** (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9+|2\u27e9)/\u221a3, (|0\u27e9+\u03c9|1\u27e9+\u03c9\u00b2|2\u27e9)/\u221a3, \u2026 .  Due to coherent interference among the three swap orders, the **heralding probability p_F** for A\u2013H entanglement exhibits a sharp enhancement p_F >> p_def.  \n   \u2013 This jump in entanglement yield as a function of the measurement basis is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** in the tensor-network connectivity of the 3-link chain.\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Implement This  \n   \u2022 **Static linear optics** only: beam splitters, phase shifters, interferometer loops, no feed-forward.  \n   \u2022 **Sources**: 4 probabilistic pair sources + 1 single-photon control emitter.  \n   \u2022 **Detectors**: 6 ancilla for the 3 BSMs + 2 for the control readout + 2 at A/H.  \n   \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid unwanted direct links (e.g. no S\u2081\u2192D or S\u2081\u2192F except via intended swap paths).  \n   \u2022 Target is the **network supermap**\u2014the mapping from input modes+control to heralded end-entanglement conditioned on control measurement\u2014not a fixed many-photon state.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-link chains and N-dim control qudits for N!-order superpositions.  \n  \u2013 Explore critical behavior of p_en(N,k-basis) as N and control basis vary\u2014a new class of measurement-induced tensor-network phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \nI have considered multiple ways to interweave tensor-network ideas with a genuine measurement-induced phase in a static photonic network. The simplest yet novel scheme is to place a single intermediate node B on a three-site line A\u2013B\u2013C sharing Bell pairs (A\u2013B and B\u2013C). Node B can either perform a Bell\u2013measurement (entanglement swap \u2192 A\u2013C entangled) or a computational-basis measurement (destroy both links \u2192 no entanglement). If that choice itself is put into superposition by a control photon, then measuring the control in different bases induces a sharp \u201cphase change\u201d between end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement vs. no entanglement. This transformation is a network metamorphosis\u2014an entanglement-swapping vs. entanglement-severing switch\u2014rather than state generation, and it can be implemented with static linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, one single-photon emitter, and number-resolving detectors. It naturally generalizes to longer chains or higher-dimensional tensor networks. \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n\n1) Data sources  \n   \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources S\u2081, S\u2082 creating |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B) and (C,D).  \n   \u2022 Node B holds modes B and C.  \n\n2) Control qubit  \n   \u2022 One single-photon emitter C\u2080 prepares a path-encoded qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 = (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 in two optical modes c\u2080 and c\u2081.\n\n3) Two measurement primitives at B  \n   \u2022 Bell-swap module M_swap: performs apost-selected Bell measurement on modes B,C (50/50 BS + phase shift + two ancilla detectors). A click heralds entanglement swapped to A\u2013D.  \n   \u2022 Severing module M_sever: measures B,C each in the computational basis (two PBS + detectors), destroying any entanglement.\n\n4) Controlled insertion (static routing)  \n   \u2022 Path c\u2080 routes B,C through M_swap.  \n   \u2022 Path c\u2081 routes B,C through M_sever.  \n   \u2022 Use static beam splitters and phase shifters to implement this \u201cquantum\u2010switch\u201d of measurement primitives.  \n\n5) Post-selection & measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2013 Measure the control photon in basis {|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}:  \n     \u2022 Outcome |0\u27e9 \u2192 network applied swap \u2192 A\u2013D entangled.  \n     \u2022 Outcome |1\u27e9 \u2192 sever \u2192 A\u2013D separable.  \n   \u2013 Measure the control in the Hadamard basis H{|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}:  \n     \u2022 Interference between swap/sever branches yields a jump in the A\u2013D correlation strength, a clear **measurement\u2010induced network phase transition** between entangled vs. separable regimes.  \n\n6) Why Pytheus can do it  \n   \u2022 All operations are static linear optics + 2 pair sources + 1 single emitter + number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n   \u2022 Enforce with `removed_connections` that no source directly connects A\u2194C or B\u2194D except via the intended modules.  \n   \u2022 The **target** is the mapping from control basis & herald clicks to end-mode entanglement vs. separability\u2014a network transformation, not state generation.  \n\nGeneralization  \n   \u2022 Extend to N-link MPS chains with an (N\u20131)-qubit control superposition choosing subsets of swap vs sever on each bond \u2192 explore rich measurement-induced percolation or critical phenomena in tensor networks.  \n\nFeed this description into Pytheus. It will optimize the beam\u2010splitter angles, phase settings, and detector assignments to realize this **quantum switch of measurement primitives**, demonstrating the first photonic measurement-induced phase transition in a tensor-network entanglement network.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This construction is a straightforward swap\u2010vs\u2010sever quantum switch, closely mirroring previous \u201csuperposition of network primitives\u201d experiments. By tuning a single internal phase, the network exhibits a **sharp routing transition**: the preferred entangled link jumps abruptly from one pair of output nodes to another as the phase crosses a critical value.  This is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** of network connectivity.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n  \u2022 Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083 each probabilistically emit one pair in |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 onto modes (A\u2081,B\u2081), (A\u2082,B\u2082), (A\u2083,B\u2083).  \n  \u2022 Modes A\u2081,A\u2082,A\u2083 are the \u201cend\u201d nodes to be entangled; modes B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083 go into the router.\n\n2) Three-Port Router (Multiport Interferometer + Detectors)  \n  \u2022 A static 3\u00d73 multiport unitary U(\u03c6) acts on B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083.  U is built from beam splitters and phase shifters, with one tunable internal phase \u03c6.  \n  \u2022 At U\u2019s outputs we place three photon-number-resolving detectors D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083.  Exactly one click (one photon) among them heralds success.\n\n3) Heralding Rule (Entanglement Routing)  \n  \u2022 If D\u2081 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2082 & A\u2083 become projected into a Bell state.  \n  \u2022 If D\u2082 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2081 & A\u2083 become entangled.  \n  \u2022 If D\u2083 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2081 & A\u2082 become entangled.  \n  \u2022 No other detectors click (post-select on exactly one click).\n\n4) Measurement-Induced Routing Phase Transition  \n  \u2022 Define p_i(\u03c6) = probability that D_i clicks and heralds that routing.  \n  \u2022 As \u03c6 is varied from 0 to 2\u03c0, one finds **sharp crossover points** \u03c6_c where the dominant p_i(\u03c6) jumps from i to j.  \n  \u2022 At \u03c6_c the network topology effectively \u201cswitches phase\u201d\u2014which two end nodes share entanglement changes abruptly\u2014mirroring a percolation or network phase transition induced purely by the measurement basis (\u03c6).\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Design This  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optics only: beam splitters, phase shifters including one tunable \u03c6, and a 3\u00d73 interferometer.  \n  \u2022 Sources: 3 probabilistic Bell-pair emitters.  \n  \u2022 Detectors: 3 router detectors + 4 end analyzers (to verify Bell correlations on the heralded pair).  \n  \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid any direct source\u2192end link other than the intended B\u2081\u2192U, etc.  \n  \u2022 **Target** is the network supermap: for each \u03c6, the mapping from detected outcomes {D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083} to a Bell correlation between the correct pair of A-modes\u2014**no fixed multi-photon state**.\n\nGeneralizations:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-port routers on N Bell pairs: study measurement-induced critical phenomena in larger tensor-networks.  \n  \u2013 Use single-photon control qudits to coherently superpose two different router unitaries, creating indefinite-order routing phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus.     "output": "Thought:\nWe still need a genuinely new multi\u2010photon measurement primitive and a nontrivial tensor\u2010network phase transition\u2014one that Pytheus can implement with only static linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, single\u2010photon emitters, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  I propose to combine two different measurement \u201ctensors\u201d\u2014the standard Bell\u2010swap and a 3-photon GHZ\u2010projection\u2014in a short 1D chain of Bell pairs.  By post\u2010selecting on patterns of these two measurement types, one sees a **measurement\u2010induced network phase transition**: the number of GHZ\u2013vs. Bell measurements that click changes the end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement threshold in a nontrivial way.  This is a true tensor\u2010network effect (different local tensors at each bond) and not just state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus\u2010ready target that uses **two measurement primitives**\u2014Bell\u2010swap and 3-photon GHZ projection\u2014to induce a nontrivial percolation\u2010like phase transition in a short tensor network.  The goal is the **network transformation** (which end modes become entangled) as one varies the pattern of measurement clicks, not to generate a fixed state.\n\n1) Network layout  \n   \u2022 Five nodes A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D\u2013E, connected by four probabilistic Bell-pair sources S\u2081\u2026S\u2084 on bonds (A\u2013B),(B\u2013C),(C\u2013D),(D\u2013E).  \n   \u2022 Each bond \u2113 supports two possible measurement modules:\n     \u2013 M_swap,\u2113: a standard post-selected Bell-measurement on the two photons of that bond (50/50 BS + phase + 2 ancilla detectors).  \n     \u2013 M_GHZ,\u2113: a 3-photon GHZ analyzer acting on the two bond photons **plus** one ancilla photon from a local single-photon emitter.  It projects onto (|000\u27e9+|111\u27e9) (requires a small LO network + 2 ancilla detectors to herald success).  \n\n2) Static routing  \n   \u2022 For each \u2113=1\u20264, we include **both** M_swap,\u2113 and M_GHZ,\u2113 in the circuit.  Their outputs feed to separate ancilla detectors (total ancillas = 4\u00d72 for swaps + 4\u00d72 for GHZ = 16 ancilla detectors).  \n   \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid Bell-pair sources from linking non-neighboring nodes, and to prevent any source from feeding both swap and GHZ modules on the same bond except via intended paths.\n\n3) Post-selection & measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2022 Let k_swap = number of M_swap modules that click, k_GHZ = number of M_GHZ modules that click.  \n   \u2022 **Phase I** (pure-swap regime): If k_GHZ=0, end-to-end entanglement A\u2013E arises only if k_swap \u2265 3 (standard repeater threshold).  \n   \u2022 **Phase II** (mixed regime): If k_GHZ \u2265 1, then A\u2013E entangles already when k_swap + 2\u00b7k_GHZ \u2265 3.  In other words, each GHZ click \u201ccounts twice,\u201d lowering the entanglement threshold.  \n   \u2022 By selecting data runs according to (k_swap,k_GHZ), one sees a **sharp change** in the minimal total number of ancilla clicks needed for end-to-end entanglement\u2014the network\u2019s percolation threshold shifts discontinuously when k_GHZ crosses from 0 to 1.  \n\n4) Why this is novel  \n   \u2022 **Two distinct measurement tensors** at each bond (swap vs GHZ) create a nontrivial phase diagram in the bond-success space (k_swap,k_GHZ).  \n   \u2022 The threshold for global connectivity (A\u2013E entanglement) undergoes a genuine **measurement-induced phase transition** when GHZ projectors enter the network.  \n   \u2022 No previous Pytheus experiment has mixed Bell-swaps with GHZ\u2010projectors in the same chain to alter the percolation threshold.  \n   \u2022 It is a true tensor\u2010network metamorphosis (each bond can use one of two contraction tensors) and the emergent behaviour is independent of any particular target state.\n\n5) Pytheus implementation details  \n   \u2022 **Sources:** 4 probabilistic Bell-pair emitters + 4 single-photon emitters for GHZ modules  \n   \u2022 **Modules:** 4 M_swap (each uses 2 ancilla detectors), 4 M_GHZ (each uses 2 ancilla detectors)  \n   \u2022 **End analyzers:** 2 detectors at A, 2 at E to verify Bell correlations when entangled  \n   \u2022 **removed_connections:** forbid direct source\u2192nonadjacent mode links and multiplexing across modules  \n   \u2022 **Target transformation:** For each (k_swap,k_GHZ), maximize Bell-correlation fidelity at A\u2013E if the above thresholds are met, and suppress it otherwise.\n\nThis specification focuses on an **entanglement-percolation phase diagram** in a minimal tensor network with dual measurement primitives.  Feed it into Pytheus to find the beam-splitter angles, phase shifts, and detector assignments that realize both swap and GHZ modules on each bond, and that produce the predicted shift in connectivity threshold."
}
