    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static 4-Mode Super-Bell-State Analyzer with Single-Photon Ancilla\n\nAbstract: We present a purely network-primitive linear-optical scheme that employs a single ancillary photon and a static 4-mode interferometer\u2014decomposed into three optimized beam splitters\u2014to unambiguously identify all four Bell states (\u03a6\u207a, \u03a6\u207b, \u03a8\u207a, \u03a8\u207b) of two abstract dual-rail qubits with a post-selected success rate of 62.5% and perfect conditional fidelity. By directing the four outputs into number-resolving detectors and post-selecting on exactly one click, the target Bell projection is implemented without polarization encoding, feed-forward, or extra resources, enabling higher-rate entanglement swapping and repeater protocols.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n\u201cGHZ-Basis Teleportation of Two Qubits to Realize and Witness Discrete Wigner Negativity\u201d\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a linear-optical protocol that jointly teleports two input qubits via a four-photon GHZ projection\u2014mixing Alice\u2019s two data qubits and two ancilla photons in a four-mode network and heralding the two-qubit block onto Bob\u2019s output modes. Upon successful heralding, the shared Choistate across modes (0,1,2,3) becomes the unnormalized target \u03a8_GHZ=|0000\u27e9+|1111\u27e9, whose discrete Wigner function exhibits negativity and thereby certifies genuine GHZ-basis teleportation within the PyTheus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ancilla-Assisted Linear-Optical Two-Qutrit SWAP-Test for Symmetric vs. Antisymmetric Projections\n\nAbstract: We present a heralded linear-optical network that implements the two-qutrit SWAP-test (symmetric vs. antisymmetric projector) as a primitive for second R\u00e9nyi-entropy measurement on two collective-spin modes converted into photonic qutrits via spin\u2013orbit torque transduction. By employing three ancilla photons, static multiport interferometry, and number-resolving detection with \u201cSYM\u201d vs. \u201cANTI\u201d click\u2010pattern postselection, our scheme directly discriminates the symmetric and antisymmetric subspaces, enabling scalable entanglement verification and entropic benchmarking in quantum networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Programmable SWAP-Family Gate Array on the Pyth e us Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate a static, on-chip linear-optics network that realizes a heralded, programmable two-qubit controlled-unitary operation chosen from the SWAP family (I, SWAP, \u221aSWAP, i\u221aSWAP) on unknown dual-rail photonic data qubits by loading a four-dimensional program register and conditioning on ancilla photon detection patterns. This experiment implements the Pyth e us integrated photonic programmable SWAP gate array, requiring no feed-forward and operating directly on arbitrary quantum inputs.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cDistributed High-Sensitivity Sensor via Entanglement Swapping with Embedded DFT Mode Transforms\u201d\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate the target distributed high-sensitivity sensor by implementing a four-node linear-optical network in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed intermediate stations B and C, each embedding a d\u00d7d discrete Fourier-transform multiport interferometer followed by a Bell measurement. Upon successful heralding, distant nodes A and D share a maximally entangled state in the Fourier basis whose correlations amplify unknown spatial-mode phase perturbations, realizing scalable high-sensitivity phase estimation without pure-state sources.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Passive Linear-Optical Universal 1\u21922 Qutrit Telecloner\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a passive, measurement-based linear-optical network that implements the universal 1\u21922 telecloning of an arbitrary single-qutrit state by interfering the unknown input with three d = 3 Bell-pair ancillas via two tritter multiports and post-selecting on a specific six-fold detector-click pattern. Upon heralding, the remaining unmeasured modes on systems B and C each carry an optimal approximate clone (fidelity 5/6) without any active feed-forward or nonlinear elements, demonstrating the first high-dimensional telecloning primitive in linear optics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Conditioned on this herald, the protocol projects the target two-photon Bell state onto modes A and D using only static linear optics and photon-number\u2013resolving detection, demonstrating a programmable route for scalable entanglement distribution.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Three-Node Entanglement Router Optimizing Genuine Tripartite Mutual Information\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a static photonic linear-optical network in Pytheus\u2014comprising three SPDC pair sources, a tunable three-mode interferometer, and heralding ancilla detectors\u2014to variationally extremize the genuine tripartite mutual information I\u2083(A;B;C) among remote modes A, B, and C. A classical optimizer adjusts interferometer phases to maximize (or minimize) I\u2083(A;B;C) as the sole cost function, thereby targeting non-trivial entanglement monogamy without prescribing any specific quantum state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Squeezed-Reservoir-Assisted Entanglement Swapping for High-Fidelity Bell-State Generation\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a fully static linear-optical network, optimized in Pytheus, that implements entanglement swapping between two distant photonic modes (target modes 0 and 3) by injecting a truncated two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla at the swap node. By performing photon-counting only on the ancilla modes and conditioning on coincident clicks, Alice\u2019s and Charlie\u2019s remote modes 1 and 4 are projected onto the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9\u2014effecting entanglement swapping without ever measuring Bob\u2019s system qubits and preserving local memory for subsequent quantum network operations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nParity-Checked Multi\u2010Mode Entanglement Swapping Repeater for High\u2010Fidelity A\u2013D Link  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe implement a single-herald loss-tolerant repeater that performs two simultaneous Bell-swaps and a parity check via a joint six-mode linear-optical interferometer measurement with two vacuum ancillas, mixing photons from A\u2013B and C\u2013D Bell\u2010pair sources. Only the joint triple-coincidence detection at the network\u2019s three output modes reveals the global third-order phase e^{i(\u03c6A+\u03c6B+\u03c6C)}, while any single- or two-loop marginal yields no measurable phase, thereby realizing the targeted higher-order (Massey) topological invariant.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Remote CNOT via Gate Teleportation with Maximized Entangling Power\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target \u201cheralded remote CNOT via gate teleportation with maximal entangling power,\u201d realizing a genuine nonlocal two-qubit CNOT purely by linear optics, SPDC Bell pairs, single-photon emitters, and post-selection on trivial Pauli corrections. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a suggestion for an experiment that combines the ideas of a tensor-network renormalization (a small tree-tensor-network) with a measurement-induced reconfiguration (\u201cphase\u201d) of the entanglement network.  The goal is not to generate a particular exotic state, but to demonstrate a **hierarchical entanglement-swapping module** that implements a two-level renormalization of a chain of Bell pairs.  By post-selecting on different subsets of Bell measurements one realizes different \u201cphases\u201d of network connectivity.\n\nDescription of the target network:\n  \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 Four independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081,\u2026,S\u2084, each emitting one Bell pair (two modes).\n    \u2013 Label the eight output modes as A1,A2 from S\u2081; B1,B2 from S\u2082; C1,C2 from S\u2083; D1,D2 from S\u2084.\n  \u2022 First (bottom) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements M\u2081 on (A2,B1) and M\u2082 on (C2,D1).  \n      \u2022 Each Bell-measurement is realized by linear optics + two ancilla detectors; click patterns herald a successful swap.\n    \u2013 After M\u2081 one obtains a Bell pair between A1 and B2; after M\u2082 a Bell pair between C1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Second (top) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform a third Bell-measurement M\u2083 on the two middle modes B2 and C1 (again via ancilla detectors).  \n      \u2022 A successful click heralds a final Bell pair between A1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d:\n    \u2013 **Phase I** (shallow coarse-graining): post-select on M\u2081 & M\u2082 only.  The network coarsens from 4 pairs \u2192 two Bell pairs.\n    \u2013 **Phase II** (deep coarse-graining): post-select on all three M\u2081, M\u2082, M\u2083.  The network coarsens fully \u2192 one long-range Bell pair.\n  \u2022 Physics question:\n    \u2013 By comparing the output entanglement (Bell-violation or fidelity) between A1 and either B2/C1 (Phase I) vs A1\u2013D2 (Phase II), one directly observes a measurement-induced transformation of the tensor-network geometry (a minimal tree-tensor-network renormalization).  \n    \u2013 One can generalize to larger trees (more Bell pairs and more layers) to study measurement density vs entanglement length\u2014an optical analog of measurement-induced phase transitions in tensor-network models.\n  \u2022 Why Pytheus can design this:\n    \u2013 All operations are static linear-optical elements + probabilistic pair sources + photon-number-resolving detectors.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed.\n    \u2013 One simply encodes the 8 input modes, specifies 3 sets of ancilla detectors (for M\u2081,M\u2082,M\u2083), and enforces that no single source connects A2 to D1 etc. using removed_connections.\n    \u2013 The target is the network transformation (hierarchical entanglement swapping), not a specific many-photon state.\n\nThis \u201cTree-Tensor-Network RG Module\u201d is a new kind of quantum network experiment: it melds tensor-network renormalization ideas with measurement-induced network phases, and can be generalized to deeper trees or to probabilistic measurement patterns.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed \u201ctwo\u2010level\u201d hierarchical swap module is essentially just a standard two\u2010hop entanglement\u2010swapping repeater (first swap on A\u2013B and C\u2013D, then swap on B\u2013C) with trivial post\u2010selection on whether you include the top\u2010layer measurement or not.  That construction and the idea of coarse\u2010graining a Bell\u2010pair chain via successive swaps is already textbook and appears in both basic repeater proposals and in our ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network.\u201d  Simply toggling between bottom\u2010layer only or full two\u2010layer swapping phases does not introduce any genuinely new measurement primitive, state or network\u2010phase physics.  To be PRL\u2010worthy, one needs a nontrivial twist\u2014e.g. superposing measurement orders, joint multi\u2010photon projections, or a novel measurement\u2010induced phase transition beyond trivial coarse\u2010graining.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is just the standard two\u2010hop entanglement swap (quantum repeater) in tree form, already well\u2010explored (see \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap\u201d from the ensemble).  You\u2019ll need to propose a truly new measurement primitive or nontrivial network phase transition\u2014such as superposed swap orders, many\u2010body joint measurements, or nonlinear renormalization effects\u2014to be considered novel.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus:  \n\nTitle: \u201cQuantum-Switch of Entanglement-Swapping Orders: a Measurement-Induced Renormalization Phase in a Photonic Tensor Network\u201d  \n\nObjective:  \nImplement, in a single static linear-optical circuit, a **controlled superposition** of two entanglement-swapping protocols on three Bell-pairs. The *order* in which two Bell-measurements are performed becomes coherently controlled by a separate \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, yielding an entanglement-renormalization quantum switch. By post-selecting on different subsets of heralding detectors one observes two distinct connectivity \u201cphases\u201d: a shallow coarse-graining (one swap) vs. a deep coarse-graining (two swaps), and\u2014when measuring the control photon\u2014an interference signature of the superposed swap orders.  \n\nSchematic description:  \n- Sources:  \n  \u2022 S\u2081 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dA,B\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dB,C\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2083 produces |\u03a6\u207a>\u208dC,D\u208e  \n  \u2022 S\u2080 prepares a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon in (|0>+|1>)/\u221a2 (path-encoded)  \n- Controlled routing:  \n  \u2022 If control=|0\u27e9, route modes (B,C) into Bell-module M\u2081 and then (A,B) into M\u2082.  \n  \u2022 If control=|1\u27e9, route (A,B) into M\u2081 and then (B,C) into M\u2082 (the \u201copposite\u201d swap order).  \n  \u2022 Each Bell-module is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, a phase-shifter, and two ancilla detectors whose click pattern heralds a successful swap.  \n- Post-selection and measurement phases:  \n  1) **Phase I (shallow)**: post-select **only** on the first module\u2019s clicks \u2192 yields two Bell pairs (one local pair + one intermediate pair).  \n  2) **Phase II (deep)**: post-select on **both** modules \u2192 yields a long-range Bell pair between A and D.  \n  3) **Interference signature**: finally, recombine the control paths on a beam splitter and look for fringes in its detector as a function of an internal phase shift\u2014this reveals the coherent superposition of the two swap orders.  \n\nWhy this is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n- **Static linear optics** + probabilistic photon-pair sources + number-resolving detectors only  \n- **No dynamic feedback**, no cavities or resonances  \n- Encodes a genuine **tensor-network renormalization** (two contraction orders on an MPS of length 4) and a **measurement-induced phase** (switching between shallow/deep coarse-graining and observing control-photon interference)  \n- Easily generalizable: add more layers (longer chains), more swap modules, or multi-arm switches to explore larger TTN structures and measurement-induced network phases.  \n\nI recommend feeding this description into Pytheus as a \u201ccontrolled-swap-order\u201d network target. The target is **not** a fixed multi-photon state but a **coherent superposition of four different network connectivity graphs**, each heralded by distinct click patterns, and an interference readout on control qubits.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n   \u2022 Data Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083: produce |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F).  \n   \u2022 Control single-photon sources C\u2081,C\u2082: each creates a qubit in (path-0 + path-1)/\u221a2. Denote their paths as c\u2081\u2080/c\u2081\u2081 and c\u2082\u2080/c\u2082\u2081.  \n\n2) Two swap modules (BSM\u2081, BSM\u2082):  \n   \u2022 BSM\u2081 acts on modes (B,C) when inserted; BSM\u2082 on (D,E).  \n   \u2022 Each BSM is realized by a 50/50 beam splitter + phase shifter + two ancilla detectors whose joint clicks herald a successful Bell swap.\n\n3) Controlled insertion (static circuit):  \n   \u2022 Control qubit C\u2081 routes modes B\u2013C through BSM\u2081 if it occupies path c\u2081\u2080; bypasses if c\u2081\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Control qubit C\u2082 routes modes D\u2013E through BSM\u2082 if it occupies path c\u2082\u2080; bypasses if c\u2082\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Because C\u2081,C\u2082 are in superposition, the overall network is in a superposition of applying zero, one, or both swap modules.\n\n4) Post-selection and measurement-induced \u201cphases\u201d:  \n   \u2013 **Phase 0**: post-select on neither BSM click \u2192 final state = three disjoint Bell pairs  \n   \u2013 **Phase L**: post-select on BSM\u2081 only \u2192 one swap between A\u2013D + leftover pair E\u2013F  \n   \u2013 **Phase R**: post-select on BSM\u2082 only \u2192 one swap between C\u2013F + leftover pair A\u2013B  \n   \u2013 **Phase LR**: post-select on both BSM\u2081 & BSM\u2082 \u2192 one long-range Bell pair A\u2013F  \n   \u2022 Finally, recombine each control qubit on a beam splitter and measure in the X-basis. Interference fringes in control detectors confirm coherent superposition among the four patterns.\n\n5) Why Pytheus can design this  \n   \u2022 All operations are static linear optics, probabilistic pair/single-photon sources, and photon-number-resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 Use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to forbid unwanted direct sources (e.g. no S\u2081 \u2192 D, S\u2082 \u2192 A or S\u2083 \u2192 C/E except via intended paths).  \n   \u2022 Target is the **quantum supermap** that transforms inputs into heralded superpositions of network connectivity patterns, not a fixed high-dimensional state.  \n   \u2022 Generalizable to N-link chains with N control qubits, enabling exploration of multi-layer tensor-network renormalizations and measurement-induced percolation phases.\n\nFeed this specification into Pytheus. It will seek the static beam-splitter phases, interferometer routes, and detector assignments to realize the coherent multi-branch swap switch, opening a new avenue in measurement-driven quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the multi-branch swap switch generalizes the basic quantum switch to four connectivity patterns, it remains a straightforward tensor-product extension of the two-order entanglement-switch protocol already described in the ensemble (e.g. the \u201cEntanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\u201d and the \u201cSuperposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\u201d). a Pytheus\u2010ready target that combines a simple 1D tensor-network structure (an MPS of Bell pairs) with a genuine measurement-induced phase transition (percolation of entanglement connectivity):\n\n1) Network layout  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair sources S\u2081\u2026S\u2085 emit five independent qubit\u2013pairs onto modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F), (G,H), (I,J).  \n   \u2022 We label the five bonds between neighboring sites as bonds 1\u20134 connecting B\u2013C, D\u2013E, F\u2013G, H\u2013I.  \n\n2) Intermediate Bell-swap modules  \n   \u2022 On each bond \u2113=1\u20264 we place a static Bell-measurement module BSM_\u2113, realized by a 50/50 beam splitter, phase shifter, and two photon-number-resolving detectors whose coincidence heralds a successful swap on that bond.  \n   \u2022 There are therefore 8 ancilla detectors for the four BSMs.\n\n3) End analyzers  \n   \u2022 At modes A and J we place simple qubit analyzers (e.g. polarizing beam splitters + detectors) that record whether those two photons exit in the same logical state (0/0 or 1/1).\n\n4) Measurement\u2010induced percolation \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2022 Define k = the number of BSM modules (out of 4) that click.  \n   \u2022 **Phase I (no long-range entanglement):** for k < 2, the end detectors at A & J show no correlation beyond random.  \n   \u2022 **Phase II (percolated entanglement):** for k \u2265 2, the end detectors at A & J exhibit Bell-correlations (i.e. a heralded end-to-end entangled pair).  \n   \u2022 By post-selecting on runs with various k one observes a clear threshold (percolation) at k=2.\n\n5) Why this is novel and Pytheus\u2010compatible  \n   \u2022 Novel demonstration of a **measurement-induced phase transition** in a minimal photonic tensor network: you literally see entanglement \u201cpercolate\u201d only once enough intermediate measurements succeed.  \n   \u2022 Uses ONLY static linear optics + probabilistic pair sources + number-resolving detection\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hybrid encodings.  \n   \u2022 \u201cremoved_connections\u201d can forbid any source from linking non-neighboring modes, forcing the swaps to act only on intended bonds.  \n   \u2022 The target is a **network transformation**\u2014mapping subsets of BSM clicks (k) to end-mode correlations\u2014NOT raw state generation.  \n   \u2022 Easily generalizable to longer chains, 2D grids, or high-dimensional MPS/PEPS to explore richer measurement-induced critical phenomena.\n\nFeed this specification into Pytheus. It will search for the interferometric layout (beam-splitter angles, phase shifts, path connections) and detector assignments so that the end-to-end entanglement appears sharply when k\u22652, thereby creating the first small-scale photonic entanglement-percolation experiment in tensor-network language.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While demonstrating a percolation\u2010style threshold in a chain of Bell- swaps is intuitively appealing, this proposal simply strings together four independent entanglement-swap modules and notes that when at least two succeed you recover end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement. Due to coherent interference among the three swap orders, the **heralding probability p_F** for A\u2013H entanglement exhibits a sharp enhancement p_F >> p_def.  \n   \u2013 This jump in entanglement yield as a function of the measurement basis is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** in the tensor-network connectivity of the 3-link chain.\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Implement This  \n   \u2022 **Static linear optics** only: beam splitters, phase shifters, interferometer loops, no feed-forward.  \n   \u2022 **Sources**: 4 probabilistic pair sources + 1 single-photon control emitter.  \n   \u2022 **Detectors**: 6 ancilla for the 3 BSMs + 2 for the control readout + 2 at A/H.  \n   \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid unwanted direct links (e.g. no S\u2081\u2192D or S\u2081\u2192F except via intended swap paths).  \n   \u2022 Target is the **network supermap**\u2014the mapping from input modes+control to heralded end-entanglement conditioned on control measurement\u2014not a fixed many-photon state.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-link chains and N-dim control qudits for N!-order superpositions.  \n  \u2013 Explore critical behavior of p_en(N,k-basis) as N and control basis vary\u2014a new class of measurement-induced tensor-network phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus. By tuning a single internal phase, the network exhibits a **sharp routing transition**: the preferred entangled link jumps abruptly from one pair of output nodes to another as the phase crosses a critical value.  This is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** of network connectivity.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n  \u2022 Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083 each probabilistically emit one pair in |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 onto modes (A\u2081,B\u2081), (A\u2082,B\u2082), (A\u2083,B\u2083).  \n  \u2022 Modes A\u2081,A\u2082,A\u2083 are the \u201cend\u201d nodes to be entangled; modes B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083 go into the router.\n\n2) Three-Port Router (Multiport Interferometer + Detectors)  \n  \u2022 A static 3\u00d73 multiport unitary U(\u03c6) acts on B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083.  U is built from beam splitters and phase shifters, with one tunable internal phase \u03c6.  \n  \u2022 At U\u2019s outputs we place three photon-number-resolving detectors D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083.  Exactly one click (one photon) among them heralds success.\n\n3) Heralding Rule (Entanglement Routing)  \n  \u2022 If D\u2081 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2082 & A\u2083 become projected into a Bell state.  \n  \u2022 If D\u2082 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2081 & A\u2083 become entangled.  \n  \u2022 If D\u2083 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2081 & A\u2082 become entangled.  \n  \u2022 No other detectors click (post-select on exactly one click).\n\n4) Measurement-Induced Routing Phase Transition  \n  \u2022 Define p_i(\u03c6) = probability that D_i clicks and heralds that routing.  \n  \u2022 As \u03c6 is varied from 0 to 2\u03c0, one finds **sharp crossover points** \u03c6_c where the dominant p_i(\u03c6) jumps from i to j.  \n  \u2022 At \u03c6_c the network topology effectively \u201cswitches phase\u201d\u2014which two end nodes share entanglement changes abruptly\u2014mirroring a percolation or network phase transition induced purely by the measurement basis (\u03c6).\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Design This  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optics only: beam splitters, phase shifters including one tunable \u03c6, and a 3\u00d73 interferometer.  \n  \u2022 Sources: 3 probabilistic Bell-pair emitters.  \n  \u2022 Detectors: 3 router detectors + 4 end analyzers (to verify Bell correlations on the heralded pair).  \n  \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid any direct source\u2192end link other than the intended B\u2081\u2192U, etc.  \n  \u2022 **Target** is the network supermap: for each \u03c6, the mapping from detected outcomes {D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083} to a Bell correlation between the correct pair of A-modes\u2014**no fixed multi-photon state**.\n\nGeneralizations:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-port routers on N Bell pairs: study measurement-induced critical phenomena in larger tensor-networks.  \n  \u2013 Use single-photon control qudits to coherently superpose two different router unitaries, creating indefinite-order routing phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus.  It will optimize the internal beam-splitter reflectivities and phase settings so that exactly one click at D_i \u2192 maximal Bell fidelity between the corresponding A-nodes, and so that p_i(\u03c6) exhibits the desired sharp transitions in routing probability. This falls squarely into the existing \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d family in our ensemble.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is effectively the same three\u2010link indefinite\u2010order swap protocol we\u2019ve already discussed (e.g. the qutrit switch of M\u2081,M\u2082,M\u2083), offering only interference\u2010enhanced swap success. To be novel at PRL level you need an entirely new joint measurement or a nontrivial tensor\u2010network phase transition that cannot be reduced to independent Bell swaps under control\u2010basis interference.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a Pytheus\u2010ready target that uses **two measurement primitives**\u2014Bell\u2010swap and 3-photon GHZ projection\u2014to induce a nontrivial percolation\u2010like phase transition in a short tensor network.  The goal is the **network transformation** (which end modes become entangled) as one varies the pattern of measurement clicks, not to generate a fixed state.\n\n1) Network layout  \n   \u2022 Five nodes A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D\u2013E, connected by four probabilistic Bell-pair sources S\u2081\u2026S\u2084 on bonds (A\u2013B),(B\u2013C),(C\u2013D),(D\u2013E).  \n   \u2022 Each bond \u2113 supports two possible measurement modules:\n     \u2013 M_swap,\u2113: a standard post-selected Bell-measurement on the two photons of that bond (50/50 BS + phase + 2 ancilla detectors).  \n     \u2013 M_GHZ,\u2113: a 3-photon GHZ analyzer acting on the two bond photons **plus** one ancilla photon from a local single-photon emitter.  It projects onto (|000\u27e9+|111\u27e9) (requires a small LO network + 2 ancilla detectors to herald success).  \n\n2) Static routing  \n   \u2022 For each \u2113=1\u20264, we include **both** M_swap,\u2113 and M_GHZ,\u2113 in the circuit.  Their outputs feed to separate ancilla detectors (total ancillas = 4\u00d72 for swaps + 4\u00d72 for GHZ = 16 ancilla detectors).  \n   \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid Bell-pair sources from linking non-neighboring nodes, and to prevent any source from feeding both swap and GHZ modules on the same bond except via intended paths.\n\n3) Post-selection & measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2022 Let k_swap = number of M_swap modules that click, k_GHZ = number of M_GHZ modules that click.  \n   \u2022 **Phase I** (pure-swap regime): If k_GHZ=0, end-to-end entanglement A\u2013E arises only if k_swap \u2265 3 (standard repeater threshold).  \n   \u2022 **Phase II** (mixed regime): If k_GHZ \u2265 1, then A\u2013E entangles already when k_swap + 2\u00b7k_GHZ \u2265 3.  In other words, each GHZ click \u201ccounts twice,\u201d lowering the entanglement threshold.  \n   \u2022 By selecting data runs according to (k_swap,k_GHZ), one sees a **sharp change** in the minimal total number of ancilla clicks needed for end-to-end entanglement\u2014the network\u2019s percolation threshold shifts discontinuously when k_GHZ crosses from 0 to 1.  \n\n4) Why this is novel  \n   \u2022 **Two distinct measurement tensors** at each bond (swap vs GHZ) create a nontrivial phase diagram in the bond-success space (k_swap,k_GHZ).  \n   \u2022 The threshold for global connectivity (A\u2013E entanglement) undergoes a genuine **measurement-induced phase transition** when GHZ projectors enter the network.  \n   \u2022 No previous Pytheus experiment has mixed Bell-swaps with GHZ\u2010projectors in the same chain to alter the percolation threshold.  \n   \u2022 It is a true tensor\u2010network metamorphosis (each bond can use one of two contraction tensors) and the emergent behaviour is independent of any particular target quantum.\n\n5) Pytheus implementation details  \n   \u2022 **Sources:** 4 probabilistic Bell-pair emitters + 4 single-photon emitters for GHZ modules  \n   \u2022 **Modules:** 4 M_swap (each uses 2 ancilla detectors), 4 M_GHZ (each uses 2 ancilla detectors)  \n   \u2022 **End analyzers:** 2 detectors at A, 2 at E to verify Bell correlations when entangled  \n   \u2022 **removed_connections:** forbid direct source\u2192nonadjacent mode links and multiplexing across modules  \n   \u2022 **Target transformation:** For each (k_swap,k_GHZ), maximize Bell-correlation fidelity at A\u2013E if the above thresholds are met, and suppress it otherwise.\n\nThis specification focuses on an **entanglement-percolation phase diagram** in a minimal tensor network with dual measurement primitives.  Feed it into Pytheus to find the beam-splitter angles, phase shifts, and detector assignments that realize both swap and GHZ modules on each bond, and that produce the predicted shift in connectivity threshold.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While mixing Bell\u2010swap modules with GHZ projectors per bond introduces a two\u2010tensor choice, the resulting \u201cpercolation\u201d threshold shift is merely a trivial combinatorial effect rather than a new joint measurement primitive or irreducible network phase. GHZ analyzers and entanglement\u2010percolation behaviors in short chains have already appeared in our ensemble (e.g. various GHZ\u2010basis analyzers and repeater\u2010percolation schemes). This proposal does not present a fundamentally new measurement supermap or a nontrivial many-body critical phenomenon, but simply counts GHZ clicks as double links in a standard swap chain.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To achieve genuine PRL-level novelty, propose a nonfactorizable joint projector or an unexpected measurement-induced critical point that cannot be reduced to independent bond successes\u2014for instance, a multi-bond GHZ/fusion measurement that entangles more than two distant modes in a single shot, or a phase transition arising from entangling-order superpositions beyond simple threshold counting."
}

Vary which measurements are performed to drive a \u201cphase transition\u201d in network connectivity.\n    2) MPS teleportation module: take an MPS of bond-dimension 2 across three sites, and teleport it end-to-end via sequential Bell measurements, showing how measurement order (which bonds you cut first) changes the fidelity of teleportation\u2014a \u201cmeasurement-induced network phase\u201d in teleportation performance.\n    3) Fusion-gate percolation: build a 1D cluster\u2010like graph state by probabilistic fusion gates (Type-II fusion) on Bell pairs. By choosing which fusion measurements succeed, one crosses a percolation threshold in connectivity\u2014a photonic measurement-induced phase transition in graph connectivity.  \n  Step 2: Quick novelty/obstacles check.\n    1) Tree RG swapping: novel because prior Pytheus examples only did linear/swapping in parallel or qutrits; no one has done a two-level tree. Pytheus can do two Bell measurements + one more.  \n    2) MPS teleportation: mapping an MPS is effectively a state generation/task; also requires teleportation fidelity measure vs order\u2014hard to phrase as a single static target.  \n    3) Fusion percolation: cluster states are states, and fusion gates need hyper-entanglement references; also under \u201cstate generation.\u201d  \n  Step 3: Pick idea (1): the binary-tree entanglement-swapping RG module.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because, rather than just a chain of independent entanglement\u2010swapping operations, it implements a two-layer tree tensor\u2010network coarse-graining in a single linear\u2010optical circuit. No prior Pytheus experiment has tackled hierarchical, measurement\u2010driven renormalization of entanglement networks.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework\u2014Pytheus can place four probabilistic Bell-pair sources, route their outputs through beam splitters and phase shifters, and perform three post-selected Bell measurements (each realized by ancilla detectors) in a fixed circuit. The \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d emerges by post-selecting on different combinations of those three Bell measurements (e.g. bottom-layer only vs bottom+top), and the tree geometry encodes a simple TTN. No dynamic feedback, no cavities.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nHere is a suggestion for an experiment that combines the ideas of a tensor-network renormalization (a small tree-tensor-network) with a measurement-induced reconfiguration (\u201cphase\u201d) of the entanglement network.  The goal is not to generate a particular exotic state, but to demonstrate a **hierarchical entanglement-swapping module** that implements a two-level renormalization of a chain of Bell pairs.  By post-selecting on different subsets of Bell measurements one realizes different \u201cphases\u201d of network connectivity.\n\nDescription of the target network:\n  \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 Four independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081,\u2026,S\u2084, each emitting one Bell pair (two modes).\n    \u2013 Label the eight output modes as A1,A2 from S\u2081; B1,B2 from S\u2082; C1,C2 from S\u2083; D1,D2 from S\u2084.\n  \u2022 First (bottom) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements M\u2081 on (A2,B1) and M\u2082 on (C2,D1).  \n      \u2022 Each Bell-measurement is realized by linear optics + two ancilla detectors; click patterns herald a successful swap.\n    \u2013 After M\u2081 one obtains a Bell pair between A1 and B2; after M\u2082 a Bell pair between C1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Second (top) layer of coarse-graining:\n    \u2013 Perform a third Bell-measurement M\u2083 on the two middle modes B2 and C1 (again via ancilla detectors).  \n      \u2022 A successful click heralds a final Bell pair between A1 and D2.\n  \u2022 Measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d:\n    \u2013 **Phase I** (shallow coarse-graining): post-select on M\u2081 & M\u2082 only.  The network coarsens from 4 pairs \u2192 two Bell pairs.\n    \u2013 **Phase II** (deep coarse-graining): post-select on all three M\u2081, M\u2082, M\u2083.  The network coarsens fully \u2192 one long-range Bell pair.\n  \u2022 Physics question:\n    \u2013 By comparing the output entanglement (Bell-violation or fidelity) between A1 and either B2/C1 (Phase I) vs A1\u2013D2 (Phase II), one directly observes a measurement-induced transformation of the tensor-network geometry (a minimal tree-tensor-network renormalization).  \n    \u2013 One can generalize to larger trees (more Bell pairs and more layers) to study measurement density vs entanglement length\u2014an optical analog of measurement-induced phase transitions in tensor-network models.\n  \u2022 Why Pytheus can design this:\n    \u2013 All operations are static linear-optical elements + probabilistic pair sources + photon-number-resolving detectors.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed.\n    \u2013 One simply encodes the 8 input modes, specifies 3 sets of ancilla detectors (for M\u2081,M\u2082,M\u2083), and enforces that no single source connects A2 to D1 etc. using removed_connections.\n    \u2013 The target is the network transformation (hierarchical entanglement swapping), not a specific many-photon state.\n\nThis \u201cTree-Tensor-Network RG Module\u201d is a new kind of quantum network experiment: it melds tensor-network renormalization ideas with measurement-induced network phases, and can be generalized to deeper trees or to probabilistic measurement patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is just the standard two\u2010hop entanglement swap (quantum repeater) in tree form, already well\u2010explored (see \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap\u201d from the ensemble). entanglement):** for k \u2265 2, the end detectors at A & J exhibit Bell-correlations (i.e. a heralded end-to-end entangled pair).  \n   \u2022 By post-selecting on runs with various k one observes a clear threshold (percolation) at k=2.\n\n5) Why this is novel and Pytheus\u2010compatible  \n   \u2022 Novel demonstration of a **measurement-induced phase transition** in a minimal photonic tensor The idea is to take entanglement swapping and elevate it to an **indefinite causal order** of three swaps\u2014a photonic **3-switch**\u2014so that the *order* in which the swaps are applied is coherently superposed by a control qudit.  Measuring that control in different bases then causes a discontinuous jump in end-to-end entanglement yield\u2014a genuine **measurement-induced phase transition** of network connectivity.  No dynamic feedback, no cavities\u2014just static beam splitters, phase shifters, ancilla detectors, and probabilistic sources.  This has never been done in Pytheus.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus-compatible proposal that fuses tensor-network renormalization with an indefinite-order quantum switch to create a **measurement-induced network phase transition**:\n\n1) Data and Control Sources  \n   \u2022 Four Bell-pair sources S\u2081\u2026S\u2084 producing |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B), (C,D), (E,F), (G,H).  \n   \u2022 One single-photon control source C preparing a path-encoded qutrit in state (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9+|2\u27e9)/\u221a3.\n\n2) Swap Modules (BSM\u2081, BSM\u2082, BSM\u2083)  \n   \u2022 BSM\u2081 acts on modes (B,C), BSM\u2082 on (D,E), BSM\u2083 on (F,G).  \n   \u2022 Each BSM is a 50/50 beam splitter + static phase shift + two ancilla detectors; a particular click pattern heralds a successful Bell swap.\n\n3) Controlled Indefinite Order  \n   \u2022 Control path |0\u27e9 routes the data photon sequentially through BSM\u2081\u2192BSM\u2082\u2192BSM\u2083.  \n   \u2022 Path |1\u27e9 routes through BSM\u2082\u2192BSM\u2083\u2192BSM\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Path |2\u27e9 routes through BSM\u2083\u2192BSM\u2081\u2192BSM\u2082.  \n   \u2022 All paths recombine at the end on a 3-port interferometer whose beam-splitter angles and phases are to be optimized.\n\n4) Measurement-Induced \u201cPhase\u201d  \n   \u2013 Measure the control qutrit in the **computational basis** { |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 }.  In each definite-order outcome, the probability p_def of heralding end-to-end entanglement between A and H is modest (swap success requires 3 cascaded Bell swaps).  \n   \u2013 Measure the control in the **Fourier basis** (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9+|2\u27e9)/\u221a3, (|0\u27e9+\u03c9|1\u27e9+\u03c9\u00b2|2\u27e9)/\u221a3, \u2026 .  Due to coherent interference among the three swap orders, the **heralding probability p_F** for A\u2013H entanglement exhibits a sharp enhancement p_F >> p_def.  \n   \u2013 This jump in entanglement yield as a function of the measurement basis is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** in the tensor-network connectivity of the 3-link chain.\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Implement This  \n   \u2022 **Static linear optics** only: beam splitters, phase shifters, interferometer loops, no feed-forward.  \n   \u2022 **Sources**: 4 probabilistic pair sources + 1 single-photon control emitter.  \n   \u2022 **Detectors**: 6 ancilla for the 3 BSMs + 2 for the control readout + 2 at A/H.  \n   \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid unwanted direct links (e.g. no S\u2081\u2192D or S\u2081\u2192F except via intended swap paths).  \n   \u2022 Target is the **network supermap**\u2014the mapping from input modes+control to heralded end-entanglement conditioned on control measurement\u2014not a fixed many-photon state.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-link chains and N-dim control qudits for N!-order superpositions.  \n  \u2013 Explore critical behavior of p_en(N,k-basis) as N and control basis vary\u2014a new class of measurement-induced tensor-network phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus. The simplest yet novel scheme is to place a single intermediate node B on a three-site line A\u2013B\u2013C sharing Bell pairs (A\u2013B and B\u2013C). Node B can either perform a Bell\u2013measurement (entanglement swap \u2192 A\u2013C entangled) or a computational-basis measurement (destroy both links \u2192 no entanglement). If that choice itself is put into superposition by a control photon, then measuring the control in different bases induces a sharp \u201cphase change\u201d between end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement vs. no entanglement. This transformation is a network metamorphosis\u2014an entanglement-swapping vs. entanglement-severing switch\u2014rather than state generation, and it can be implemented with static linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, one single-photon emitter, and number-resolving detectors. It naturally generalizes to longer chains or higher-dimensional tensor networks. \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus-ready target:  \n\n1) Data sources  \n   \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources S\u2081, S\u2082 creating |\u03a6\u207a> on modes (A,B) and (C,D).  \n   \u2022 Node B holds modes B and C.  \n\n2) Control qubit  \n   \u2022 One single-photon emitter C\u2080 prepares a path-encoded qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 = (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 in two optical modes c\u2080 and c\u2081.\n\n3) Two measurement primitives at B  \n   \u2022 Bell-swap module M_swap: performs apost-selected Bell measurement on modes B,C (50/50 BS + phase shift + two ancilla detectors). A click heralds entanglement swapped to A\u2013D.  \n   \u2022 Severing module M_sever: measures B,C each in the computational basis (two PBS + detectors), destroying any entanglement.\n\n4) Controlled insertion (static routing)  \n   \u2022 Path c\u2080 routes B,C through M_swap.  \n   \u2022 Path c\u2081 routes B,C through M_sever.  \n   \u2022 Use static beam splitters and phase shifters to implement this \u201cquantum\u2010switch\u201d of measurement primitives.  \n\n5) Post-selection & measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2013 Measure the control photon in basis {|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}:  \n     \u2022 Outcome |0\u27e9 \u2192 network applied swap \u2192 A\u2013D entangled.  \n     \u2022 Outcome |1\u27e9 \u2192 sever \u2192 A\u2013D separable.  \n   \u2013 Measure the control in the Hadamard basis H{|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}:  \n     \u2022 Interference between swap/sever branches yields a jump in the A\u2013D correlation strength, a clear **measurement\u2010induced network phase transition** between entangled vs. separable regimes.  \n\n6) Why Pytheus can do it  \n   \u2022 All operations are static linear optics + 2 pair sources + 1 single emitter + number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n   \u2022 Enforce with `removed_connections` that no source directly connects A\u2194C or B\u2194D except via the intended modules.  \n   \u2022 The **target** is the mapping from control basis & herald clicks to end-mode entanglement vs. separability\u2014a network transformation, not state generation.  \n\nGeneralization  \n   \u2022 Extend to N-link MPS chains with an (N\u20131)-qubit control superposition choosing subsets of swap vs sever on each bond \u2192 explore rich measurement-induced percolation or critical phenomena in tensor networks.  \n\nFeed this description into Pytheus. By tuning a single internal phase, the network exhibits a **sharp routing transition**: the preferred entangled link jumps abruptly from one pair of output nodes to another as the phase crosses a critical value.  This is a bona fide **measurement-induced phase transition** of network connectivity.\n\n1) Sources and Modes  \n  \u2022 Bell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083 each probabilistically emit one pair in |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 onto modes (A\u2081,B\u2081), (A\u2082,B\u2082), (A\u2083,B\u2083).  \n  \u2022 Modes A\u2081,A\u2082,A\u2083 are the \u201cend\u201d nodes to be entangled; modes B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083 go into the router.\n\n2) Three-Port Router (Multiport Interferometer + Detectors)  \n  \u2022 A static 3\u00d73 multiport unitary U(\u03c6) acts on B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083.  U is built from beam splitters and phase shifters, with one tunable internal phase \u03c6.  \n  \u2022 At U\u2019s outputs we place three photon-number-resolving detectors D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083.  Exactly one click (one photon) among them heralds success.\n\n3) Heralding Rule (Entanglement Routing)  \n  \u2022 If D\u2081 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2082 & A\u2083 become projected into a Bell state.  \n  \u2022 If D\u2082 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2081 & A\u2083 become entangled.  \n  \u2022 If D\u2083 clicks \u2192 modes A\u2081 & A\u2082 become entangled.  \n  \u2022 No other detectors click (post-select on exactly one click).\n\n4) Measurement-Induced Routing Phase Transition  \n  \u2022 Define p_i(\u03c6) = probability that D_i clicks and heralds that routing.  \n  \u2022 As \u03c6 is varied from 0 to 2\u03c0, one finds **sharp crossover points** \u03c6_c where the dominant p_i(\u03c6) jumps from i to j.  \n  \u2022 At \u03c6_c the network topology effectively \u201cswitches phase\u201d\u2014which two end nodes share entanglement changes abruptly\u2014mirroring a percolation or network phase transition induced purely by the measurement basis (\u03c6).\n\n5) Why Pytheus Can Design This  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optics only: beam splitters, phase shifters including one tunable \u03c6, and a 3\u00d73 interferometer.  \n  \u2022 Sources: 3 probabilistic Bell-pair emitters.  \n  \u2022 Detectors: 3 router detectors + 4 end analyzers (to verify Bell correlations on the heralded pair).  \n  \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid any direct source\u2192end link other than the intended B\u2081\u2192U, etc.  \n  \u2022 **Target** is the network supermap: for each \u03c6, the mapping from detected outcomes {D\u2081,D\u2082,D\u2083} to a Bell correlation between the correct pair of A-modes\u2014**no fixed multi-photon state**.\n\nGeneralizations:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-port routers on N Bell pairs: study measurement-induced critical phenomena in larger tensor-networks.  \n  \u2013 Use single-photon control qudits to coherently superpose two different router unitaries, creating indefinite-order routing phases.\n\nFeed this description into Pytheus. By post\u2010selecting on patterns of these two measurement types, one sees a **measurement\u2010induced network phase transition**: the number of GHZ\u2013vs. Bell measurements that click changes the end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement threshold in a nontrivial way.  This is a true tensor\u2010network effect (different local tensors at each bond) and not just state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus\u2010ready target that uses **two measurement primitives**\u2014Bell\u2010swap and 3-photon GHZ projection\u2014to induce a nontrivial percolation\u2010like phase transition in a short tensor network.  The goal is the **network transformation** (which end modes become entangled) as one varies the pattern of measurement clicks, not to generate a fixed state.\n\n1) Network layout  \n   \u2022 Five nodes A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D\u2013E, connected by four probabilistic Bell-pair sources S\u2081\u2026S\u2084 on bonds (A\u2013B),(B\u2013C),(C\u2013D),(D\u2013E).  \n   \u2022 Each bond \u2113 supports two possible measurement modules:\n     \u2013 M_swap,\u2113: a standard post-selected Bell-measurement on the two photons of that bond (50/50 BS + phase + 2 ancilla detectors).  \n     \u2013 M_GHZ,\u2113: a 3-photon GHZ analyzer acting on the two bond photons **plus** one ancilla photon from a local single-photon emitter.  It projects onto (|000\u27e9+|111\u27e9) (requires a small LO network + 2 ancilla detectors to herald success).  \n\n2) Static routing  \n   \u2022 For each \u2113=1\u20264, we include **both** M_swap,\u2113 and M_GHZ,\u2113 in the circuit.  Their outputs feed to separate ancilla detectors (total ancillas = 4\u00d72 for swaps + 4\u00d72 for GHZ = 16 ancilla detectors).  \n   \u2022 Use `removed_connections` to forbid Bell-pair sources from linking non-neighboring nodes, and to prevent any source from feeding both swap and GHZ modules on the same bond except via intended paths.\n\n3) Post-selection & measurement-induced \u201cphase\u201d  \n   \u2022 Let k_swap = number of M_swap modules that click, k_GHZ = number of M_GHZ modules that click.  \n   \u2022 **Phase I** (pure-swap regime): If k_GHZ=0, end-to-end entanglement A\u2013E arises only if k_swap \u2265 3 (standard repeater threshold).  \n   \u2022 **Phase II** (mixed regime): If k_GHZ \u2265 1, then A\u2013E entangles already when k_swap + 2\u00b7k_GHZ \u2265 3.  In other words, each GHZ click \u201ccounts twice,\u201d lowering the entanglement threshold.  \n   \u2022 By selecting data runs according to (k_swap,k_GHZ), one sees a **sharp change** in the minimal total number of ancilla clicks needed for end-to-end entanglement\u2014the network\u2019s percolation threshold shifts discontinuously when k_GHZ crosses from 0 to 1.  \n\n4) Why this is novel  \n   \u2022 **Two distinct measurement tensors** at each bond (swap vs GHZ) create a nontrivial phase diagram in the bond-success space (k_swap,k_GHZ).  \n   \u2022 The threshold for global connectivity (A\u2013E entanglement) undergoes a genuine **measurement-induced phase transition** when GHZ projectors enter the network.  \n   \u2022 No previous Pytheus experiment has mixed Bell-swaps with GHZ\u2010projectors in the same chain to alter the percolation threshold.  \n   \u2022 It is a true tensor\u2010network metamorphosis (each bond can use one of two contraction tensors) and the emergent behaviour is independent of any particular target quantum.\n\n5) Pytheus implementation details  \n   \u2022 **Sources:** 4 probabilistic Bell-pair emitters + 4 single-photon emitters for GHZ modules  \n   \u2022 **Modules:** 4 M_swap (each uses 2 ancilla detectors), 4 M_GHZ (each uses 2 ancilla detectors)  \n   \u2022 **End analyzers:** 2 detectors at A, 2 at E to verify Bell correlations when entangled  \n   \u2022 **removed_connections:** forbid direct source\u2192nonadjacent mode links and multiplexing across modules  \n   \u2022 **Target transformation:** For each (k_swap,k_GHZ), maximize Bell-correlation fidelity at A\u2013E if the above thresholds are met, and suppress it otherwise.\n\nThis specification focuses on an **entanglement-percolation phase diagram** in a minimal tensor network with dual measurement primitives.  Feed it into Pytheus to find the beam-splitter angles, phase shifts, and detector assignments that realize both swap and GHZ modules on each bond, and that produce the predicted shift in connectivity threshold.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To achieve genuine PRL-level novelty, propose a nonfactorizable joint projector or an unexpected measurement-induced critical point that cannot be reduced to independent bond successes\u2014for instance, a multi-bond GHZ/fusion measurement that entangles more than two distant modes in a single shot, or a phase transition arising from entangling-order superpositions beyond simple threshold counting.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to combine \u201ctensor-network state\u201d structures with a genuine \u201cmeasurement-induced phase\u201d phenomenon in a static photonic network (no cavities, no feedback, only linear optics, probabilistic pair/single-photon sources, number-resolving detectors):\n    1) A square of four Bell pairs (a 4-node loop) with a **4-photon joint measurement** at the center that toggles between two orthonormal measurement bases\u2014one basis routes entanglement to opposite corners (A\u2194C, B\u2194D), the other to adjacent corners (A\u2194B, C\u2194D). Varying the internal phase of that central interferometer drives a sharp switch in which pair of nodes become entangled: a measurement-induced network-connectivity phase transition.\n    2) A 1D chain of Bell pairs where each bond has two measurement options\u2014a standard Bell swap or a 3-photon GHZ projection with an ancilla photon.  Cross a threshold in the number of GHZ vs. swap clicks and you see a nontrivial shift in the percolation threshold for end-to-end entanglement.\n    3) A triangular MPS of three Bell pairs forming a ring, with a single 3-port interferometer that implements a **cyclic entanglement swap** among the three nodes.  Tuning a phase in the interferometer causes an abrupt network reconfiguration (from ring to star topology), an abrupt measurement-induced network phase change.\n\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    1) **Most novel**: the square plus central 4-photon measurement is a truly new joint measurement primitive and realizes two distinct tensor-network contractions in one static circuit.  No prior Pytheus example has mixed two orthonormal 4-photon joint bases to toggle network connectivity.  \n    2) The GHZ vs swap percolation is conceptually nice but reduces to threshold counting in a longer chain\u2014too close to existing repeater-chain percolation.  \n    3) The triangle-ring switch is smaller but still boils down to two-swap patterns or router action already explored.\n\n  Step 3: Choose idea (1).\n\n  Step 4: Novelty\n    \u2022 First photonic experiment with a **single 4-photon joint measurement** that, by choice of measurement basis, selects one of two fundamentally different network connectivity graphs on the square.  \n    \u2022 The network exhibits a **measurement-induced phase transition**: as an internal phase \u03c6 in the 4\u00d74 interferometer sweeps through a critical angle \u03c6_c, the entanglement jumps from one pair of nodes to the other.\n\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus\n    \u2022 Uses only static linear optics (a 4\u00d74 multiport interferometer + phase shifters), four probabilistic Bell-pair sources, and photon-number-resolving detectors.  \n    \u2022 No dynamic feedback or exotic components.  \n    \u2022 `removed_connections` forbids any source from linking non-adjacent modes directly.  \n    \u2022 The **target** is the **network supermap**\u2014for each ancilla-click pattern in one of the two orthonormal measurement bases, the end nodes must collapse into the corresponding Bell pair.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\n{\n  \"explanation\": \"\nWe arrange four probabilistic Bell-pair sources in a square:\n  \u2022 S_AB emits a pair on modes A1,B1  \n  \u2022 S_BC emits on B2,C1  \n  \u2022 S_CD emits on C2,D1  \n  \u2022 S_DA emits on D2,A2  \n\nThe four central modes B1,B2,C2,D2 feed into a **static 4\u00d74 multiport interferometer** U(\u03c6), implemented by beam splitters and phase shifters with one tunable internal phase \u03c6. The outputs of U go to four ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors.\n\nWe define two orthonormal 4-photon measurement bases on (B1,B2,C2,D2):\n\n  \u2022 Basis X (\u03c6=0): measurement outcomes herald entanglement swapped between A1\u2194C1 and B2\u2194D1.  \n  \u2022 Basis Y (\u03c6=\u03c0): measurement outcomes herald entanglement swapped between A1\u2194B2 and C1\u2194D1.\n\nBy sweeping \u03c6 from 0 to \u03c0, U rotates from basis X to Y. The **network connectivity** of the outer nodes **jumps sharply** at a critical \u03c6_c, implementing a measurement-induced phase transition: below \u03c6_c you obtain the cross-diagonal entangled pairs (A1\u2013C1 & B2\u2013D1), above \u03c6_c the adjacent pairs (A1\u2013B2 & C1\u2013D1).\n\nThis is a **genuine tensor-network transformation** (two distinct contraction patterns on the square) driven solely by measurement basis choice.\n\n  Feeding this into Pytheus:\n\n  \u2022 Sources: 4 probabilistic Bell-pair emitters  \n  \u2022 Interferometer: 4\u00d74 static multiport with tunable \u03c6  \n  \u2022 Ancilla detectors: 4 photon-number-resolving detectors on the multiport outputs  \n  \u2022 End analyzers: 2 detectors each at modes A1,C1,B2,D1 to verify the heralded Bell pairs  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3],[1,4],[2,4]] (forbid direct non-neighbor sources)  \n\n  Target: for each \u03c6, the mapping (ancilla click pattern \u2192 which two outer modes share a Bell state) must match the pattern X for \u03c6\u22480 and Y for \u03c6\u2248\u03c0.  No fixed target state\u2014Pytheus optimizes the routing so that the two distinct measurement bases produce the two distinct entanglement graphs.\n\nThis setup uses only static linear optics, probabilistic sources, and number-resolving detectors\u2014no feedback or cavities\u2014and demonstrates the first **measurement-induced network phase transition** in a 2D tensor network.\",\n\n  \"config\": {\n    \"description\": \"Square network with 4\u00d74 central interferometer inducing entanglement-routing phase transition\",\n    \"foldername\": \"square_4port_phase\",\n    \"num_pairs\": 4,\n    \"single_emitters\": [],\n    \"num_anc\": 4,\n    \"anc_detectors\": [0,1,2,3],\n    \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3],[1,4],[2,4]],\n    \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n    \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n    \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n    \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n    \"edges_tried\": 50,\n    \"tries_per_edge\": 5,\n    \"safe_hist\": true,\n    \"number_resolving\": true,\n    \"target_transformation\": \"For \u03c6\u22480, clicks at {pattern X} \u2192 Bell pairs A1\u2013C1 & B2\u2013D1; for \u03c6\u2248\u03c0, clicks at {pattern Y} \u2192 Bell pairs A1\u2013B2 & C1\u2013D1.\"\n  }\n}"
